In order to grasp ACS, and their audiences' content needs, I took advantage of the team Hugo & Cat had already assembled:

- I collaborated with the UX Director to render ACS's information architecture in Figma, allowing us to easily visualize the branching of content. - Hosting co-design sessions like Crazy Eight, our whole team sketched their visions for the ACS home page, and newly-proposed landing pages. - Building upon existing UX research, I wrote landing page copy in 3 distinct "archetypes" which were A/B tested through surveys on the ACS site. - After analyzing the results of our A/B tests, we presented Figma prototypes to volunteer surgeons, and continued to iterate on their feedback. Once we had solidified a design direction for ACS, I developed a new taxonomy which enhanced navigation and search functionality within the site. In tandem, I annotated our audit sheet, marking pages that were to be prioritized, merged, or omitted for the migration to Umbraco. ---

As part of its philanthropic charter, Chan Zuckerberg Initiative was supporting the development of an open-source, Python-based image analysis tool called napari. Hired as a Sr. Content Designer by CZI, my responsibilities also included those of a project manager, and later an instructional designer:

- Ingest hundreds of pages of UX research on napari, and establish a full 6-month project plan, with milestones and tentative deadlines. - Audit the existing napari.org and napari-hub.org, and support 8 volunteer research scientists to conduct their own audits in tandem. - Host multiple co-design workshops with research scientists, and synthesize these findings into a formal proposal for our project MVP. - Design and build an iterative wiki-like onboarding platform for "non-coder" research biologists interested in adopting the napari tool. As co-lead of the "Bravo Cohort", I plugged into the CZI Slack, partook in daily and weekly stand-ups, and bi-monthly napari community meetings. At the end of 2020, Dolby Labs had a bit of a problem. It had been years since their last redesign, and in that time they had amassed a CMS of **thousands of pages of complex, seemingly disparate content** they couldn't possibly update themselves. Within that collection, Dolby was maintaining what were effectively two separate websites: one for casual consumers, and one for technical folks. Since the scale of this was beyond their scope, Dolby Labs recruited Valtech to re-organize and migrate **all of their domains** to the Sitecore engine. ---

As a consultant at Valtech, I became the Lead Content Strategist on the Dolby Labs re-design with a **2 week deadline** to:

- Audit the Dolby Labs consumer AND technical websites, and propose up to 12 page types to classify its thousands of web pages. - Onboard to Sitecore's CMS, and familiarize myself with hundreds of design components built specifically for Dolby Labs by developers. - Build interactive prototypes of the 12 proposed page types in Sitecore, and work with developers to modify components as needed. - Pitch this vision for Dolby.com to their marketing leadership, gain their buy-in, and lay out a long-term plan for migrating to Sitecore. Conferring with my product manager via Teams, I held daily stand-ups with her and our front-end engineering lead, ensuring I had access to the styling behind our design components, and approval for my creative direction. ---

metadata.title: Dolby Laboratories - Sitecore Migration

content:
[Document: Dolby Laboratories - Sitecore Migration | Tags: information-architecture, cms-migration, content-audit, page-templates, dual-audience-strategy, sitecore, dolby, valtech, lead-content-strategist, contemporary]

With the relatively short timeframe allotted to me (in the middle of May 2020), I quickly executed on a few parallel workstreams:

- On a Zoom call with our engineering lead, I exported Dolby Labs' domain sitemaps from their proprietary CMS, including all available metadata. - With the branching of Dolby's consumer and technical webpages clearly visualized for me, I discerned 10-12 buckets I could categorize them into. - After winning approval for these 12 page "archetypes," I built them in the Sitecore CMS, experimenting with a full library of branded components. - I created variations for each of these 12 templates, and annotated them from top-to-bottom for future copywriters and front-end devs to maintain. Upon reaching a consensus internally, I worked tirelessly with our front-end devs to launch a fully-functional demo of these 12 page archetypes on Sitecore. As needed, I requested new components, or modified existing ones, to achieve our unified vision. ---

Fine-tuning LLMs for specific personas is only half the battle. The harder problem: **how do you systematically evaluate whether a fine-tuned model actually sounds like the expert it's meant to embody?**

Traditional benchmarks measure factual accuracy, but they miss:
- Does it sound authentic to the expert's voice? - Is the therapeutic or coaching value actually present? - Does it maintain appropriate professional boundaries? - Can it push back against sycophancy? The goal: replace subjective "vibe checks" with quantifiable, reproducible metrics. ---

[Document: Subquadratic / Aldea AI - LLM Production Deployment | Tags: tensorrt-llm, triton-inference-server, tensor-parallelism, lora-adapters, gpu-optimization, multi-gpu-inference, model-serving, aldea, subquadratic, founding-engineer]

1. **TensorRT Version Mismatch**: Identified that engines built with newer TRT-LLM failed to deserialize on older Triton. Solution: Build engines inside the runtime container itself. 2. **MPI Worker Spawn Failures**: OpenMPI's process spawning failed in Docker containers. Solution: Configured orchestrator mode to use single-process architecture. 3. **GPU Isolation**: Standard CUDA environment variables were ignored in NVIDIA container runtime. Solution: Used proper Docker Compose device reservations. 4. **LoRA Cache OOM**: Default LoRA cache size insufficient for 70B models. Solution: Configured host memory and max adapter size parameters. 5. **RoPE Configuration**: Extended context models use custom RoPE scaling. Solution: Verified automatic reading of scaling parameters from config files. 6. **BF16 LoRA Dtype Mismatch**: Host NumPy doesn't support BF16. Solution: Store BF16 bit-patterns in uint16 arrays, converting via FP32 intermediate. 7. **Weight Streaming**: Plugin weights aren't streamable. Solution: Rebuild engines with plugin disabled alongside streaming flags. 8. **Multi-GB LoRA Payloads**: gRPC/MPI transport constraints blocked large adapter uploads. Solution: Implemented system shared memory for LoRA seeding—register regions, send only metadata over gRPC. ---

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
[Document: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966) | Tags: zeus, dqt, hellenosemitica, etymology, graeco-semitic-doublet, toponymy, group-writing, syllabic-orthography, knossos, amnisos]

This article analyzes a newly published topographical list from Amenhotep III's (1406–1369 BCE) funeral temple at Kom el Hetan, identifying nine toponyms written in Egyptian "group writing" (syllabic orthography). Kitchen had already tentatively identified Knossos and Amnisos; Astour confirms these and extends the identifications to cover all nine names, placing them in Crete, the Peloponnese (Kingdom of Pylos), and Kythera. The article demonstrates that Egyptians of the 14th century BCE knew specific Aegean localities far better than previously supposed, confirming steady connections between Egypt, the Levant, and the Aegean. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This provides direct documentary evidence—from an Egyptian royal inscription—of Bronze Age Egyptian knowledge of specific Minoan and Mycenaean localities, corroborating the archaeological evidence for sustained Aegean-Near Eastern contact. ---

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
[Document: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966) | Tags: zeus, dqt, hellenosemitica, etymology, graeco-semitic-doublet, toponymy, group-writing, syllabic-orthography, knossos, amnisos]

K. A. Kitchen published the inscription from Base C at Kom el Hetan and tentatively identified:
- **Ku-nu-sha** = Knossos (Linear B *ko-no-so*)
- **'A-m-ni-sha** = Amnisos (harbor of Knossos)
- **Ri-ka-ta** = Lyktos (tentatively)

Kitchen hesitated: "Could this list just conceivably be partly Syrian and partly 'Keftiu' (Cretan)? The latter would have to be ports or towns trading with Egypt (construed as tribute)."

Astour's response: "Kitchen had no reason to hesitate in making his absolutely plausible equation."

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
[Document: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966) | Tags: zeus, dqt, hellenosemitica, etymology, graeco-semitic-doublet, toponymy, group-writing, syllabic-orthography, knossos, amnisos]

**Egyptian spelling**: The second syllable is "pleonastically spelled as the Egyptian root *q₃*, 'be high,' combining its two graphic variants... including its determinative 'high.'"

**Linear B confirmation**: *di-ka-ta-de* "to Dikte" (KN Fp 7:2), *di-ka-ta-jo di-we* "to Dictaean Zeus" (KN Fp 1:2)

**The Graeco-Semitic doublet**:
> "Hesiod's (Theogony 484) Aigaion oros, 'Goat's Mountain,' in Crete, where the infant Zeus was raised in a secret holy cave, is evidently identical with the mountain and cave of Dikte. Aigaion oros = Diktê may well be a Graeco-Semitic doublet, for in Ugaritic ritual texts *dqt* (literally, 'small one') was the term for a 'female head of small cattle for sacrifice,' and a goat rather than a sheep."

**Divine name**: "*Dqt* is also found as a divine name in a Ugaritic list of gods (RS 24.246), which reminds us of the goat that nourished Zeus in the Dictaean cave."

**Phonetic match**: "Egyptian *dj* transcribed the Semitic zayin and sade, while the Greek zêta derived from and transcribed the Semitic zayin."

Astour extracts phonetic data from the Egyptian spelling:

> "We have now the name of Knossos written in a script which is phonetically (so far as consonants are concerned) greatly superior to Linear B. We see that its first consonant corresponds to Egyptian *k* (= Semitic kaph), and its last, to Egyptian *sh* (= Semitic 'true' shin)."

**Sea Peoples connection**: The *-sha* ending matches 'A-qi-ya-wa-sha (Ahhiyawa/Achaeans), Tu-ru-sha (Tyrsenians), Sha-k(a)-ru-sha (Sikels), Wa-sha-sha

metadata.title: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966)

content:
[Document: Aegean Place-Names in an Egyptian Inscription (1966) | Tags: zeus, dqt, hellenosemitica, etymology, graeco-semitic-doublet, toponymy, group-writing, syllabic-orthography, knossos, amnisos]

**Phonetic analysis**: The apparent vowel discrepancy (*Ri-ka-ta* vs. *Ru-ki-to*) follows known patterns:

> "Hesitation between *i* and *y(u)* is frequent in pre-Greek names adopted into Greek. In Crete itself, the name of the city of Itanos is spelled *I-ta-nu* in Linear A, but *U-ta-no* in Linear B."

**Semitic transmission pattern**: The form *Likata* follows "a common pattern in Syrian toponymy of the 15th-13th centuries B.C." (cf. Ar-da-ta, Ir-qa-ta, U-ga-ri-ta). The relationship between *Lukto-* and *Likat(a)* is "that between status rectus and status absolutus of a Semitic feminine noun."

**Tentative identification**: If the lost sign before *w* was *p*, the result would be *[P]ā-k(i)-'a-nu* = Linear B *Pa-ki-ja-ne*, "an important town of the Kingdom of Pylos, frequently mentioned in Linear B tablets."

**Geographic distribution**: "If this is so, four toponyms of the new list would belong to the Kingdom of Pylos, four to Crete, and one to the principal island between the two."

This methodological manifesto, published a year before *Hellenosemitica*, establishes Astour's three key analytical methods: the **method of doublets** (borrowed from Victor Bérard), **functional parallelism** (names must match in mythological role, not just sound), and the **method of vestiges** (traces of older myths preserved in later versions). The article demonstrates these methods through two extended case studies: Membliaros/Poikiles as West Semitic cosmogonic terminology, and Cadmos as the West Semitic dawn-deity *qadm* whose entire mythological cycle betrays Semitic origins (Semele = *Ṣml*, Actaeon = *Aqht*, Thebes = *têbâ*, Bakchos = *bākâ*). **Why this matters for Kothar**: This article provides the essential methodological framework for all of Astour's etymological work. It also explicitly references Cyrus Gordon's Linear A decipherment as "the most important documentary proof of a strong West Semitic element" in Crete. ---

> "These indications are quite precise. They do not confirm the existence of a permanent Mycenaean settlement at Ugarit... In the second millennium B.C. the trend of influence seems to have followed the opposite direction." (p. 194)

Astour's first extended demonstration of methodology:

**The name**: *Membliaros* = W-S *mêm-bli-'âr* = "waters without light"

**Functional confirmation** (Apollonius Rhodius, *Argonautica* IV.1694–98):
> "Night scared them, that night which they name the Pall of Darkness; the stars pierced not that fatal night nor the beams of the moon, but black chaos descended from heaven."

This description of cosmogonic darkness occurs precisely when the Argonauts approach Anaphe-Membliaros. **Poikiles** (Membliaros's father) = W-S *pî-kôl* "womb of all"

**Combined formula**: *mêm-bli-'âr pî-kôl* = "dark water, the womb of all"—matching Phoenician and Orphic cosmogony exactly.

**Ladon** (Theban river from dragon's blood) = Ugaritic dragon *Ltn* (Leviathan)

This opening chapter establishes Astour's central thesis: that the Greek Danaans (*Danaoi*) and the Cilician Danunians (*Dnnym*) share more than a coincidental name—they share West Semitic origins. Astour marshals evidence from the Karatepe inscription, Amarna letters, Egyptian sources, and East Cilician toponymics to demonstrate that the Danunians were indigenous West Semites, not Greek colonizers. He then analyzes the Greek mythological figure Danaos alongside the Ugaritic hero Danel (*Dnil*) to show functional parallels that point to a common Semitic origin. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter provides the foundational argument that Greek civilization's mythological ancestry (the Danaans/Danaoi of Homer) traces back to Semitic populations in the Eastern Mediterranean—a key pillar of the Hellenosemitic thesis. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians | Tags: danel, baal, reshef, el, hellenosemitica, etymology, ethnic-names, gentilic-suffix, method-of-relics, toponymy]

The 1946 discovery of the Karatepe bilingual inscription (Phoenician and Hieroglyphic Luwian) by H. T. Bossert revealed a kingdom of "Danunians" (*Dnnym*) in Eastern Cilicia, ruled by the "House of Mopsos" (*Bt-Mps*). This discovery ignited debate about whether the Danunians were:

- Anatolian natives
- Greek colonizers (Danaans from Greece)
- West Semitic inhabitants

Astour argues decisively for the West Semitic option based on:

1. **The Phoenician language** of the inscription itself
2. **Semitic divine names** in the royal pantheon (Baal, El, Reshef)
3. **Semitic toponymics** throughout Eastern Cilicia
4. **The name Danuna** itself, which has clear West Semitic formation

> "The numerous scholars who have studied the Karatepe inscription and the problems connected with it have not considered the possibility of a Semitic character in the name Danuna, borne by the inhabitants of that country—the Danunians. If the name Danuna had been discovered not in Palestine, there would hardly have been any doubts about its purely West-Semitic (W-S) origin." (p. 61)

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter I: The Danaans-Danunians | Tags: danel, baal, reshef, el, hellenosemitica, etymology, ethnic-names, gentilic-suffix, method-of-relics, toponymy]

Astour demonstrates that *Danuna* has transparent West Semitic morphology:

- **Root**: *dān* (W-S "to judge")—cognate with Hebrew tribe of *Dān*, Ugaritic sage *Dnil* (Daniel), and Amarna personal name *Danuna* (EA 117:92)
- **Suffix**: *-una/-ana*—the standard W-S gentilic ending (cf. *Ṣidōn* < *Ṣidūna*, *'Ašqelōn* < *'Ašqalūna*)

The name follows the same pattern as Palestinian toponyms preserved in the Amarna letters:

| Amarna Form | Biblical Form |
|-------------|---------------|
| *A-ia-lu-na* | *'Ayyālôn* |
| *Aš-qa-lu-na* | *'Ašqelôn* |
| *Zi-du-na* | *Ṣidôn* |
| *Sa-ru-na* | *Šārôn* |

> "Thus the W-S name *Danuna* is not just a hypothetical construction: it is actually found in EA 117:92 as a personal name; and it is known that W-S names of towns and tribes were often formed after the same models as those of persons and frequently coincided with them." (p. 72)

Drawing on king Idri-mi of Alalah's campaign records and Hittite delimitation treaties, Astour identifies numerous Semitic place-names in Eastern Cilicia:

**From Idri-mi's campaign (~1500 BCE):**
- *Ṣa-ru-na*: W-S root *ṣar* "narrow" (cf. *Šārôn*)
- *I-e*: Hebrew *'î* "island, coast-land"
- *Da-ma-ru-ut-re*: Semitic *damara*

**Adana itself:**
> "The name *'dn*, preserved up to this day as Adana, is also Semitic and derives from *'adân* 'lord' (which became in South Canaanite, including Hebrew, *'ādōn*)—a frequent divine title, especially well known by the Greco-Phoenician Adonis." (p. 40)

The evidence shows that Eastern Cilicia had the same mixed Hurrian-Semitic population as North Syria (Ugarit, Alalah).

Astour addresses the presence of the "House of Mopsos" (*Bt-Mps*), which some scholars cite as proof of Greek colonization. He demonstrates that Mopsos was:

1. **Not exclusively Greek**—the name appears in Lydian, Thessalian, and Anatolian contexts
2. **Originally Anatolian**—the form *Muksas* in Hieroglyphic Luwian suggests an Asianic name
3. **Retrojected**—Greek legends about Mopsos founding Cilician cities arose *after* Greek colonization (~700 BCE), not before

> "Thessalian *Mopsion*, Ionian Claros and Colophon, Lydia, Phrygia, Cabalia, Attica, Libya, Pamphylia, Lycian Phaselis, Palestinian Ascalon, Cilician Mallos—is it not too wide an arena for one life, are not there too many cities founded for one man?" (p. 86)

Astour's most innovative argument compares the Greek eponymous hero Danaos with the Ugaritic hero Danel (*Dnil*), protagonist of the Aqhat epic:

**Functional Parallels:**

| Danel (Ugaritic) | Danaos (Greek) |
|------------------|----------------|
| Healer (*mtrpi*), judge, soothsayer | King who brought fertility to Argos |
| Daughter Pǵt "who shoulders water, spreads dew on barley" | Daughters (Danaides) who "watered the country," found springs |
| Pǵt arms herself with dagger for vengeance | Danaides armed with daggers, kill husbands |
| Connected with agricultural cycles | Daughters introduced Thesmophoria (Demeter's feast) |

> "The Argive Danaos is an analogous character—to judge from the relics in the myth. He and his daughters brought fertility to the Argive plain. His daughters found springs, and to them was also ascribed the introduction of the Thesmophoria." (p. 100)

The Hebrew tribe of Dan also connects to this complex through the Blessing of Jacob: "Dan will judge his people" (Gen. 49:16) and his serpent symbolism (Gen. 49:17)—matching Danel's chthonic, agrarian character.

Astour explains how the Semitic *Danuna* became Greek *Danaoi*:

- Original: *Dān* + *-una* (W-S gentilic suffix)
- Hellenized: *Dān* + *-awoi* (I-E suffix of belonging)
- Result: *Danawoi* > *Danaoi*

This follows the same pattern as Hittite *Adanawa* ("that of Adana") and is confirmed by Mycenaean tablets where names ending in *-aos* are spelled *-awo-*. > "Thus the Gr. *Dana(w)oi* is a regular Hellenization of the Semitic ethnic name *Danuna* by way of replacing its gentilic ending *-una* (or *-ana*) with the Indo-European equivalent suffix *-aw-*." The place-names of Eastern Cilicia in the second millennium were Hurrian, Akkadian and W-S, and they survived far into the first millennium. > "In our approach to the Danaos myth, we shall not begin by another attempt to reinterpret it as an historical relation... We should like to put the question in this way: if the Argive Danaans really had come from the Semitic East, and if the myth about their eponym Danaos really had been born among the Danaans themselves, then this myth must have had a close analogy to the W-S myths which were told in Syria, Phoenicia, and Palestine about the hero whose name the Cilician Danunians bore." metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids | Tags: cadmos, europa, semele, dionysos, actaeon, membliaros, poikiles, harmonia, ningiszida, cabiri]

This chapter is the heart of *Hellenosemitica*—Astour's most sustained demonstration that the Theban mythological cycle (Cadmos, Europa, Semele, Dionysos, Actaeon, Pentheus) derives from West Semitic religious traditions. Astour begins not with Cadmos himself but with the obscure Phoenician settler Membliaros on the island of Thera, showing that even minor figures in Herodotus preserve authentic Semitic cosmogonic traditions. He then traces Europa (= W-S *ʿarôb*, "sunset") and Cadmos (= W-S *qadm*, "east/dawn") as the Evening and Morning Stars—siblings who can never meet. The chapter culminates in detailed analyses of Semele (= Ugaritic *Ṣml*, "Eagle-Mother"), Actaeon (= Ugaritic *Aqht*), and the Semitic elements pervading the cult of Dionysos. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter provides the core evidence that Greek mythology's most famous Phoenician—Cadmos—actually was Phoenician, with name, myths, and cult elements traceable to Ugarit and broader West Semitic religion. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids | Tags: cadmos, europa, semele, dionysos, actaeon, membliaros, poikiles, harmonia, ningiszida, cabiri]

Herodotus (IV.147) reports that Phoenicians under Membliaros son of Poikiles settled on Thera. Astour demonstrates this is not invention but authentic memory of West Semitic cosmogonic ritual:

- **Membliaros** = W-S *mêm-bli-ʾâr*, "waters without light"
- **Poikiles** = W-S *pî-kôl*, "womb of all" (the primordial chaos)

The cosmogonic darkness described in Apollonius Rhodius's *Argonautica* IV.1694-98—"black chaos descended from heaven"—occurs precisely at the island Anaphe-Membliaros, proving the Semitic etymology correct. > "The fragment speaks for itself; it operates with such notions, sacralized by liturgic tradition, as 'black chaos' and 'darkness rising from the nethermost depths,' which reminds one of 'the dark air' and 'the obscure, Erebos-like chaos' of Philo, and 'darkness upon the face of the Deep' of Gen. I: 2." (p. 120)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids | Tags: cadmos, europa, semele, dionysos, actaeon, membliaros, poikiles, harmonia, ningiszida, cabiri]

Hesychius defines *Eurōpē* as "land of sunset, or dark one" (*chōra tēs dyseōs, ē skoteinē*). This semantics cannot derive from Greek but only from Semitic *ʿrb* ("to set," of the sun; "to be dark"). Astour identifies Europa's Semitic prototype in Ugaritic texts:
- *UM 9:9* lists offerings for *ʿrb špš*, "the personified sunset"
- An Akkadian hymn in Ugaritic script (UM 104) hymns "Night, the veiled bride, who enters into the sunset"

The constant epithet of this Night-goddess—*kuttumtum*, "veiled"—appears on Greek coins of Europa and in the Cretan name **Tektamos** (= W-S *tiktam*, "she is veiled"). > "The myth of Europa: the goddess of night, the veiled bride, who goes away into the sunset, as Europa (= Sunset/Evening) was carried away far westward, to Crete, and there became the mate of Zeus." (p. 137)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids | Tags: cadmos, europa, semele, dionysos, actaeon, membliaros, poikiles, harmonia, ningiszida, cabiri]

Astour demonstrates that wherever the eponym Phoenix appears in Greek myth, Semitic traces are present:

| Greek Name | Semitic Etymology | Meaning | Evidence |
|------------|-------------------|---------|----------|
| **Phoenix** | *Pûnî* | "Of the madder-dye" | Num. 26:23; *puwwā* = *Rubia tinctorum L.* |
| **Itanos** (son of Phoenix) | *'êtân* | "Strong, perennial" | *nahal 'êtân* (Amos 5:24) |
| **Karnos** (son of Phoenix) | *qarn* | "Horn" | Coins spell *Qrn*; Latin *Cornu Phenices* |
| **Kythera** (son of Phoenix) | *keter, kōteret* | "Crown, tiara" | Method of doublets with *Skandeia* |

**Archaeological evidence**: A cuneiform dedication of Naram-Sin, king of Ešnunna (18th century BCE), was found on Cythera—proving Mesopotamian connections through Semitic maritime routes. > "Wherever the eponym or toponym Phoenix is found, evident traces of Semitism are present." (p. 143)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids | Tags: cadmos, europa, semele, dionysos, actaeon, membliaros, poikiles, harmonia, ningiszida, cabiri]

Astour addresses the systematic effort to deny Cadmos's Phoenician origin:

**Ed. Meyer's objection**: Thebes' "mid-continent" location contradicts Phoenician coastal settlement patterns. **Astour's rebuttal**: Thebes lies only 12 miles from the Gulf of Corinth and 15 miles from the Euripos. Compare: Alalah was 25+ miles from the sea; Adana and Karatepe similarly inland—yet their kings had ships and engaged in sea-battles (depicted in Azitawadd's palace reliefs). > "The topography of Thebes corresponds exactly to that of the capitals of the North Canaanite maritime states which, in the IId millennium, linked the Orient with the Aegean." (p. 151)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids | Tags: cadmos, europa, semele, dionysos, actaeon, membliaros, poikiles, harmonia, ningiszida, cabiri]

**Cadmos** = W-S *qadm*, "east/front/dawn." Three Greek forms (*Kadmos*, *Kadmōn*, *Kadmaíōn*) reflect W-S forms (*Qdm*, *Qdmn*, *Qdmyn*). Astour's key insight: Cadmos and Europa are the two aspects of Venus—Morning Star (male) and Evening Star (female)—who can never meet:

> "If Europa is the west, the Evening Star, then Cadmos, as shown by his name, is the east, the Morning Star... The Evening Star goes away to the west, disappears beyond the sea; the Morning Star, her brother, rushes to her search, but the two can never meet." (p. 153)

A god *Qa-a-dm-u* is attested in Babylonia. In the Ugaritic poem UM 75:I.7-8, *qdm* ("East") parallels *šhr* ("Dawn"), establishing that *Qdm* was another name for the dawn-god *Šahar*. Cadmos's serpent-transformation connects him to the Sumerian *Ningišzida*—a chthonic serpent-god, personification of sunrise, dragon-victor, and city-founder. **The Ningišzida Parallels:**

| Shared Motif | Cadmos | Ningišzida |
|--------------|--------|------------|
| **Serpent symbolism** | Transformed into entwined serpents | Serpent-god, entwined serpent emblem |
| **Dragon-victor** | Kills the dragon at Thebes | Conquers dragons |
| **Sunrise personification** | *Qadm* = "East/Dawn" | "Sun which rose from the fruitful earth" |
| **City-founder** | Founds Thebes | Establishes city foundations |

> "The goddess Nanše revealed in his dream: 'The sun which rose from the fruitful earth is thy god Ningizzida who, like the sun, rises for thee out of the fruitful earth.'" (p. 157, quoting Gudea)

**The Cabiri Connection:**

The Cabiri (*Kabeiroi*) = W-S *kabbîr* "great, mighty." Their worship centers (Thebes, Samothrace) connect to Cadmos:
- Original number: seven (matching Ugaritic poem UM 52 with *Šhr*, *Šlm*, and five anonymous gods)
- The only known Cabiri name: **Kadmilos** = W-S *Qadm-ʾēl* "Qadm the god" (cf. Hebrew *Qadmîʾēl* Ezra 3:9)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter II: Cadmos and the Cadmids | Tags: cadmos, europa, semele, dionysos, actaeon, membliaros, poikiles, harmonia, ningiszida, cabiri]

**Semele** (= Ugaritic *Ṣml*, "Eagle-Mother"):
In the Ugaritic poem of Aqht, the goddess *Ṣml* is the "Mother of the Eagles" who swallowed the remains of the slain hero Aqht. In Greek myth, Semele swallows Dionysos's heart and becomes pregnant with his new incarnation. > "Ṣml thus corresponds to Semele both by her name and by her function in the myth." (from Greek Names article, cf. p. 170)

**Actaeon** (= Ugaritic *Aqht*):
The proud young hunter torn apart by his hounds directly parallels Aqht, the proud young hunter slain for refusing to cede his bow to the goddess Anath. The name derives from extended forms *Aqhtn* or *Aqhtyn*. **Dionysos** and his epithets:
- *Bakchos* = W-S *bākuy*, from root *bākâ*, "to weep" (cf. Hesychius: *bakchon* is Phoenician for "mourning")
- *Bassareus* / *Bassarids* = W-S *bāṣar*, "to cut, to tear to pieces"

The myth of Zagreus-Dionysos (dismembered and eaten by Titans) has close parallels in Ugaritic texts describing the fate of Aqht. ---

This opening section of Chapter III establishes the foundation for understanding Greek healer-heroes as derivatives of Semitic and Sumerian healing deities. Astour begins with the name "Bellerophon" (*B'l-rāphôn* = "Healing Baal") and builds outward to demonstrate that an entire category of Greek mythological figures—distinguished not by genealogy but by their role as healers—traces back to Near Eastern prototypes. The section examines Sumerian *Ninazu* ("Lord Physician"), the serpent-god *Ningišzida*, the Ugaritic *Rpu-Bʿl* ("Healing Lord"), and the bird-symbolism (especially owls) that pervades both Babylonian medicine and Greek mythology. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This section reveals that Greek healing mythology is deeply rooted in Semitic and Sumerian traditions, with the serpent (a key Minoan symbol) and the owl serving as cross-cultural symbols of healing and chthonic wisdom. ---

content:

Astour refines H. Lewy's earlier Semitic etymology of Bellerophon:

- **Root**: W-S *rpʾ* "to heal" (not *rpy* "to sink")
- **Formation**: *Baʿal* + *rāphôn* = "Baal the Healer" or "Healing Lord"
- **Parallel**: Ugaritic personal name *Rpan* (UM 91:7), Akkadian *mRap-a-na*

The Greek rendering follows normal patterns:
- *a* > *e* common in Greek transcriptions (cf. *Ekdippa* < *ʿAkzib*)
- Double lambda compensates for dropped laryngal
- Variant *Ellerophontês* reflects alternate form *ʿEl-Rāphôn*

> "With the preceding emendations, the derivation of Bellerophôn from *Baʿal-rāphôn* is quite possible and regular. However, *comparaison n'est pas raison*... the principal and essential stress is put on the similarity and relationship not of names, but of mythical motifs." (p. 234)

**Methodological principle**: Etymology alone is insufficient; the *functional role* of the figure must also match.

Astour traces the Sumerian prototypes that influenced West Semitic healing gods:

**Ninazu** (*dNin-a-zu* "Lord Physician"):
- Name literally translates into W-S as *Baʿal-rāphôn*
- Conceived in Hades (chthonic nature)
- Prototype of many W-S healing deities

**Ningišzida** (*dNin-giš-zi(d)-da*):
- Son of Ninazu
- Symbol: serpent or two entwined serpents
- Depicted with serpents growing from shoulders
- Identified with serpent-deity Šeraḫ and constellation Hydra (*mulMuš*)
- Related to "tree" or "wooden pole" as vegetation symbol

> "As convincingly shown by Starcky in his excellent study, Ninazu was, most probably, the prototype of many, if not of all, W-S healing gods. His name literally means 'Lord Physician' and, translated into W-S, is actually found in different variants." (p. 237)

Astour demonstrates that the Ugaritic deity *Mš* (son of Baal and the heifer-goddess Anath) is the Sumerian serpent-god *Muš*:

**Phonetic correspondence**: Flawless—Ugaritic *š* = Sumerian *š* [sh]

**Evidence against Egyptian origin** (cf. Moses):
- No Egyptian divine/human names borrowed in Ugaritic texts
- Sumerian element prominent in Ugaritic pantheon

**Sumerian deities at Ugarit** (7 attested):
1. *Nkl-w-Ib* < *Ningal* + *enbu*
2. *Ušhry* < Išhara (healing goddess)
3. *Prgl* < Piri(g)gal "Great Lioness"
4. *Ppšr* < Pap-sukkal
5. *Pbl-mlk* < Pa-bil-sag
6. *Bʿlt-bhtm* < Nin-é-gal
7. *Mš* < Muš "serpent"

**Feminine form** *Mšt*: Appears in names *Mšt-Dnty* (wife of Danel) and *Mšt-Hry* (wife of Krt)—"she-serpent" with W-S feminine ending.

The Ugaritic *Rpu-Bʿl*, son of Baal and the heifer, is:
- Identical with *Mš* in the mythological plane
- A chthonic deity
- The exact W-S translation of Sumerian *Ninazu* ("Lord Physician")

This establishes the chain: **Ninazu** → **Rpu-Bʿl** → **Bellerophon**

content:

Astour reveals the crucial role of nocturnal birds (especially owls) in Babylonian medicine and Greek mythology:

**Akkadian owl-terms**:
- *kâsu* / *kôs* "owl" → Greek island **Kôs** (sacred to Asclepios)
- *eššepu* "owl" AND "exorcist-priest"
- *anpatu* → Greek **Anaphê** (island) and *'ânâphâ* (Heb. bird-name)

**The Coan Myth Cycle** (Antoninus Liberalis):
- King Merops (= *merappeʾ* "healer") changed into eagle
- Son Eumelos → *nyktikorax* (owl)
- Son Agron → *charadrios* (night-bird)
- Daughter Meropis → *glaux* (owl)
- Daughter Byssa → *bûṣu* (owl)

> "This local myth from the island of Asclepios is very significant. It not only reveals its Semitic toponymics, but also shows how strong the Semitic impact was precisely in the cycle referring to the sphere of chthonic healing-spirits, personified in Cos—as in Babylon—as nocturnal birds of prey." (p. 256)

**Athena's owl**: Not accidental but inherited from Near Eastern bird-goddesses. *Glaukōpis* = "owl-eyed/owl-faced," not "grey-eyed."

This section applies Astour's methodological principle—that names must be validated by *functional parallels*—to Bellerophon and his entire family tree. Astour demonstrates that Bellerophon's grandfather Sisyphos, grandmother Merope, and father Glaucos all bear names with Semitic healing-god connections. The section then analyzes the Bellerophon-Anteia conflict as a variant of the widespread Near Eastern "chaste youth slandered by rejected woman" motif (cf. Joseph and Potiphar's wife, Bata, Ešmun). The analysis extends to the Chimaera, Pegasos, and parallels with Hippolytos, Phaëthon, and the "flying heroes" (Icaros, Idas, Abaris). **Why this matters for Kothar**: This section reveals that Greek hero myths—even those seemingly "native" like Bellerophon—preserve Near Eastern mythological structures, divine names, and cult patterns related to healing, the underworld, and the dying-and-rising god. ---

Bellerophon's grandfather Sisyphos defies Greek etymology ("Very Very Wise One" < *sophos*). Astour derives him from Akkadian:

- **Etymology**: *šešup* = Š-stem permansive of *(w)ašapu* "to incant, to bewitch"
- **Meaning**: "The one producing incantations/witchcraft"
- **Cognates**: *āšipu* "exorcist-priest," *eššepu* "owl/exorcist"

**Mythological confirmation**:
- Sisyphos chained Death himself—the ultimate healing feat
- His city **Ephyra** = W-S *ʾäphurā* "dusty" = the Nether World (Akk. *Bît epri* "House of Dust")
- Brothers Cretheus and Salmoneus bear Semitic names
- Brother Athamas married Ino (Semitic goddess), father of Melicertes/Palaemon

> "Victory over Death, prolongation of human life was the greatest that was expected from a healing god." (p. 252)

Sisyphos's wife Merope (one of the Pleiades):

- **Etymology**: W-S *merappeʾ* "female healer" (< *rpʾ* "to heal")
- **Pleiades connection**: Babylonian *Sibittu* "the Heptad"—defenders against evil spirits; located near Scorpion constellation (symbol of healing goddess Išhara)
- **Father Atlas**: W-S El in his role as ocean-ruler (cognate with Ea, the *a-zu* "water-knower")

**Mythological function**: Merope helped Sisyphos escape Hades by deliberately omitting funeral rites, enabling his return. She "knew how to return dead men to life."

Bellerophon's father Glaucos:

- **Etymology**: From *glaux* "owl" (not "grey sea")
- **Cognate with Sisyphos**: *glaux* corresponds to Akkadian *eššepu* "owl/exorcist"
- **Brother Ornytion**: Greek *ornithion* "bird"—confirming the bird-nature

**Mythological parallels**:
- Torn by maddened horses (= dismemberment/sparagmos)
- Same death as Hippolytos, Pentheus, Lycurgos
- Connected to the "dying god" pattern (Zagreus, *Rpu-Bʿl*)
- Worshipped at Corinth as *Taraxippos* (horse-frightening demon)

**Three Glaukoi** (variants of same figure):
1. Corinthian Glaucos (Bellerophon's father)
2. Boeotian sea-god Glaucos (fishtail, prophet, possesses plant of life)
3. Cretan Glaucos (Minos's son, revived by serpent's healing herb)

> "The name of Glaucos was a Greek one, and has a very transparent significance. It means 'rent by horses' and indicates the circumstances of the hero's death." (p. 259)

The core myth: Anteia (Proitos's wife) falsely accuses Bellerophon of attempted seduction. **Near Eastern parallels**:
- Joseph and Potiphar's wife (Gen. 39:7-20)
- Bata in Egyptian *Tale of Two Brothers*
- Ešmun and Astronoë/Astarte
- Combabos (= Humbaba) and Stratonice
- Baal and Ašertu (Hittite version)
- Gilgameš and Ištar (tablet VI)

**The goddess behind Anteia**:
- *Anteia* = Greek rendering of **Anath** (*ʿAnat*, *ʿAntit*)
- Doublet name **Stheneboea** = "mighty cow" = epithet of Anath (cf. *Lʾt* "cow/mighty")
- Daughter **Maira** = W-S *maʿîrā* "the shining one" (Morning Star = Anath as Venus/*Kaukabtā*)

> "The wife of Proitos who slandered Bellerophon is called Anteia in the Iliad: this is a correct and precise rendering of the name of Anath." (p. 266)

**Chimaera**: Not volcanic allegory but Semitic sea-monster:
- Etymology: W-S *ḥāmar* "to heave, to foam" (of sea)—cf. Habakkuk 3:15 *ḥōmer mayim rabbîm* "foaming of great waters"
- Related to Leviathan (*Ltn*), the seven-headed sea-dragon
- Fire-breathing matches Leviathan description (Job 41:11-13)
- Composite monsters (lion-goat-serpent) = Mesopotamian *Mischgestalten*

**Pegasos**: The winged horse:
- Iconographically Oriental (Assyrian seals show winged horses)
- Ugaritic text RS 24.244 mentions divinized horses, daughter of Sun-goddess
- "Daughter of the source, daughter of the Ocean" = Hesiod's Pegasos "born near the sources (*pēgai*) of Ocean"
- Horses sacred to the Sun (cf. II Kings 23:11)

- Same death by horses (= sparagmos)
- Dying god of Adonis type (Frazer)
- Name = "rent by horses" (describes death, not original name)

**Phaëthon** = Canaanite **Hêlêl ben Šaḥar** (Isaiah 14:12-15):
- *Phaëthōn* "the shining" = exact translation of *Hêlêl*
- Son of Eos (Dawn) = "son of Dawn" (*ben Šaḥar*)
- Ascension to heaven, fall to underworld
- Struck by Zeus's lightning

> "The name, image, and myth of Phaëthon go back to the Canaanite myth of Hêlêl ben Šahar 'Shining One, son of Dawn,' preserved as a fragment in Isaiah 14:12-15." (p. 280)

**The mythical river Eridanos**: Derives from Eridu (Ea's city), the river of the Nether World (*Hubur*).

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part B: Bellerophon, His Family, and His Adventures | Tags: bellerophon, sisyphos, glaucos, anath, phaethon, hippolytos, lucifer, leviathan, hellenosemitica, etymology]

**Icaros** = W-S *ʾikkâr* "farmer" (< Akkadian *ikkaru* < Sumerian ENGAR):
- Agrarian and chthonic motifs
- Erigone "the early born" (Dawn/Morning Star)
- Pestilence/healing themes
- Same heavenward flight, fall pattern

**Marpessa** = W-S *marpeʾ* "healer" + Greek feminine *-ssa*:
- Flew in winged chariot with husband Idas
- Father **Aphareus** = W-S *ʿāphār* "dust" (= Underworld)

**Idas and Amorite Onomastics** (pp. 272–273):

Astour derives Idas from the Semitic root **yd'** "to know, to learn, to apprehend":

> "Its stem is Ida-, declinable according to the first declension. It may well derive from the Semitic root *yd'* 'to know, to learn, to apprehend', Akk. *idû*, Heb. perf. *yâda'*, but in some proper names (*ʾÂbîdâʾ* Gen. 25:4, *Šemîdâʾ* Num. 26:32) *yidâʿ*."

**Key methodological point**: "Ida-" was a productive element in **early 2nd millennium Amorite names**:

> "This form was, apparently, quite ancient, for in W-S (Amorite) names of early IId millennium it is found even in the beginning of a name, as **Idamaras**, a tribe and a country in Mesopotamia."

Astour analyzes **Idamaras** etymologically:
- *maraṣu* (Akkadian) / *mrs* (Ugaritic) = "to be ill, become ill"
- *marṣu* (noun) = "disease"
- *Ida-maras* = "he knows the disease" OR "Maraṣ (the disease-god) knows"

This confirms the healer-pattern: "knowledge of the secret of causes of the sickness and of the no less secret procedures of cure belonged to the first duties of a medicine-man."

**Connection to bird-god Zû**: The Akkadian *Zû* derives from Sumerian *zu* "who knows"—the same semantic field. Idas shares Zû's characteristics:
- Name meaning "who knows"
- Ability to fly (winged chariot)
- Theomachy (rivaling Apollo)
- Death by Zeus's thunderbolt

> "Idas, 'the one who knows,' is an appropriate husband for Marpessa, 'the healer.'" (p. 273)

**Abaris** = Hebrew *ʿābar* "to fly, soar":
- Hyperborean priest of Apollo
- Flew on golden arrow
- Healed diseases, saved Sparta from pestilence
- Built temple of Persephone the Savior

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia | Tags: jason, iasion, demeter, aietes, circe, medea, zu, anath, shamash, hellenosemitica]

This section traces the healing-god origins of Jason ("the healer") and his entire mythological cycle. Astour begins with Iasion (lover of Demeter in the *hieros gamos*), demonstrates parallels with Hebrew Ruth-Boaz tradition, then shows that Jason's quest for the Golden Fleece derives from the Babylonian myth of Zû—the bird-god who stole the Tablets of Destinies. The section culminates in a systematic analysis of Semitic names in the "bird-family" of Aietes: Aietes the Eagle, Circe the She-Hawk, Chalciope ("hawk-faced"), Medea ("the flying one"), Absyrtos ("the dismembered"), and others. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This section reveals that the Argonaut myth—one of Greece's most celebrated epic cycles—is fundamentally a Near Eastern narrative about healer-gods, bird-deities, and the cosmic struggle for divine kingship (the Tablets of Destinies/Golden Fleece). ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia | Tags: jason, iasion, demeter, aietes, circe, medea, zu, anath, shamash, hellenosemitica]

**Iasion** = Greek *iaomai* "to heal," *iasis* "healing, recovery"

Iasion's union with Demeter in the "thrice-ploughed fallow" (Odyssey V:125-128, Hesiod *Theog.* 969-974) represents the widespread agrarian rite of *hieros gamos*—sexual union in a freshly ploughed field to secure harvest through magic. **Parallels**:
- His fruit **Plutos** ("wealth") = Pluto (king of Hades)—chthonic fertility-gods were considered rich, givers of harvest
- Death by Zeus's thunderbolt = same fate as Phaëthon, Idas, Asclepios—"obviously inherent to the cycle itself"
- Ugaritic verb *šlš* (from numeral "three") = "to plough"—the custom of ploughing thrice was common to Greece and Syria

> "The example of Iasion shows in relief the organic connection of the chthonic fertility-gods with healing, which often was an essential feature of their character." (p. 277)

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia | Tags: jason, iasion, demeter, aietes, circe, medea, zu, anath, shamash, hellenosemitica]

Astour identifies the Book of Ruth as "the Hebrew version of the Eleusis myth" in "fully euhemerized form":

| Eleusis | Bethlehem |
|---------|-----------|
| Demeter, depressed by loss of Cora | Naomi, depressed by loss of sons |
| Old harvest-goddess + young (Cora) | Old (Naomi) + young (Ruth) |
| *Hieros gamos* in thrice-ploughed field | *Hieros gamos* on threshing-floor |
| Triptolemos ("thrice-ploughed") | Boaz = *Ba'al 'Oz* ("strong Baal") |
| Demeter's relationship to foster-child | "There is a son born to Naomi" (Ruth 4:17) |

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia | Tags: jason, iasion, demeter, aietes, circe, medea, zu, anath, shamash, hellenosemitica]

**Jason** (*Iasôn*) = "healer" (almost identical to Iasion)

The Golden Fleece was not mere treasure but **magical medicine**:

> "The fleece—i.e., the hide together with the wool—of the freshly killed victims, played one of the most important rôles in the rite of purification... The fleece is not divine in our sense, not definitely either for blessing or for cursing; it is taboo, it is 'medicine,' it is magical." (p. 281, quoting Jane Harrison)

**Babylonian parallel**: "Fleece of the Great Bull" (*sugugallu*) was deified, identified with Anu himself—"this clarifies why the Golden Fleece plays the rôle of the Babylonian Tablets of Destinies in the Argonaut myth."

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia | Tags: jason, iasion, demeter, aietes, circe, medea, zu, anath, shamash, hellenosemitica]

**Aietes** (*Aiêtês*) = "eagle" (from *aêtos*)

**Aia**: Never had real geographical existence—a "fantastic country at the edge of the world." V. Bérard recognized:
- **Circe** (*Kirkê*) = feminine of *kirkos* "hawk"
- **Aiaie** = W-S *'Ay-'ayyâ* "island of the Hawk" (or *Aia* + Greek feminine ending *-ie*)

**Sun-god connection**: The iconographic idea of personifying the sun by a hawk penetrated from Egypt throughout the Near East. The sun-disc with hawk's wings was adopted by Hurrians, Hittites, Assyrians. West Semites were influenced by consonance of their word for hawk (*'ayyā*) with Babylonian goddess Aia, spouse of sun-god Šamaš. > "The Sun-god was considered the ruler and patron of the inhabitants of Hades... at night, when all gods, identified with stars and planets, are in the sky, the Sun travels his path underground from West to East." (p. 287)

metadata.section: 4. Aietes, Circe, and the Land of Aia (pp. 282–286)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia | Tags: jason, iasion, demeter, aietes, circe, medea, zu, anath, shamash, hellenosemitica]

**Central thesis**: The Argonaut plot is "entirely borrowed from the Babylonian one of the theft of the Tablets of Destinies by the bird-god Zû."

| Babylonian Zû Myth | Greek Argonaut Myth |
|-------------------|---------------------|
| Zû steals Tablets of Destinies | Aietes holds Golden Fleece |
| Tablets = symbol of divine kingship | Fleece = symbol of royal power (cf. Atreus/Thyestes) |
| Zû = "doer of evil, who raises the head of evil" | Aietes = *oloophrōn* "of baneful mind" |
| Zû's wife seduced, Zû intoxicated | Dragon intoxicated by Medea's soporific |
| Tablets retrieved after Zû vanquished | Fleece retrieved after Jason's trials |

**Ugaritic parallel**: Anath boasts of crushing the "writhing serpent" and "powerful one of seven heads" (= Leviathan), then "I fought and I inherited gold"—the dragon-guarding-gold motif. > "Jason, before he became in the epic the personification of the ideal of ancient Greek knights-errant, a kind of chairman of the Hellenic Round Table, had first of all been a healer-hero, a magic expeller of evil." (p. 282)

metadata.section: 5. The Argonauts and the Myth of Zû (pp. 286–293)
metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part C: Jason and the Bird-Heroes of Aia | Tags: jason, iasion, demeter, aietes, circe, medea, zu, anath, shamash, hellenosemitica]

Astour systematically analyzes every name in Aietes' family:

**Aietes**: Either from W-S *'ayit* "bird of prey" (Hebrew), or the name confirms the mythological borrowing from Zû (*ZU* = Akkadian *idû* "to know")—matching wife **Idyia** "the one who knows."

**Chalciope** ("hawk-faced"): From *chalkis*, a word from the "language of gods" (= Semitic)—probably from Akkadian *halâqu* "to perish/destroy" or Hebrew *hălaq* "smooth, hairless" (bald head of vultures). **Cytissoros**: *-issôros* = Ugaritic *'ṣr*, Akkadian *iṣṣuru* "bird"—determinative placed after the name as in cuneiform. **Absyrtos**: *A-bsyr-tos* = prothetic *a-* + *bașur* (passive participle of *bṣr* "to cut, tear to pieces") + Greek suffix *-tos* = "the dismembered one"—matching his fate of being cut to pieces by Medea. **Medea**: From W-S root *d'y* "to fly" (Hebrew *dā'â*, Ugaritic *diy* // *nšrm* "eagles"). Participle feminine Piel: *madīyat* > *Mēdeia* = "the flying one"—confirmed by her flying chariot driven by dragons.

The flying chariot of Medea (also Phaëthon, Idas, Triptolemos) is not Greek invention but W-S:

**II Kings 2:11** (Elijah's ascension): "Behold, a chariot of fire and horses of fire separated the two of them. And Elijah went up by whirlwind into heaven."

> "It is more than probable that the Greeks of the Mycenaean Age, having borrowed the personages of their myths about healer gods and heroes from the East, have also simultaneously borrowed the motif of a flying chariot, too." (p. 298)

This section culminates Astour's analysis of Greek healer-heroes by tracing Cheiron (the centaur who taught medicine to Achilles and Asclepios) to the Sumerian scorpion-god Pabilsag, and by demonstrating that Asclepios—Greece's supreme healer-god—has Mesopotamian and Canaanite origins revealed through his symbols (serpent-staff, dog), his mythology (exposed child, death by thunderbolt, resurrection), and his very name (derived from Ugaritic priestly terminology for ritual prostration). The section concludes with a comprehensive summary of the entire chapter's thesis on healer-heroes. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This section completes the chain connecting Greek healing mythology to Mesopotamian origins via West Semitic intermediaries, demonstrating that even the most revered Greek medical god—Asclepios—derives from Near Eastern prototypes. ---

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios | Tags: cheiron, asclepios, pabilsag, ninazu, resheph, apollo, gula, coronis, hellenosemitica, etymology]

**Comparative astrology**: The Greeks identified Cheiron with Sagittarius, which they borrowed (like most astral notions) from Babylonians. The Babylonians represented Sagittarius as a scorpion-man with a bow, named after the god **Pabilsag**. **Pabilsag** (Sum. *dPa-bil-sag*):
- Husband of healing-goddesses (Ninkarrak/Nin-isinna)
- Located next to Scorpio (constellation of healing goddess Išhara) and Hydra (Ningišzida)
- "Explains why Cheiron-Sagittarius was considered the teacher of the ophic healer-god Asclepios"

**Ugaritic evidence**: Pbl-mlk in the *Krt* epic = Pabilsag. Virolleaud's identification: "Pbl is the Sumerian Pabil-sag 'Pabil (is) the chief.'"

> "Pbl-mlk, king of Udm, figures in the epic of King Krt, and it was his beautiful elder daughter Mšt-Hry whom Krt married." (p. 302)

**Mšt-Hry** = "fiery serpent" (*Mušt-Harayyā*) = constellation Hydra—daughter of Pabilsag/Sagittarius.

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios | Tags: cheiron, asclepios, pabilsag, ninazu, resheph, apollo, gula, coronis, hellenosemitica, etymology]

Greek etymology *cheir* "hand" (surgeon) is contradicted by Attic spelling *Chirôn* (never *chir* for "hand"). Astour proposes Ugaritic personal name **Hyyn** as source:

**Two etymological possibilities**:

1. From *ḥyr* "to choose" (Akkadian *ḫâru*) → *ḫâwiru/ḫâ'iru* "husband"
   - Pabilsag was husband of Ninkarrak; their *hierogamy* was a popular feast at Isin
   - Scorpions symbolized mating; Išḥara was patroness of marriage consummation
   - Cheiron advised Peleus on seizing Thetis; their wedding was celebrated at his cave

2. From Arabic *ḫair* "good, excellent, beneficent, benevolent"
   - "An excellent name for a god of health, fertility, abundance, and help to humans"
   - Attested in Aramaic personal names: *Ḥyr, Ḥyr', Ḥyrw, Ḥyrn*

**Serpent-staff emblem**:
- "This very emblem—a bronze serpent on a staff—was worshipped in the temple of Jerusalem until about 700; its creation was ascribed to the great thaumaturge and healer, the ophic hero Moses" (II Kings 18:4; Num. 21:8)
- Phoenician coins show Ešmun with serpent-staff
- Šed-râphe' at Palmyra depicted with serpent coiled around spear
- "The way by which the old Sumerian emblem penetrated into Greece is clear"

**Dog emblem**:
- Goddess Gula, "the great physician," had the dog as her emblem
- Depicted on Cassite-period *kudurrus* like Asclepios at Epidauros: sitting on throne with dog at feet
- Clay figurines of magic dogs ("he who bites his adversaries") were Babylonian talismans against disease

**Birth mythology parallels**:
- Exposed child nursed by goat = Sumerian Ningirsu
- Nursed by turtle-dove = Semiramis legend from Ascalon
- Found in chest = Sargon I, Moses, Adonis
- Lightning flashing from child = divine origin marker

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter III Part D: Cheiron and Asclepios | Tags: cheiron, asclepios, pabilsag, ninazu, resheph, apollo, gula, coronis, hellenosemitica, etymology]

**Coronis** (Asclepios's mother):
- Common etymology: *korônê* "crow"
- Astour's alternative: *korônis* = "cow with concave and crescent-shaped horns" (Hesychius)
- = W-S *'Aštart Qarnayim* "two-horned Astarte"
- Alternative name **Aigla** = possibly W-S *'eglā* "heifer"
- Matches Ugaritic myth of cow-goddess giving birth to *Rpu-Bʿl* "lord-healer"

**Phlegyas** (Coronis's father):
- *phlegyas* = "eagle" (Hesiod *Scutum Herc.* 134)
- Also from *phlego* "to burn, flame" = Canaanite god **Rešeph** (*rešeph* "flame, lightning, fever")
- Rešeph corresponded to Sumero-Akkadian Nergal (pestilence, underworld, war)
- Son of Ares—who is also similar to Rešeph/Nergal

**Double genealogy of Asclepios**:
- Variant 1: Son of Apollo (Greek identification of Rešeph)
- Variant 2: Great-grandson of Ares (another Rešeph identification)
- In Orchomenos: directly son of Ares, under name **Ascalaphos**

> "The two variants are reduced to one: there is no essential difference, but only onomastic hesitation in translating the original Rešeph into Greek." (p. 312)

**Ascalaphos** (Nether World deity):
- Son of Acheron (river of Hades)—*Acherôn* < W-S *'aḥărôn* "western" (Hades was in Far West)
- Mother: Gorgyrê ("underground") or Orphnê ("darkness")
- Denounced Persephone for eating pomegranate seed
- Transformed into *askalaphos* (short-eared owl)

**Key correspondence**:
- Acheron = Hubur (Sumerian river of Hades)
- Ninlil's son by the underworld river-god = **Ninazu** "Lord Physician"
- "Ascalaphos, the son of Hades-river Acheron, thus fully corresponds to Ninazu"

> "This striking correspondence finally establishes beyond any doubt the identity Asclepios = Ascalaphos = Ninazu." (p. 316)

content:

**Problem**: "The name of Asclepios absolutely does not surrender to even the remotest Greek etymology."

**Solution**: From Akkadian priestly terminology:
- *labānu appi* = "to fall with the face down" (ritual prostration)
- Goes back to Sumerian *KA.SU.GAL*
- Ugaritic verb *ql/qll* "to fall," Š-stem *šql* "to cause to fall"
- 1st person imperfect: ***ašql-ap** = "I prostrate myself" (literally: "I cause my face to fall down")

**Corroboration**: Personal name from Alalah: *A-aš-qa-li-ia*—hypocoristic constructed with 1st person imperfect of *šql*. > "Our restoration presents a full coincidence with Askalaphos, and, consequently, with Asklépios... It harmonizes with the symbol of Asclepios, with the Mesopotamo-Syrian origin of all details of his image, myth, pedigree, symbols." (p. 318)

**Machaon** (Asclepios's son, surgeon in *Iliad*):
- Common etymology: from *machomai* "to fight" (but this means "fight," not "cut")
- Astour's proposal: W-S *mḥwy* "reviver" (Piel participle of *ḥwy* "to live") + suffix *-n*
- = **Maḥawwôn* → Mycenaean *Ma-ka-wo* → *Macha(w)ôn*
- Matches ability ascribed to Asclepios and Oriental healer-gods to revive the dead

content:

This concluding chapter marshals the archaeological, epigraphic, and documentary evidence for West Semitic penetration into the Aegean during the Bronze Age. Astour systematically dismantles Beloch's 1894 argument that archaeology contradicts Phoenician presence in Greece, presenting material proofs: Schaeffer's "Torque-Bearers" who brought bronze metallurgy from Syria to Europe via the Aegean, Mari texts mentioning Kaptara (Crete), Syrian architectural influence on Minoan palaces (Woolley), Cyrus Gordon's decipherment of Linear A as West Semitic and Eteocretan inscriptions as "Phoenician," documentary evidence of massive Ugaritic ship-building capacity, the Cape Gelidonya shipwreck, and the remarkable testimony of circumcision among the Achaeans in Merneptah's inscription. The chapter concludes that Mycenaean civilization was "essentially a peripheral culture of the Ancient East, its westernmost extension."

**Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter provides the physical and documentary proof for the cultural transmission argued in Chapters I–III, establishing that Semitic presence in the Aegean was not merely mythological but archaeologically and epigraphically attested. ---

Astour begins by confronting Julius Beloch's influential 1894 article *Die Phoeniker am aegaeischen Meer*, which "had a baneful influence out of proportion to its modest size."

**Beloch's claims**:
- Phoenicians never visited the Aegean before the VIIIth century
- Their ships were too small for such voyages
- Semitic words could only have entered Greek via land-route through Asia Minor
- "The last word belongs here, as everywhere in prehistoric questions, to the monuments"

**Astour's response**: "Now, in our own time, Beloch's argumentation makes an almost ridiculous impression. What did he know about ancient navigation and the minimum size of a ship able to sustain a voyage from Syria to Crete?"

metadata.title: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy

content:
[Document: Hellenosemitica Chapter IV: Evidence of Archaeology and Epigraphy | Tags: kothar, hellenosemitica, archaeology, epigraphy, torque-bearers, circumcision, cultural-transmission, linear-a, eteocretan, ugarit]

Claude F.-A. Schaeffer discovered at Ras Shamra bronze weapons and ornaments characteristic of Central European Early Bronze, which he traced to a specific population group:

**The "Torque-Bearer" assemblage** (Middle Ugarit I, 2100–1900):
- Triangular daggers with hilts finished in crescents
- Spears with sockets
- Flat axes with blades pierced by "windows"
- Massive bronze neck rings (*torques*)
- Toggle-pins and wire spirals

**Distribution**: Found identically at Ugarit, Byblos, Qaṭna, Megiddo, Sidon, Gezer—and in Central Europe (Hungary, Bohemia) from about 1800–1700. **The sea-route**: "According to the investigations, the Torque-Bearers did not take the land route—the 'torque' is lacking on this route [i.e., in West Anatolia and the Balkans]. This compels us to admit that the Torque-Bearers of Syria, the prospectors and artisans of metal, took the sea." (Schaeffer)

> "The Torque-Bearers were originally no Semites, but they rapidly became Semitized after their establishment in Syria. And, certainly, without the commercial genius of the Proto-Phoenicians, without their experience of the seas, they would not have been able to traverse the Mediterranean." (Schaeffer, quoted p. 328)

**Mari texts** (18th century): Mention **Kap-ta-ra** (Kaphtor/Crete), confirming mutual relations between Crete and Mesopotamia via North Syrian coastal cities. **Akkadian votive inscription from Cythera** (18th century): Corroborates archaeological data of Syro-Aegean contact. **Woolley on Alalah**: After excavating the palace of King Yarim-Lim (Level VII), Woolley traced "unmistakable connections with Crete":
- Construction methods identical to Knossos
- Frescoes "identical in colouring, technique, and style"

> "There can be no doubt but that Crete owes the best of its architecture, and its frescoes, to the Asiatic mainland. And we can say more than this... These professional techniques require direct contacts, and we are bound to believe that trained experts, members of the Architects' and Painters' Guilds, were invited to travel overseas from Asia." (Woolley, quoted p. 333)

Astour summarizes Cyrus H. Gordon's decipherment findings:

**Linguistic milieu of Linear A**: "Exactly the same as in Ugarit, where a mixed West-Semitic (W-S) and Hurrian Semitized population lived in a state of perfect symbiosis."

**Onomastic evidence**: "While names of Syrian origin in the Mycenaean (Linear B) texts form only a minority in a predominantly Greek milieu, the Minoan (Linear A) onomastica known so far is practically all Syrian."

**Implication**: "This betrays the existence of a solid and compact Semitic population in the eastern and central parts of Crete. It was by far more important than mere commercial foreign enclaves in harbor cities."

Gordon's 1962 discovery that Eteocretan ("true Cretan") inscriptions—written in Greek characters but in a non-Greek language—are West Semitic:

**Examples Gordon deciphered**:
- *me y mar krk o kl es y es* = *mē hū' mar krak 'ô kol 'îš we-'îš* "whosoever (whether) son of the city or any man at all"
- *mosel os phraiso* = *môšel 'oz Prays-* "the mighty ruler of Praisos"

**Historical significance**: The Eteocretans did not use the Phoenician alphabet, proving "they were not recent migrants from Phoenicia, but direct descendants of the W-S Minoans from mid-second millennium, who settled in Crete before the invention of the Phoenician alphabet."

> "When Beloch tendentiously tried to ridicule Phoenician presence in any spot of Greece, he ironically asked: if there were Phoenicians in Crete, why are they not listed among the five peoples of the island?... Now C. H. Gordon demonstrated that precisely one of those five peoples, the Eteocretans, were Phoenicians!" (p. 352)

**RS 20.212** (late 12th century): Hittite court requests one Ugaritic ship to transport 2,000 *kor* (≈6,000 hectoliters = 450 metric tons) of grain in one or two trips. > "Nougayrol, in his recently published report, tries to evaluate the capacity of that ship... 'The author of the letter admitted thus that the king of Ugarit disposed, or could dispose, of ships capable of carrying about 500 tons, or perhaps even more.' A vessel of 500 tons—even half as big—certainly could even cross the Atlantic, not only the short sea-distances on the route: Ugarit-Cyprus-Southwest Asia Minor-Crete." (p. 354)

**RS 16.238**: Documents a Ugaritic merchant returning with his ship from **Kapturi** (Crete). **RS 20.238**: Reveals that the Ugaritic fleet was stationed "in the Lycian country" defending against the Sea Peoples—"at the very entrance into the Aegean."

The University of Pennsylvania underwater archaeology expedition found an ancient wreck off Cape Gelidonya in Lycia (c. 1200):

- Ship heavily loaded with Cypriot copper ingots (stamped with Cypro-Minoan signs)
- Scarabs, oil-lamp, and skipper's seal are Syrian
- Wood analysis shows "the ship was probably made with Syrian wood"
- A smith traveled on board as "an ambulant metallurgic workshop"

> "We are in presence of a Syrian vessel which not only carried copper to the Aegean, but also served as an ambulant metallurgic workshop to supply with tools the harbors it visited." (p. 358)

Astour refutes the theory (Dussaud, Webster) that Greeks settled at Ugarit and transmitted Eastern culture back to Greece:

**Documentary evidence against Mycenaean presence**:
- "Among the ethnic names listed in Ugaritic administrative texts, we find Assyrians, Egyptians, Subaraeans, Mittanites, Hittites, Arzawians, Hurrians, Amorites, Canaanites, Nuhaššeans, Alašiots, and natives of several Phoenician and Palestinian cities"
- "No Achaeans, Aeolians, Ionians, Cretans, Caphtorians, Cnossians, Rhodians or any other ethnic or geographical names of the Greco-Aegean world can be found in Ugaritic texts"

**Conclusion**: "These indications are quite precise. They prove that no Mycenaean settlement existed at Ugarit in the XIVth and XIIIth centuries."

Merneptah's inscription (c. 1225) describes carnal trophies from the Sea Peoples:
- From Libyans: phalli cut off (they had *qrn't* "foreskin")
- From Sardana, Šak(a)ruša, Turuša, and **'Aqiyawaša**: hands cut off, "who had no *qrn't*"

**'Aqiyawaša** = Ahhiyawā = Achaeans—they were circumcised. > "Only the settlement in Greece of an important group of population whose religious and ritual principles would be adopted by large masses of the people, could have introduced the general spread of circumcision among the Achaeans... Circumcision among the Achaeans, attested by the eye-witness Merneptah, shows most convincingly how strongly W-S ritual customs became rooted among them." (p. 368)

> "Not only was Phoenician spoken in several parts of Mycenaean Greece, but the entire Mycenaean civilization was essentially a peripheral culture of the Ancient East, its westernmost extension." (p. 370)

**Geopolitical parallel**: "Greece and Syria-Palestine were very similar in their geographical and natural conditions. Both were broken, geographically dismembered territories without a central organizing axis."

**The two swings of the Mediterranean pendulum**:
> "Long before Hellenism imposed itself over the ancient civilizations of the East, Semitism had exercised no less an impact upon the young civilization of Greece. Hellenism became the epilogue of the Oriental civilizations, but Semitism was the prologue of Greek civilization." (p. 374)

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
[Document: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966) | Tags: phlt, chemosh, lucifer, sdq-mshr, esmun, dqt, trt, ishara, el, baal]

This article analyzes newly discovered Ugaritic texts from the 24th excavation campaign at Ras Shamra (1961), focusing on divine names appearing for the first time in Ugaritic literature. Astour identifies key deities including: the Mare-goddess *Phlt* (parallel to Phigalian "Black Demeter"); *Ttt/Kmt* (earliest attestation of Chemosh); *Ngh w Srr* (prototype of Isaiah's Lucifer/Morning Star); *Dqt* (goat-goddess paralleling Cretan Dikte); *Trt* ("wine" deity = possible Bacchus prototype); and *Itm* (guilt-offering personified = earliest form of Phoenician *Ešmûn*). The article demonstrates extensive Greco-Semitic religious parallels and contributes to understanding the "Aegean Oriental religious *koinē*."

**Why this matters for Kothar**: This article provides direct textual evidence from Ugarit for the Semitic origins of Greek divine figures, including the prototype of Lucifer, the etymology of Bacchic *thyrsoi*, and the mare-goddess parallel to Black Demeter—all supporting the broader Hellenosemitic thesis. ---

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
[Document: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966) | Tags: phlt, chemosh, lucifer, sdq-mshr, esmun, dqt, trt, ishara, el, baal]

**Text introduction**: "*um. phl. phlt. bt. 'n. bt. abn. bt šmm w thm... qrit. l špš. umh*" = "the mother of Phl, Phlt, daughter of the Spring, daughter of the Stone, daughter of the Sky and of the Ocean, calls to Špš her mother"

**Phigalian parallel**: Pausanias (VIII:42:1-13) describes an archaic wooden image (xoanon) of "Dēmētēr Melaina" (Black Demeter) or "Dēō Hippolechos" (Deo who bore a horse) in southwestern Arcadia:
- "The Phigalian xoanon had the body of a woman with the head and mane of a horse"
- "There grew out of her head images of serpents and other beasts"
- Located near a spring of cold water (cf. *bt 'n* "daughter of the Spring")
- Sitting on a rock (cf. *bt abn* "daughter of the Stone")
- Having dolphin and dove, symbols of sea and sky (cf. *bt šmm w thm* "daughter of the Sky and Ocean")

> "RS 24.244, unearthed thirty years after V. Bérard's death, offers an exact parallel to all details given by Pausanias. We may safely ascribe the introduction of this iconographic entity into southwestern Arcadia to the Mycenaean Age."

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
[Document: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966) | Tags: phlt, chemosh, lucifer, sdq-mshr, esmun, dqt, trt, ishara, el, baal]

**The binomial**: *Tttw Kmt* (RS 24.244:36) = *'ttw Kmt* (RS 24.271:5)

**Kmt identification**: "The second component of the binomial... is identical with the later chief god of the Moabites, Heb. *Kěmôš*, LXX *Chamôs*, Moabite inscriptional *Kmš*, Assyrian *Ka-a-mu-su*."

**Ttt etymology**: "*Ttt* (Heb. *tīt*, Akk. *tītu*) signifies 'clay' which, together with 'dust' and 'darkness,' was one of the attributes of the Babylonian Nether World."

**Alternate name 'tt**: Virolleaud explained as Heb. *'āyiṭ* "bird of prey" (eagle or vulture)—"an image from the Babylonian 'Land without return,' the residents of which are described as winged and feathered bird-like creatures."

**Tityos connection**: "The doublet *Ttt='tt* leads us to a Greek mythological character, Tityos, son of Earth, who in the Nekyia... is depicted as being punished in the Hades by having his liver eternally torn by two vultures."

**First attestation**: "*ars w šmm*" (RS 24.643:obv. 5)—"This is the first time that Earth and Heaven appear in a Ugaritic text as a divine entity."

**Sequence significance**: "The sequence—Earth standing before Heaven—is the opposite of the Sumerian and Akkadian usage (*an.ki*, *šamû w erṣetu*)... but is the same as in the creation story of J (Gen. 2:4b) which has preserved the Canaanite pattern."

**Philo parallel**: "According to Philo of Byblos, *Ilos* with his brothers and sisters were born of a union of *Uranos* and *Gē*."

[Document: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966) | Tags: phlt, chemosh, lucifer, sdq-mshr, esmun, dqt, trt, ishara, el, baal]

**Etymology**:
- *NGH* "to shine" (Ugaritic, Syriac, Ethiopic; Hebrew *nôgah* = "brightness," Mishnaic = Venus)
- *SRR* "to rebel" (Hebrew, Akkadian D-form *sarāru*)

**Isaiah parallel**: "We have here the earliest occurrence of the rebellious hero of the magnificent mythological poem, Isaiah 14:12-15: *Hēlel ben-Šahar*, 'Morning Star... son of Dawn,' who tried 'to ascend to heaven,' to 'sit on the Mount of Assembly in the far North' and to make himself 'like the Most High (*'Elyôn*),' but was brought down to Sheol."

> "One feels a certain emotion in discovering its prototype in a Ugaritic tablet written some six or eight hundred years before the dirge in Isaiah 14 and some three thousand years before Milton's *Paradise Lost*."

content:
[Document: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966) | Tags: phlt, chemosh, lucifer, sdq-mshr, esmun, dqt, trt, ishara, el, baal]

**Identification**: "Personifications of 'righteousness' and 'justice,' Babylonian *Kettu* and *Mēsaru* (personified as sons of *Šamaš*, the god of justice), Philo's sixth pair of primeval brothers, *Misôr* and *Sydyk*."

**First attestation**: "The nouns *sdq* and *mšr* have been known in Ugaritic literary texts... but this is the first time that they are found as a divine pair."

metadata.title: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966)

content:
[Document: Some New Divine Names from Ugarit (1966) | Tags: phlt, chemosh, lucifer, sdq-mshr, esmun, dqt, trt, ishara, el, baal]

**The divine pair**: *Šgr w Itm* (RS 24.643:rev. 9)

**Itm etymology**: "*Itm* is the same word as the Ugaritic noun *iṭm* = Arab. *'iṭm* = Heb. *'āšām*, i.e., 'guilt,' 'transgression,' and 'guilt offering.'"

**Ešmûn connection** (quoting Astour's 1951/52 work):
> "Disease was considered the result of some fault or guilt (*'āšām*) that had first to be identified and then atoned... Therefore the healer-god, too, received the name *'Āšām*... Amos 8:14 mentions this deity as *'Āšēmāt* of Samaria; II Kings 17:30 knows him, in the Aramaic form *'Ašima'*, as a god of the men of Hamath. The Phoenician healer-god *'Ešmûn* bears the same name with the suffix *-ûn*."

**Confirmation**: "We have here the earliest recorded mention of the god that later, in the first millennium B.C., was worshipped all over the West Semitic world under names derived from the root *'TM*."

**Etymology**: "*Trt*, literally 'grape-juice' (synonym of 'wine'), Heb. *tirōš*, Phoen. (Karatepe) *trš*, Ugar. *trt*."

**Albright's hypothesis confirmed**: "'This hitherto unknown divinity may perhaps have been a kind of Bacchus from whose name the Israelites got their poetic word *tirōš* for "wine."' This hypothesis has now been completely confirmed by the occurrence of the deity *Trt* in two Ugaritic lists of gods."

**Thyrsoi connection**: "The proposed derivation of the term *thyrsoi*, the sacral wands carried at the festivals of Dionysos, from this West Semitic word for 'wine,' has also been strengthened by the disclosure that *trt* had a religious connotation in the West Semitic world."

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
[Document: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975) | Tags: decipherment, bilingual-method, eteocretan, minoan, linear-a, northwest-semitic, adjuration-formula, dreros, praisos, psychro]

This technical article presents Gordon's mature methodology for deciphering Minoan and Eteocretan inscriptions. He outlines six methods of decipherment, works through the Dreros bilinguals, demonstrates the Semitic character of Eteocretan through variant phrases, and connects Minoan Linear A to Eteocretan through shared vocabulary (*ku-ro* "all/total", *u* "and"). The Psychro stone inscription is fully translated as a Northwest Semitic dedication formula. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This is Gordon's most methodologically rigorous article, establishing the six-method framework for Minoan-Eteocretan decipherment and providing detailed bilingual readings that anchor the Northwest Semitic identification. ---

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
[Document: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975) | Tags: decipherment, bilingual-method, eteocretan, minoan, linear-a, northwest-semitic, adjuration-formula, dreros, praisos, psychro]

Gordon explicitly outlines six methods applicable to Minoan and Eteocretan:

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| (i) **Bilingual method** | Greek-Eteocretan bilinguals provide known-to-unknown equations |
| (ii) **Phrase translation** | Whole Eteocretan phrases tested for meaning and internal consistency |
| (iii) **Inner variants** | Synonyms and alternative idioms within Eteocretan texts confirm readings |
| (iv) **Parallel unilinguals** | Greek and Eteocretan unilinguals from same sites provide equivalences |
| (v) **Contextual method** | All readings must fit context |
| (vi) **Collateral evidence** | Interpretation within known East Mediterranean epigraphical usage |
| (vii) **Pictograms/determinatives** | For Minoan, meaning fixed through accompanying pictographs |

**Key quote**: "The material dictates the methods. There is no one prefabricated methodology for deciphering all scripts and languages."

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
