**First Dreros Bilingual:**
- Eteocretan opens with *]φμαF* = Greek *EΦ AΔE* "they decreed"
- Eteocretan ends with *λμο* = Greek *[τα]ματρίτα[τα]ο* "for his mother"
- Analysis: *λμο* = Hebrew *l-immō* "for his mother"

**Second Dreros Bilingual:**
- Demonstrates additional Greco-Eteocretan correspondences
- Confirms Northwest Semitic character

**Key quote**: "The Greek version tells us to equate λμο with Hebrew לִאמוֹ *l'immô* 'for his mother'."

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
[Document: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975) | Tags: decipherment, bilingual-method, eteocretan, minoan, linear-a, northwest-semitic, adjuration-formula, dreros, praisos, psychro]

Gordon demonstrates that Eteocretan contains standardized adjuration formulas found throughout East Mediterranean epigraphy. **Eteocretan phrase**: *ετ·μενυμαρκρκοκλες·νες...*
- = Hebrew *...מי הוא מר כרכו כל איש ואיש* "whosoever he be, citizen of his fortress (or) any (other) man and man of..."

**Variant phrasing**: *vas φονκλες* "the people of his city and every (other) man"

**Parallel construction in known languages:**
- **Phoenician (Tabnit)**: *m y't k l'd m's...* "whosoever thou art, any man who..."
- **Phoenician (Eshmunazar)**: *qnmy't kl mmikt wkl'd m* "my oath is with every ruler and every (other) man"
- **Phoenician (Azitawadd)**: *w'm mlk bmlkm wrzn brznm'm'd m's' 'd m šm* "and if any king among kings..."

**Key insight**: The two Eteocretan variants provide synonymous pairs—*mar krk* "lord of fortress" and *vas ir* "people of city"—that only make sense in Northwest Semitic.

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
[Document: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975) | Tags: decipherment, bilingual-method, eteocretan, minoan, linear-a, northwest-semitic, adjuration-formula, dreros, praisos, psychro]

Two key words bridge Minoan (Bronze Age) and Eteocretan (Early Iron Age):

**1. *ku-ro* / *kull-* "all, total"**
- Introduces numerical totals in Hagia Triada tablets
- = Semitic *kull-* "all"
- Biblical parallel: 2 Sam. 23:39 sums up David's heroes with *kol* "total: 37"

**2. *u* "and"**
- Connects parallel utterances in Minoan dedications
- Example: *ya-ta-no-x u ya-[...]* "he donated it and set [it up as votive offering]"
- = Phoenician *ytn wytn'* "he donated and set up as votive offering"

**Key quote**: "We have shown that two common words (of types not likely to be borrowings) are shared by Minoan and Eteocretan: *kull-* 'all', *u* 'and'."

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
[Document: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975) | Tags: decipherment, bilingual-method, eteocretan, minoan, linear-a, northwest-semitic, adjuration-formula, dreros, praisos, psychro]

The complete translation of the Psychro stone inscription from the Dictaean Cave:

**Text**: *επιθίζηθανθη* + syllabic *i-pi-ti*

**Translation**: "I, E. the son of S., have donated this engraved stone."

**Analysis:**
- *epithi* = *e-pth* "the engraved stone" (with definite article *e-*)
- = Phoenician *pth* "engraved stone" (cf. YHWMLK inscription: *pthy z* "this engraved stone of mine")
- *ζηθανθη* = *ytnt-* "I have donated" (cf. Punic *ytnty*)
- The first word repeated in Minoan syllabary (*i-pi-ti*) proves scribe knew both scripts

**Addendum**: Robert Stieglitz solved the third line *ενετηπαρσιφαι* as "E. the son of S." where *par* = "son" (standard Aramaic, also Phoenician KLMW inscription and Hebrew Prov. 31:2).

metadata.title: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975)

content:
[Document: The Decipherment of Minoan and Eteocretan (1975) | Tags: decipherment, bilingual-method, eteocretan, minoan, linear-a, northwest-semitic, adjuration-formula, dreros, praisos, psychro]

**Wine (*ya-ne*):**
- Inscribed on Knossos pithos fragment
- = NW Semitic *yayn-* "wine"
- Michael Astour noted: Ugaritic place "Yan(a)" written *ya-na* or GESTIN-*na* (where GESTIN = wine)
- This gives an isogloss connecting Minoan and Ugaritic

**Wheat (*ku-ni-su*):**
- Four occurrences in Hagia Triada tablets, twice with wheat determinative
- = Akkadian *kunnishu* "emmer wheat"
- Position in tablets fixes meaning as commodity (not personal name)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, bilingual-method, eteocretan, eteocypriote, decipherment, northwest-semitic, retrograde-writing, amathus, dreros, praisos]

This opening section establishes the bilingual method as the foundation for Gordon's decipherment. Using Greek-Eteocypriote and Greek-Eteocretan bilinguals, Gordon demonstrates that the pre-Greek languages of Cyprus and Crete are Northwest Semitic dialects closely related to Phoenician. The bilinguals from Amathus and Dreros provide the "Rosetta Stones" that unlock the linguistic identity of the Minoan world. **Why this matters for Kothar**: These bilinguals establish the empirical foundation for the Minoan-Semitic thesis. The Dreros equations (*lmo* = "for his mother," *ihia* = "it will be") prove continuity from Bronze Age Minoan through Hellenistic Eteocretan. ---

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, bilingual-method, eteocretan, eteocypriote, decipherment, northwest-semitic, retrograde-writing, amathus, dreros, praisos]

Gordon frames Minoan civilization within the East Mediterranean koiné of the second millennium BC:

> "A comparative study of Ugaritic, Greek and Hebrew literatures points to a single culture that permeated the East Mediterranean throughout the second millennium B.C." (§1)

The fall of Knossos (ca. 1400–1200 BC) dispersed the Minoans, explaining:
- The sudden appearance of Ugaritic literature after 1400 BC
- References to Caphtor (Crete) as home of **Kothar-wa-Khasis**
- The spread of hide-shaped ingots from Crete to Anatolia and Sardinia

> "That god (Kothar-wa-Khasis) has a pure Semitic name, indicating that Caphtor had been the artistic center of the linguistic, cultural and religious sphere to which Ugarit belonged." (§1)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, bilingual-method, eteocretan, eteocypriote, decipherment, northwest-semitic, retrograde-writing, amathus, dreros, praisos]

The Greco-Eteocypriote bilingual from Amathus (Cyprus), inscribed on black marble, provides the first key equations. **The Greek epitome**:
> Ἡ ΠΟΛΙΣ Ἡ ΑΜΑΘΟΥΣΙΟΝ ΑΡΙΣΤΩΝΑ ΑΡΙΣΤΩΝΑΚΤΟΣ ΕΥΠΑΤΡΙΔΗΝ
> "The city of the Amathusians (has honored) the noble Ariston (son) of Aristonax."

**Key Eteocypriote readings** (§7–17):

| Eteocypriote | Semitic | Meaning |
|--------------|---------|---------|
| *a-na ma-to-ri* | הַנָּה מְתוֹרֵי | "the city" (= ἡ πόλις) |
| *a-na* | הַנָּא (Syriac *hānā*) | "the, this" |
| *sa-na* | זֶנָה | "this" (m. sg. demonstrative) |
| *-o-se* | אז | "this" (enclitic) |
| *la* | ל | "for" |
| *a-lo* | עָלָיו | "over him" |
| *ka* | כ | "like, as" |

**Double demonstrative construction**: *sa-na a-ri-si-to-no-se* "this Ariston" parallels Aramaic idiom (§17).

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, bilingual-method, eteocretan, eteocypriote, decipherment, northwest-semitic, retrograde-writing, amathus, dreros, praisos]

**Eteocretan** (retrograde, with word dividers):
```
]ΙΡΜΑΦ . ΕΤ . ΙΣΑΑΒΡ ΕΤ ΚΟΜΝ
]Σ . ΜΕΝ . ΙΝΑΙ . ΙΣΑΑΤΡΙΑ . ΑΜΟ
```

**Greek** (boustrophedon):
```
]Σ ΤΟΝ ΤΥΡΟΝ Μ[ΥΝ]Α ΤΟ ΑΟΙ ΕΦΑΣ[Ε
ΤΑΙ] ΜΑΤΡΙ ΤΑΙ Α[ΥΤΟ]
```

**Critical equation** (§22):
> "The final word in the Eteocretan is ΑΜΟ corresponding to ]ΜΑΤΡΙ ΤΑΙ Α[. Since ΜΑΤΡΙ can only be the dative for 'mother,' the Eteocretan ΑΜΟ is the equivalent of Hebrew לְאִמּוֹ *l'immō* 'for his mother.'"

**Other equations from First Dreros** (§23–27):

| Eteocretan | Greek | Semitic | Meaning |
|------------|-------|---------|---------|
| ΕΤ ΚΟΜΝ | τὸν τυρόν | אֶת גֹּבֶן | "the cheese" (accusative) |
| ΕΤ | — | אֶת | sign of definite accusative |
| ΑΜΟ | μητρὶ | לְאִמּוֹ | "for his mother" |
| ΙΣΑΑ- | μύνα | אִשָּׁה | "woman" |
| ΑΒΡ | — | חָבֵר | "companion" |
| ΤΡΙΑ | — | רֵעַ | "friend" |

> "The First Dreros Bilingual provides Greek evidence that establishes the close Eteocretan correspondents of Hebrew/Phoenician ל 'to,' ו 'his,' אם 'mother' and the accusative indicator את. Even if we set aside the other Eteocretan readings, these four would fix the Dreros dialect as Northwest Semitic." (§27)

**Eteocretan**: `]Σ . ΤΥΣΡ ΜΗΡ ΙΗΙΑ`

**Greek**: `ΟΜΟΝΤΑΙ ΔΑΙΠΕΡ ΕΝ ΟΡΚΙΟΙΣΙ . Α[ ] ΚΑΘΑΡΟΝ ΓΕΝΟΙΤΟ`

**Critical equation** (§30–31):
> "What is clear is that Eteocretan ΙΗΙΑ corresponds to Greek γένοιτο 'let there be.' The Semitic ΙΗΙΑ (in Hebrew יִהְיֶה *yihyeh*) by itself means 'he will be.'"

This establishes the Hebrew verb היה "to be" in the Dreros dialect—a crucial morphological confirmation.

Four funerary inscriptions from Praisos, spanning ca. 600–300 BC. **Recurring element**: ΜΙΤ = Hebrew מֵת *mēt* "died" appears in all three texts where the first line survives. **Key readings from Praisos**:

| Eteocretan | Hebrew | Meaning |
|------------|--------|---------|
| ΜΙΤ | מֵת | "died" |
| Υ | ו | "and" (as in Punic) |
| ΣΦΑΑ | שֶׁבַע | "7" |
| ΣΑΡ | עֶשֶׂר | "10" |
| ΤΖΑΑ | תֵּשַׁע | "9" |
| ΣΑΝΟ | זֶנָה | "this" (m. sg.) |
| ΟΣ | אז | "this" (enclitic) |
| ΜΟΣΕΛ | מוֹשֵׁל | "ruler" |
| ΚΑΡΚ | כַּרְךְ | "town" |
| ΝΑΣ | נָשׁ | "people" |
| ΙΡ | עִיר | "city" |

**Double demonstrative** (§37): ΣΑΝΟ ΜΟΣΕΛ ΟΣ = זה מושל זה "this ruler"—same construction as Eteocypriote. **Formulaic phrase** (§33, 41): ΜΕ Υ ΜΑΡ ΚΡΚΟ ΚΑ ΕΣ Υ ΕΣ = מי הוא מר כרכו כל איש ואיש "whoever he be, lord of his town, every man and man"

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, bilingual-method, eteocretan, eteocypriote, decipherment, northwest-semitic, retrograde-writing, amathus, dreros, praisos]

A unique **digraphic** text from the Dictaean Cave (ca. 300 BC) where the scribe rewrites ΕΤΙΘΙ in Minoan syllabary as *i-pi-ti*:

```
ΕΤΙΘΙ
Ζ ΗΘΑΝΘΗ
ΕΝΕΤΗ ΠΑΡΣΙΦΑΙ
i-pi-ti
```

**Key readings**:

| Eteocretan | Phoenician | Meaning |
|------------|------------|---------|
| ΕΤΙΘΙ / *i-pi-ti* | הַפֵּתַח | "the engraved monument" |
| Ε | ה | "the" (definite article) |
| Ζ | ז | "this" or "which" (relative) |
| ΗΘΑΝΘΗ | יְתַנְתִי | "I have given/set" |

> "Four key words are clear: Ε = ה 'the,' ΙΤΙΘΙ = Minoan *pi-te* = פתח 'engraved monument,' Ζ = Minoan *za* = ז 'this' or 'which,' and *ytn* 'to give, set' as in Minoan and Phoenician." (§49)

This text proves **continuity from Minoan to Eteocretan**—the same terminology for votive monuments persisted for over a millennium.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 1: Bilinguals & Eteocretan | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, bilingual-method, eteocretan, eteocypriote, decipherment, northwest-semitic, retrograde-writing, amathus, dreros, praisos]

Gordon argues the Greek alphabet with vowels was developed on Crete:

> "When the Cretans adopted the consonantal Phoenician alphabet, they added to it the means of expressing the five vowels to which they had so long been accustomed from their long use of the native syllabary." (§51)

**Key evidence**: Omicron corresponds to Phoenician ע (*'ayin*), which was pronounced *o* in Minoan words like *bol* (< *ba'l*) "Baal" and *nol* (< *na'l*) "sandal" (§53).

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment | Tags: addu, baal, yamm, tinit, gupanu, ugaru, dagon, kret, linear-a, decipherment]

This central section presents Gordon's methodology for deciphering Linear A through virtual bilinguals, contextual analysis, and comparison with the Eteocretan evidence. Building on Ventris's Linear B values (since most Linear A signs recur in Linear B), Gordon establishes that Minoan is Northwest Semitic through systematic vocabulary analysis. The section culminates in comprehensive word lists proving the Semitic character of Minoan. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This is the technical core—the actual decipherment work. The vocabulary tables (§113, §126) provide the linguistic evidence that Minoan Crete spoke a language ancestral to Phoenician. ---

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment | Tags: addu, baal, yamm, tinit, gupanu, ugaru, dagon, kret, linear-a, decipherment]

Gordon accepts Ventris's 1952 Linear B decipherment as the basis for pronouncing Linear A:

> "The decipherment of Mycenaean Linear B by Michael Ventris in 1952 was confirmed by a 'virtual bilingual' from Pylos in which various pots are drawn pictographically as well as defined syllabically in Mycenaean Greek... Since most of the Linear A signs recur in Linear B with the same phonetic values, Ventris's decipherment enables us to pronounce many names and words in the Minoan Linear A texts." (§114)

**Proof of sign continuity**: The same proper names appear in both scripts (e.g., *pa-i-to* "Phaistos"), implying identical phonetic values.

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment | Tags: addu, baal, yamm, tinit, gupanu, ugaru, dagon, kret, linear-a, decipherment]

Like the Pylos tablet that confirmed Linear B, Hagia Triada tablet HT 31 shows pictographs of pots with their Minoan names spelled syllabically. **Four of five legible pot names are Semitic** (§115):

| Minoan | Semitic | Meaning |
|--------|---------|---------|
| *qa-pa* | Hebrew כַּף *kap* | "pan, vessel" |
| *su-pu* | Hebrew/Ugaritic סַף *sap* | "jar" |
| *ka-ro-pa* | Akkadian *karpu* (cf. Ug. *krpn*) | "vase" |
| *su-pa-ra* | Hebrew/Ugaritic סֶפֶל *sefel* | "pot" |

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment | Tags: addu, baal, yamm, tinit, gupanu, ugaru, dagon, kret, linear-a, decipherment]

> "The WHEAT determinative following *ku-ni-su* tells us that the word means 'wheat.' In Akkadian *ku(n)nisu* means 'emmer wheat.' Its Aramaic cognate כֻּנָּתָא (a masculine noun from the Semitic root *\*knt*) is defined as 'spelt' wheat."

The parallel: Linear B *si-to* + WHEAT = σῖτος "wheat"

**Result**: Minoan *ku-ni-su* = Mycenaean *si-to* — a Greco-Semitic equation via the WHEAT determinative.

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment | Tags: addu, baal, yamm, tinit, gupanu, ugaru, dagon, kret, linear-a, decipherment]

Totals on Minoan tablets are labeled *ku-ro* = Semitic *kull-* (Hebrew כֹּל *kōl*) "all."

**Example** — HT 88 (§117):
```
ki-ro ku-pa-nu    1
ka-x              1
ku-pa-nu          1
pa-ya-re          1
sa-ma-ro          1
da-ta-re          1
—————————————————
ku-ro             6
```

**"Grandtotal"**: HT 122 uses *po-to-ku-ro* = בַּת כֹּל "daughter of all" = "grandtotal" (§118)

metadata.title: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment | Tags: addu, baal, yamm, tinit, gupanu, ugaru, dagon, kret, linear-a, decipherment]

**The *ya-ta-no* formula** (§121):

Several stone cult objects begin with *ya-ta-no-* (var. *a-ta-no-*) = Phoenician יָתַן *yātan-* "he has given/donated."

A libation bowl (I,14) contains:
> *ya-ta-no-x u ya-[* ] = Phoenician יתן ויתנא *ytn wytn'* "he has given and set up as a votive offering"

Note: The conjunction "and" appears as *u* (as in Punic, Akkadian). **The *ta-nu-a-ti* formula** (§122):

A libation table from Knossos (I,8) contains:
> *ta-nu-a-ti ya-sa-sa-ra-ma-na* = "I have set up this votive offering"

The verb תנא *tn'* "to set up (as a votive offering)" is common in Phoenician dedications. **Wine on wine jars** (§123):

Pithoi from Knossos bear the word *ya-ne* flanked by word dividers = Hebrew יַיִן *yayin* "wine"—found on vessels with the WINE determinative.

content:
[Document: Evidence for the Minoan Language (1966) — Part 2: Linear A Decipherment | Tags: addu, baal, yamm, tinit, gupanu, ugaru, dagon, kret, linear-a, decipherment]

Gordon's key continuity proof:

> "An inscribed libation table from Palaikastro (I,4:b) refers to itself as *pi-te za* (with a word divider on each side) = Phoenician זה פתח 'this engraved monument.'"

**The chain**:
- Bronze Age Minoan: *pi-te* + *za*
- Hellenistic Eteocretan: ΕΙΤΙΘΙ + Ζ (Psychro text)
- Both = Phoenician פתח + ז

> "The Psychro text thus shows the continuity of the language and tradition since Minoan times." (§49, referenced in §124)

**The ʿayin > o shift** (§150):
> "The ʿ (cayin) at least in certain combinations, shifts to *o*. Thus *ʿa > o* in: *baʿl- > bōl-* (written *pu-ra*) 'Baal' and *naʿl- > nōl-* 'sandal.'"

This concluding section applies Gordon's acrophonic method to the Phaistos Disc, proposes a historical origin for the Minoans (Northwest Semites from the Egyptian Delta), and synthesizes the dialect evidence. Though Gordon acknowledges the Disc interpretation is "especially subject to correction" (Foreword), his acrophonic readings and the Delta hypothesis provide the capstone to his Minoan-Semitic thesis. **Why this matters for Kothar**: The Phaistos Disc analysis demonstrates how acrophony works—the principle underlying the entire Linear A decipherment. The Delta hypothesis explains *why* a Semitic-speaking civilization arose on Crete ca. 1800 BC. ---

> "A frequent word occurring five times in the Disc is written HORN + *ku*. The Semitic word for 'horn' is *karn-*. However, we know from the early Eteocretan text from Praisos (§33) that the word for 'town' was pronounced *krk* (as distinct from *kark*, which appears later). Accordingly, *krn-* (rather than *karn-*) would be the Minoan pronunciation of the word for 'horn.' HORN + *ku* should therefore be read *kr-ku* 'town.'"

This matches the high frequency of "town" in both the Disc and the Praisos texts.

> "Now the latter [*spīt*] is used in a magico-religious context 'to eat a ceremonial meal in the house of Baal.'"

**Full phrase**: *su-pe-ʾi-ti* followed by CORNER-MAN-*te-ha-da* = *pi-pu-te-ha-da*

**Interpretation**: The combination *pu-te* (occurring 5 times) = Ugaritic *bwt* "house, temple"

The final syllables *ha-da* = oblique case of הדד *Hadda* = Ugaritic *hd* = another name of Baal. > "We have here a parallel to the religious rite of eating a ceremonial meal in the Shrine of Baal (cf. Ugaritic *spī ksmh bt bʿl* in text 2 Aqht:I:32)... If this is correct, the shrine connected with the Phaistos Palace is the Temple of Baal/Hadd." (§174)

- **Absence of hearth** (essential in Greece, Anatolia)

> "When we ask ourselves what historic factor impelled the palace builders to occupy Crete in MM I, we must consider the establishment of the Middle Kingdom under Upper Egyptian leadership against the non-Egyptians who had become too strong in the Delta."

**Gordon's argument**:

1. The entire East Mediterranean was permeated with Northwest Semites
2. The Delta was never "pure Egyptian" like Upper Egypt—it was "Levantine" with large Semitic population
3. Egypt was called "The Two Lands" for good reason
4. At the end of the First Intermediate Period (= MM I), Upper Egypt expelled non-Egyptians from the Delta
5. The palace-building Minoans arrived on Crete precisely then (MM I)

> "We can now answer, in broad outline, who the palace-building Minoans were, that imposed their already highly developed Bronze Age civilization on Neolithic Crete. They were Northwest Semites mainly from the Delta. However, they were essentially the same people as the other Northwest Semites in Libya, Palestine, Phoenicia, Syria, etc., so that it would be a mistake to insist that all of the early Minoans came exclusively from the Delta." (§178)

metadata.title: Minoica (1962)

content:
[Document: Minoica (1962) | Tags: asherah, nergal, dagon, gupanu, minos, linear-a, west-semitic, phoenician, dedicatory-formula, ki-particle]

This foundational article moves beyond the Hagia Triada tablets to analyze dedicatory formulas from cultic objects across eastern and central Crete. Gordon establishes that Linear A represents "West Semitic, of the Phoenician type" through analysis of vocabulary (*ki-re-ya-tu* "city," *ya-ne* "wine," *bi-ti za* "this house"), morphology (prefixed *t-* verbs, the particle *ki* "so that"), and syntax. He also identifies the conjunction *u* "and" as West Semitic rather than East Semitic, revising his earlier position on the Hagia Triada dialect. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This is Gordon's key methodological article establishing Linear A as specifically Phoenician-type West Semitic, providing the linguistic foundation for the Minoan-Semitic thesis that connects Crete to the Canaanite world from which Kothar-wa-Hasis originates. ---

**Thesis**: The dedicatory formula proves Semitic morphology and syntax, not just vocabulary. **Reading:**
- *le ya-sa-[sa-ra-mu]* = "to the deity Y." (with preposition לְ)
- *ki-te-te-bi ki-re-ya-tu* = "so that the city may be well"
- *ki-re-ya-tu* = קִרְיָה (*qiryat-*) "city" (Hebrew/Ugaritic)
- *ki-* = כִּי "so that, because" particle

**Analysis**: Gordon identifies three West Semitic features in one inscription:
1. Preposition *le-* = לְ "to, for"
2. Particle *ki* = כִּי "so that"
3. Noun *qiryat-* = קִרְיָה "city"

**Key quote**: "The fact remains that any single one of these West Semitic features (לְ, 'to,' כִּי 'so that,' קִרְיָה, 'city') would suffice to indicate the West Semitic character of the Minoan texts."

**Evidence:**
- Two-syllable word with word-dividers on either side
- Following Linear B orthographic rules, *yai-* would be written *ya-*
- Therefore *ya-ne* = *yain-* = יַיִן "wine"
- Context: label referring to pithos contents

content:
[Document: Minoica (1962) | Tags: asherah, nergal, dagon, gupanu, minos, linear-a, west-semitic, phoenician, dedicatory-formula, ki-particle]

**Thesis**: The phrase *bi-ti za* means "this house" (i.e., the shrine). **Reading**: *bi-ti za* = Phoenician בַּיִת זֶה "this house"

**Orthographic problem and solution**: If *ya-ne* "wine" uses *ya-* for diphthong *ai*, why does *bi-ti* "house" use *bi-*? Gordon's answer: Hebrew shows the same variation:
- בַּיִת < **bait* (with diphthong preserved)
- חַיִּים *haiq-* (with different treatment)

Alternative: *bi-ti za* may represent "בּיתי זה" = "this house of mine" with regressive vocalic assimilation (*baitī* > *bittī* = *bītī*), as known from Ugaritic.

**Thesis**: "Eteocretan" is simply a late survival of Phoenician on Crete. **Evidence**: The Psychro stone (ca. 300 BC) opens with EΠIΘI ZH (also rendered *i-bi-ti* in Minoan characters), possibly equivalent to Phoenician (הַ)בַּיִת "the house" with definite article. **Key quote**: "The collocation of EΠIΘI ZH in the Psychro 'Eteocretan' text with Minoan Linear A *bi-ti za* hints at the possibility of the 'Eteocretan' language being simply a late survival of Phoenician on Crete."

content:
[Document: Minoica (1962) | Tags: asherah, nergal, dagon, gupanu, minos, linear-a, west-semitic, phoenician, dedicatory-formula, ki-particle]

**Thesis**: Minoan uses *u* "and" rather than expected *wa*, requiring revision of the East Semitic hypothesis. **Evidence:**
- Text I, 4:c: *a-[sa]-sa-ra-mu u-na-ru-ka-na* = "(Y)asasaramu and Nergal"
- HT 28:a:1-2: *a-ne-ya-ka u-mi-na-ne* = "A. and Minan"

**Significance**: Gordon had previously argued for East Semitic identity based on *u* (instead of *wa*). This article acknowledges *u* occurs in West Semitic Minoan, necessitating re-examination. **Key quote**: "Since the use of *u* (instead of *wa*) was my main reason for maintaining an East Semitic identity of the Hagia Triada dialect, the whole Hagia Triada problem requires re-examination."

---

> ### Editorial Note: The *Yasharum* Hypothesis
>
> Gordon's identification of *ya-sa-sa-ra-mu* as a deity requires careful examination. He writes: "*Ya-sa-sa-ra-mu* is taken by all Minoanists to be a deity; whether that deity is female (in accordance with the consensus of opinion) is another matter that need not be investigated at this time" (p. 207). Notably, Gordon does *not* identify this form as Asherah (*ʾAṯirat*); he refers to it only as "the deity Y." The Asherah identification (*ʾaṯirat* → *asasaramu*) is a later scholarly inference based on phonetic similarity, not Gordon's explicit claim. >
> An alternative reading merits consideration. The form *ya-sa-sa-ra-mu* may represent the Semitic root **י-ש-ר** (*y-š-r*) "to be straight, upright, righteous" with archaic mimation — the nominative case ending *-um* preserved in Akkadian and early West Semitic. Gordon himself argues that Minoan retains case endings (cf. *ki-re-ya-tu* with nominative *-u*, p. 208). Under this analysis, ***Yasharum*** would mean "The Upright One" — a divine epithet rather than a proper theonym. >
> **Supporting evidence:**
> - The root *y-š-r* is productive in West Semitic divine/royal epithets: Heb. *Jeshurun* (יְשֻׁרוּן) as a name for Israel, the *Book of Jashar* (סֵפֶר הַיָּשָׁר), *mesharim* (מֵישָׁרִים) "equity/uprightness"
> - Mimation (*-um*) on Minoan forms would parallel Gordon's analysis of other case-marked nouns in the corpus
> - An epithet explains why "all Minoanists" recognized the form as divine without identifying a specific deity — titles like *Elyon* ("Most High") or *Shaddai* ("Almighty") function similarly
>
> **Phonetic difficulty:** The doubled *-sa-sa-* does not straightforwardly derive from *yashar*. Possible explanations include: (1) gemination in an intensive form (*yaššar* "he who makes straight"); (2) Linear A scribal convention for representing Semitic שׁ (/ʃ/); (3) a dialectal or morphological variant not yet understood. A comparative note: Middle English scribes used "ss" to represent the /ʃ/ sound in certain texts (e.g., *Ayenbite of Inwyt*, c. 1340; see Scragg, *A History of English Spelling*), demonstrating that "ss" for /ʃ/ is not unprecedented in syllabic or alphabetic writing systems facing phonemic gaps. >
> **Theological implication:** Text I,4:c pairs this deity with Nergal, the Mesopotamian god of the underworld and divine judgment.

If *Yasharum* rather than *Athirat*, the pairing yields "*Yasharum u-Nergal*" — "The Upright One and Nergal" — potentially representing cosmic justice: righteousness in life, judgment in death. This would evidence Minoan religious syncretism bridging West Semitic ethical concepts with Mesopotamian eschatology. >
> The hypothesis remains speculative pending further analysis of Linear A phonology and morphology. It is offered here as an alternative to the consensus *Athirat* reading, which itself lacks definitive confirmation. >

— *Context*: The concluding methodological statement, marking the transition from general "Semitic" to specifically "Phoenician-type West Semitic."

> "Indo-Europeanists, including a dedicated group of Classicists, have been advancing our knowledge of the Mycenaean Greek Linear B tablets. Semitists have no right to expect the Indo-Europeanists to shoulder the responsibility of interpreting the Linear A documents as well. I hope this article will lead some Semitists—particularly young Hebraists—into a new and challenging field that will yield rich results in West Semitic linguistics."

— *Context*: Gordon's call for Semitists to engage with Minoan studies, challenging disciplinary boundaries. > "That the Semitic names of Hagia Triada are primarily West Semitic has been abundantly clear for some time; e.g., *da-we-da*, 'David,' *da-gu-na*, 'Dagon,' *gu-pa₃-nu* = Ugaritic 'Gupanu,' and its feminine counterpart *gu-pa₃-na-tu*, etc."

— *Context*: Evidence for West Semitic deity and personal names at Hagia Triada. ---

The Minoan syllabary does not distinguish:
- Unvoiced, voiced, and emphatic stops (*k, g, q* all written with same sign)
- Exception: voiced *d* is kept separate from *t / ṭ*

This affects readings: *ma-ka-we-te* = Ugaritic *mqwt* shows *k(a)=q* and *t(e)=ṭ*. ---

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
[Document: Ugarit and Caphtor | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, dagon, caphtor, helen-of-troy-motif, kret-legend, moses-minos, daedalus-bezalel, srn-tyrant, ugarit, crete]

This article argues that Caphtor (Minoan Crete) was "the principal source of inspiration for early Greek and Hebrew culture." Gordon demonstrates connections through: (1) the Ugaritic craftsman god Kothar-wa-Hasis whose workshop was on Caphtor, (2) the Kret legend linking Cretan and Semitic epic traditions, (3) the Moses-Minos and Daedalus-Bezalel parallels, and (4) linguistic evidence from the term *srn* "tyrant" found at both Ugarit and in the Bible for Philistine rulers. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This article provides the most direct connection between Kothar-wa-Hasis (the Ugaritic craftsman god after whom Kothar is named) and Crete, establishing Caphtor as his workshop and as the cultural bridge between Greek and Hebrew civilization. ---

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
[Document: Ugarit and Caphtor | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, dagon, caphtor, helen-of-troy-motif, kret-legend, moses-minos, daedalus-bezalel, srn-tyrant, ugarit, crete]

**Thesis**: "Throughout the second millennium B.C., but especially during its latter half, the islands and coastal mainland of the East Mediterranean shared a large cultural common denominator. The focal point of the unifying forces was Crete together with culturally related Aegean areas."

**Evidence for Caphtor = Crete:**
- Egyptian *kftîw* "Caphtor" attested since 18th Dynasty; as divine name *hr-kftî* ("Horus of Caphtor") back to Middle Kingdom
- Hebrew "Caphtor" = homeland of Philistines (Amos 9:7)
- "Philistines" interchangeable with "Cretans" (Ezekiel 25:16) and "Caphtorians" (Deuteronomy 2:23)
- Consonantal skeleton *kft* = *KPT* with variants *kp tr* (Hebrew-style) and *hkpt* (prefixed form)

**Phonetic note**: Ugaritic variant *hqkpt* shows double writing of palatal stop (*-qk-*) because "Caphtorian *k* was not quite the same as Semitic *k*, but between Semitic *k* and *q*."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
[Document: Ugarit and Caphtor | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, dagon, caphtor, helen-of-troy-motif, kret-legend, moses-minos, daedalus-bezalel, srn-tyrant, ugarit, crete]

**Thesis**: The Ugaritic god of arts and crafts (*Ktr w Hss*), resembling Hephaestus, had his workshop located in Caphtor. **Key textual evidence:**
- Workshop appears in two poetic forms: *kp tr* and *hkpt* (to suit parallelistic poetry requirements)
- Text 51:I:35: Kothar fashions *hdm id* "a footstool of Ida" — the Idaean footstool

**The word *hdm* "footstool":**
- Hebrew: *hădōm*
- Egyptian: *hdmw* (not attested before 18th Dynasty)
- NOT Semitic (absent from Akkadian, Arabic, Ethiopic)
- Conclusion: Loan from Caphtorian into Hebrew and Egyptian

**Mount Ida:** "In all probability *id* refers to Mount Ida in Crete, though we should note that 'Ida' is also found in Asia Minor; cf. the Mount Ida overlooking Troy."

metadata.title: Ugarit and Caphtor

content:
[Document: Ugarit and Caphtor | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, dagon, caphtor, helen-of-troy-motif, kret-legend, moses-minos, daedalus-bezalel, srn-tyrant, ugarit, crete]

**Thesis**: The Caphtorian word *srn* appears at both Ugarit and in the Bible, proving the Caphtorian settlers in both localities spoke the same language. **Semantic development:**
- Primary meaning: "axle" (cf. Syriac *surna*, Hebrew *sarnê nêhōšet* "copper axles" in 1 Kings 7:30)
- Secondary meaning: "tyrant, king" — applied to Philistine rulers (1 Samuel 6:16–18)
- Parallel: Hebrew *'ōfan* "wheel" also designates an angel in the hierarchy
- "Apparently the state was pictured as a chariot, which depended on the strength of its axles and wheels."

**At Ugarit:**
- *srn* and *bn srn* "Son of Srn" occur as personal names (= "King" and "Son of the King")
- Parallel: Semitic names *mlk* and *bn mlk* meaning "King" and "Son of the King"
- Phrase *yn srnm* = "wine of kings"

content:
[Document: Ugarit and Caphtor | Tags: kothar-wa-hasis, dagon, caphtor, helen-of-troy-motif, kret-legend, moses-minos, daedalus-bezalel, srn-tyrant, ugarit, crete]

**Thesis**: The Legend of King Kret links Cretan and Semitic epic traditions and serves as the "connecting link between Greek and Hebrew epic."

**The Helen-of-Troy motif:**
- King *Krēt* loses his beautiful wife *Hurray* (cf. Helen)
- He gathers an army and marches to *Odom* (cf. Troy) to recover her
- He gets his wife back, as in the Iliad

**Parallels with Homer (general):**
- Mingling of men and gods
- *Krēt* is a divine king; head of pantheon attends his wedding
- In Iliad: divine heroes; gods give wedding gifts to Peleus and Thetis

**Parallels with Homer (specific):**
- Lavish gifts offered (short of the heroine herself) to induce invading army to leave
- Offers rejected by *Krēt* outside *Odom* and by Achaeans outside Troy

**Parallels with Hebrew epic:**
- David weds princess Michal; she is taken away; he must get her back
- "Thus the legend of the Cretan hero *Kret* is the connecting link between Greek and Hebrew epic."

**Key quote**: "No matter how different Homer and the Hebrew 'Epic of Kings' may be in spirit, they draw on the same epic repertoire for content."

metadata.section: 4. The Kret Legend as Epic Bridge

**Moses-Minos:**
- Minos: giver of divine law, obtained (according to some traditions) on a mountain
- Moses: got the Law from God on Mount Sinai
- Both lay down foundations of society

**Daedalus-Bezalel:**
- Daedalus: master craftsman of Minoan tradition
- Bezalel: Moses's master craftsman
- Bezalel's creations include *kaftōrîm* "caphtors" (Exodus 37:17, 19–22)
- The word *kaftōrîm* bears the name of "the homeland of early Israel's major source of cultural inspiration"

**Key quote**: "What has not been noted is that the second greatest figure in Minoan tradition, namely Daedalus, has his counterpart in Moses's master-craftsman Bezalel."

> "This article aims at showing that Caphtor is the principal source of inspiration for early Greek and Hebrew culture: the two fountainheads of our heritage. It therefore follows that, in the years ahead, the field covered by 'Minos' is destined to be the cornerstone of the study of the origin of Western Civilization."

— *Context*: The concluding statement, asserting Minoan studies as central to understanding Western origins. > "The Hebrew account from Abraham through David's reign is based on East Mediterranean epic sources, just as Homer's epics are. Both are due to the Caphtorian impact."

— *Context*: Gordon's thesis that both Greek and Hebrew epic traditions derive from Caphtorian influence. > "Just as the Mycenaean offshoot of Caphtor was the basic civilizing factor of Achaean Greece, so too was the Philistine offshoot of Caphtor the basic civilizing factor of nascent Israel."

— *Context*: The parallel development of Greek and Israelite civilization from common Caphtorian roots. ---

This introductory chapter establishes the historical significance of Ugarit as the crossroads of Bronze Age civilizations. Gordon describes the 1928 discovery, the rapid decipherment of Ugaritic cuneiform, and Ugarit's position at the center of the "Amarna Order"—the international synthesis linking Mesopotamia, Egypt, the Hittites, and the Sea People. He argues that Ugarit provides the common backdrop to both Greek and Hebrew literatures, and explicitly challenges scholars who wish to keep Minoan civilization "free of Asiatic—and particularly Semitic—'contamination.'"

**Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter establishes the methodological framework for the entire book—Ugarit as the link between East and West Mediterranean, and the argument that relationship and individuality are not mutually exclusive. ---

**Narrative**: In 1928, a peasant accidentally plowed into an ancient Mycenaean-style tomb near the Syrian coast. French authorities (Direction des Antiquités de Syrie) sponsored excavations at Ras Shamra ("Fennel Head"), the mound marking ancient Ugarit. The port was Minet al-Bayda ("White Harbor"). **Rapid decipherment:**
- Cuneiform tablets in a new script discovered early 1929
- Published by Charles Virolleaud before the close of 1929
- Three scholars independently deciphered the script in 1930:
  1. Hans Bauer (first to publish)
  2. Edouard Dhorme (second)
  3. Charles Virolleaud (third)

**Claude Schaeffer's role**: The French archaeologist who directed excavations at Ras Shamra from 1929, publishing findings in the journal *Syria* and the multi-volume *Palais royal d'Ugarit* (PRU) series. **Key quote**: "It is to the lasting credit of French scholarship that the tablets were published in record time before the close of 1929."

**Significance of the tomb**: The Mycenaean-style architecture of the initial discovery hinted at what the texts would confirm—Ugarit's close connections with the Aegean world.

**Thesis**: Ugarit derived its importance from its location at the center of what was destined to become the cradle of Western civilization. **The International Order (ca. 1400–1200 BC):**

| Direction | Power | Significance |
|-----------|-------|--------------|
| East | Mesopotamia | "Outstanding pioneer in literate culture and international trade" |
| South | Egypt | "The aristocrat of the international Order" |
| North | Hittite Empire | Leading power after defeating Mitannians |
| West | Sea People | Mycenaean Greeks emerging as dominant factor |

**Canaan's position**: Ugarit was near the northwest corner of Canaan, "the land that nurtured a number of linguistically related groups, including the Phoenicians and Hebrews."

**Key quote**: "Ugarit was in contact with the forerunners of the classical Greeks and Hebrews, who were destined to found Western civilization by their combined and parallel achievements."

**Thesis**: The Ugaritic alphabet embodies the same tradition that came down through Phoenicians/Hebrews, Greeks, and Romans. **Evidence**: Ugaritic school texts list letters in fixed order: *a b g h d h w z h t y k š l m d n z s° p s q r t ġ t i u ṣ*

**Comparison:**
- English ABC: *a b—d—h—k l m n—p q r—t* appears in same Ugaritic sequence
- Hebrew: *a b g d h w z h t y k l m n s° p s q r—t* agrees even more strikingly

**Key quote**: "This alphabet is the most important and useful single invention of civilized man. Greece and Israel shared it—and much else besides."

**Evidence**: School tablets list words in three or four parallel columns:
- Three-column: Sumerian, Akkadian, Hurrian
- Four-column: adds Ugaritic

**Implication**: "A community that fostered a school system in which the advanced scribes studied texts to qualify them in four languages at a time, was highly sophisticated."

**Key quote**: "The earliest Greek and Hebrew literatures stem from a highly cultured and international milieu. There is nothing primitive about either of them."

**Thesis**: The tacit assumption that Israel and Greece were "independent cultures, poles apart" is contradicted by the Ugaritic epics. **The Athens-Sparta analogy**:
- "It would be hard to imagine two cultures more different than those of Athens and Sparta in the Age of Pericles, and yet because they were both Greek we know that they were related."
- "The newspapers in the homes of the English village and in the apartments of Manhattan are better historical and cultural criteria than the buildings."

**Against scholarly resistance**: Gordon explicitly challenges "some writers who want to keep Minoan civilization free of Asiatic—and particularly Semitic—'contamination.'"

**Key quote**: "What is often misunderstood is that relationship and individuality are not mutually exclusive."

> "Ugarit was the heir of the great cultures that had gone before, from Sumer to Egypt. Ugarit had the closest relations with people such as the Hittites and Hurrians, who were of prime importance in Mycenaean times, but were destined to disappear and require the spade of the archaeologist to revive their memory."

— *Context*: Establishing Ugarit's position as inheritor and transmitter of ancient traditions. > "We need not and must not withhold credit from the Ugaritians themselves. They were a talented and enterprising people in their own right. But they were lucky to be living in the right place at the right time: at the crossroads of the Western world when the seeds of Hellas and Israel had been planted and were producing their first fruits."

— *Context*: Balancing Ugarit's derivative and original contributions. > "A tacit assumption has it that Israel and Greece were independent cultures, poles apart. Speciously, a case can be made for such a view. For when did Israel produce a Parthenon, and when did Greece bring forth an Isaiah? But the Ugaritic epics, as will appear below, have unmistakable and organic parallels that link the preprophetic Hebrews with the prephilosophical Greeks."

— *Context*: The central thesis of the book, challenging disciplinary separation. ---

This chapter establishes the cultural mechanisms by which Ugaritic literature connects Greek and Hebrew traditions. Gordon demonstrates how guild mobility (craftsmen, traders, priests) spread cultural complexes across the East Mediterranean, then traces specific parallels: the Baal-Mot cycle's sabbatical structure, Kothar-wa-Hasis coming from Caphtor to build Baal's palace, the Helen-of-Troy motif linking Homer's Iliad to the Epic of Kret to Genesis, and the shared vocabulary of Danel's curse and David's lament over Gilboa. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter explicitly places Kothar-wa-Hasis as the link between Crete and Ugarit, shows how the Helen-of-Troy motif bridges Greek and Hebrew epic, and provides the cultural context for understanding Minoan-Semitic connections. ---

metadata.title: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II)

content:

**Thesis**: The international spread of cultural patterns in the Bronze Age East Mediterranean resulted from the mobility of guildsmen—craftsmen, potters, warriors, traders, and priests. **Evidence:**
- "There was no point in importing fragile ceramics for ordinary household use. It was the potters, rather than their wares, who could move without breakage."
- Warriors organized into guilds (like the *maryannu* charioteers) served on both sides of conflicts
- Ugaritic text 81 mentions mobile traders (*mkrm* = Hebrew *môkērîm*) and two priestly guilds: *khnm* (= Hebrew *kōhănîm*) and *qdšm* (= Hebrew *qĕdēšîm*)

content:
[Document: Ugaritic Literature and Its Greco-Hebrew Affinities (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter II) | Tags: baal, anath, leviathan, mot, yamm, kothar-wa-hasis, dagon, el, asherah, guild-mobility]

Gordon's footnote 4 provides a crucial insight into how the Hebrews selectively adopted and rejected Canaanite religious institutions:

> "This illustrates the fact that the Hebrews sometimes **borrowed from** (as in the case of the *kōhănîm*), and at other times **reacted against** (as in the case of the *qĕdēšîm*), their Canaanite milieu."

- **Kōhănîm** (כֹּהֲנִים): The legitimate priestly guild, borrowed from Canaanite practice and retained throughout biblical history to the present day
- **Qĕdēšîm** (קְדֵשִׁים): Temple functionaries associated with Asherah's cult, eliminated by King Josiah around 621 BC (II Kings 23:7)

**Significance**: This demonstrates that Hebrew religion was not created *ex nihilo* but emerged through selective adoption and deliberate rejection of existing Canaanite institutions. The same Ugaritic text documenting both priestly guilds shows they operated side by side in Canaanite religion; Israel's choice to keep one and eliminate the other reveals the theological priorities of emerging Yahwism. **Key quote**: "The international spread of religious guilds helped disseminate cultic practices and religious beliefs far and wide."

**Thesis**: West Semitic divine names reached Greek soil, proved by the site name "Sapyselaton" near Epidauris. **Analysis:**
- Pausanius (2:25:10) records the name "Sapyselaton"
- "Sapys" = Ugaritic *Spš*, the sun "goddess" (*elat*)
- The *p* (not *m*) and feminine gender link it to Ugaritic, not Akkadian
- This is distinctively Northwest Semitic: "unmistakably with the Ugaritic branch"

**Thesis**: The Epic of Aqhat was known to the Hebrews and provides pre-Hebrew literary sources. **Parallels:**
- Levi's son Qehat ("Kohath") = variant of Aqhat
- Ezekiel 14:14; 28:3 mentions Danel by name
- Incubation and sacrifice for obtaining a model son = Abraham/Isaac pattern
- *Kosharot* (songstresses/muses) appear in Psalm 68:7
- Pughat's transvestism = why Deuteronomy forbids cross-dressing

**Danel's Curse:**
> "Seven years may Baal afflict thee / Eight, the Rider of Clouds! / Let there be no dew / Let there be no rain / Let there be no surging of the Two Deeps / Let there be no goodness of Baal's voice!"

**The Seven/Eight Formula**: The "seven years / eight" pattern is not merely poetic parallelism but reflects the sabbatical agricultural cycle—seven years of cultivation followed by the eighth year of fallow. This formula appears throughout Ugaritic literature (see also Text 52) and demonstrates the pre-Hebrew, Canaanite origin of the biblical sabbatical institution. (cf. p. 93n)

**David's Lament (II Samuel 1:21):**
> "O mountains of Gilboa / Let there be no rain / Let there be no dew upon you!"

**Key quote**: "Danel and David react in the same way and express themselves in almost identical words because the culture and literature of heroic Israel stemmed from the heritage of Canaan."

This chapter presents Gordon's core thesis that Minoan civilization was founded by Northwest Semitic "Delta folk" who brought palace culture, syllabic writing, and Canaanite religion to Crete around 1800 BC. Gordon demonstrates the Semitic character of Linear A through the acrophony principle, Eteocretan bilinguals, and the pantheon of Hagia Triada tablets. This is the most technically important chapter for understanding Gordon's decipherment methodology. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter provides the key evidence for the Minoan-Semitic thesis—the acrophony principle, bilingual readings, and deity identifications that connect Minoan Crete to the Ugaritic/Canaanite cultural sphere from which Kothar-wa-Hasis originates. ---

metadata.title: Minoan Crete (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter III)

content:
[Document: Minoan Crete (Ugarit and Minoan Crete, Chapter III) | Tags: addu, baal, yamm, tinit, gupanu, kret, delta-origins, acrophony, linear-a, eteocretan]

**Thesis**: Minoan civilization appeared suddenly in MM I (ca. 1800 BC) fully developed, without prior evolution on Crete. The palace builders came from the Nile Delta. **Evidence:**
- Pre-Minoan Cretans were still Neolithic when the palace builders arrived
- Minoan palaces have no built-in hearths—unsuited to Cretan winters, suggesting southern origin
- Light-and-air wells expose interiors, aggravating heating problems
- Egyptian artifacts, ivory, and gold in Cretan excavations confirm Delta connections
- Genesis 10:13–14 derives "Philistines" and "Caphtorians" from Egypt
- Palace storerooms for grain and oil parallel Egyptian and Levantine administrative architecture

**The "Palace-without-Hearth" Problem**: Gordon notes that the absence of built-in hearths in Minoan palaces is architecturally definitive—these buildings were designed for a climate where heating was unnecessary, pointing unambiguously to southern (Egyptian Delta) origin. Mainland Greek Mycenaean palaces, by contrast, feature central hearths. > "The southern clime whence the Minoan palace builders came is not hard to determine. It must have been the Nile Delta, for Cretan archaeology has yielded a host of artifacts imported from, or imitating the workmanship of, Egypt."

**Key quote**: "Thus the forerunners of classical Greek and Hebrew cultures were kindred Delta folk."

**Thesis**: Linear A/B syllabic values derive from the initial consonant+vowel of Northwest Semitic words depicted by the pictographic signs. **Evidence table:**

| Pictograph | Syllabic Value | Semitic Word | Meaning |
|------------|----------------|--------------|---------|
| MAN | *bu* | Ug. *bunushu* | "man" |
| BOAT | *si* | Ug. *sipinatu* | "boat" |
| APPLE | *tu* | Ug. *tuppuhu* | "apple" |
| BIRD-OF-PREY | *ku* | Ug. *kudru* | "bird of prey" |
| MOUTH | *pe* | Heb. *peh* | "mouth" |
| CORNER | *pi/bi* | Ug. *pinnatu* | "corner" |
| BARLEY | *i* | Eg. *it* | "barley" |
| BREAST | *ha* | NW-S *hayniq* | "to nurse" |
| HAIR/HEAD | *qe* | Heb. *qewuṣṣa* | "hair, forelock" |
| EYE | *'a* | Heb. *'ayin* | "eye" |
| HORN | *qa* | NW-S *qarnu* | "horn" |
| HAND | *ya* | Heb. *yād* | "hand" |
| WATER | *ma* | Heb. *mayim* | "water" |
| HOUSE | *be* | Heb. *bayit* | "house" |

**Note on Method**: Gordon applies the syllabic values discovered by Ventris through cryptanalysis to derive Semitic readings. The pictographic origins demonstrate that the script was *invented* for a Semitic language, not merely borrowed for one. **Key quote**: "This principle, known as acrophony, indicates that Minoan writing was invented for the Northwest Semitic language whose vocabulary provides the syllabic values for the signs that Ventris discovered cryptanalytically in complete ignorance of the Semitic language."

**Thesis**: Eteocretan (Greek-letter inscriptions from Crete, 600–300 BC) is simply late Minoan, proving linguistic continuity for over a millennium. **Dreros First Bilingual:**
- Greek: ends with *matri* "for mother" (space for "his" broken)
- Eteocretan: ends with *lmo*
- Analysis: *lmo* = Hebrew *l-immō* "for his mother"

**Dreros Second Bilingual:**
- Greek: ends with *katharōn génoito* "let there be purity"
- Eteocretan: last word is *ihia*
- Analysis: *ihia* = Hebrew *yihye* "it will be" (jussive "let there be")

**Psychro Stone:**
- Written in Greek letters with first word *epithi* repeated in Minoan syllabic: *i-pi-ti*
- Analysis: = Phoenician *pth* "engraved stone" with definite article *e-*

**Key quote**: "The Eteocretan text from Psychro is fortunately a religious dedication that perpetuates some of the old Minoan terminology found in the eighteen known Linear A dedications, thereby proving that Eteocretan is a continuation of Minoan."

**Thesis**: The deities receiving offerings in the Hagia Triada tablets are Canaanite gods known from Ugarit. **Deity identifications:**

| Linear A | Ugaritic | Identity |
|----------|----------|----------|
| *A-du* | Addu/Haddu | Baal (storm god) |
| *Gu-pà-nu* | Gupanu | Vine god |
| *Gu-pà-na-tu* | — | Female counterpart of Gupanu |
| *A-ga-ru* | Ugaru | God of the field |
| *Ki-re-tá* / *Ki-re-ta-na* | Krt/Krtn | Divine king, son of El and Asherah |
| *Ya-mo* | Yamm | Sea god |
| *Ti-ni-ta* | Thinith | "Our great Lady" (Tanit) |

**The wheat equation (quasi-bilingual):**
- Linear A: *ku-ni-su* + WHEAT determinative
- Linear B: *si-to* + same WHEAT determinative
- Analysis: *ku-ni-su* = Akkadian *kunnishu* "emmer wheat"; *si-to* = Greek *sítos* "wheat"
- Conclusion: This equation confirms Semitic character of Linear A

**Thesis**: Not just nouns but also verbs, pronouns, conjunctions, numerals, and prepositions in Linear A are Northwest Semitic—ruling out loanword explanations. **Examples:**
- Verbs: "to be," "to give/donate," "to set up as offering"
- Pronouns: "he," "his," "this," "all" (*ku-lo* = Heb. *kol*)
- Conjunctions: "and" (*u*), "or"
- Numerals: "seven," "nine," "ten"
- Preposition: "to, for" (*le-*)

**Key quote**: "The grammar and syntax are Semitic, so that the Northwest Semitic nature of Minoan is established by the primary evidence."

'Europa' and 'Cadmus' are an appropriate pair of Semitic names, meaning 'West' and 'East,' respectively."

— *Context*: Gordon cites Greek mythological tradition as evidence for the Semitic character of Minoan culture. The names Europa (West) and Cadmus (East) form a complementary pair. > "The knowledge that the Minoan language was 'Phoenician' persisted until at least the fourth century A.D., when a Latin author, Lucius Septimius, described the accidental discovery of ancient literary texts at Knossos in the reign of Nero. The texts were brought to Nero, who assumed them to be Phoenician and turned them over to Semitists for translation."

— *Context*: Gordon notes that ancient tradition preserved knowledge of Minoan as Phoenician, which modern scholarship erroneously rejected. > "We have rich literary remains from Ugarit, but little so far from Minoan Crete. This is due to the accidents of discovery... Meanwhile the known Minoan texts suffice to bridge the gap between Ugarit and Greece, and show us that Northwest Semites laid the Minoan foundations for Mycenaean civilization: the first Greek culture in recorded history."

— *Context*: The concluding statement of the chapter, summarizing Gordon's thesis about the Minoan bridge between Semitic East and Greek West. ---

This massive chapter (100+ pages) contains Gordon's complete translations of the major Ugaritic mythological and epic texts. It includes the Baal and Anath Cycle (Yamm's kingship, Baal's palace building, the Baal-Mot conflict), the Epic of Kret (with its Helen-of-Troy motif), and the Epic of Aqhat/Danel (with parallels to Genesis and David's lament). **Myth**: "A narrative aimed at explaining either a natural phenomenon, such as some basic aspect of fertility (e.g., rain or dew), or a general condition affecting man's welfare (e.g., peace, health, or prosperity)."
- Used ritually to induce well-being by sympathetic principles
- Ritual drama reenacts myth

**Epic**: "Heroic narratives about people, although the gods are constantly affecting their destiny."
- Heroes are of the ruling class
- Continuity of royal line is of prime interest
- "The people worthy of a place in the epic are greater than life-size. As such they mingle with the gods socially."
- May have historical kernel; myths usually lack one

content:

**Structure**: Parallelistic balance—"two or more units of expression repeat, oppose, or otherwise complement each other."

**Synonymous pairs**: If "Baal" appears in one hemistich, the poet uses "Hadd" or "Dagon's Son" or "the Rider of Clouds" in the parallel. **Repetitions**: Gordon notes that "repetitions (with varying differences in wording) are part and parcel of the literary style; in general they do not result from the combining of different sources"—a challenge to documentary hypothesis assumptions. **Challenge to Source Criticism**: This observation has significant implications for biblical studies. The Wellhausen school's documentary hypothesis identified repetitions as evidence of multiple sources being conflated. Gordon argues instead that repetition is an *aesthetic* feature of Northwest Semitic literature, not evidence of composite authorship. The same repetitive patterns appear in both Ugaritic texts (where no source conflation is proposed) and biblical texts (where it has been assumed).

**David's Lament (II Samuel 1:21):**

**Key quote**: "Danel and David react in the same way and express themselves in almost identical words because the culture and literature of heroic Israel stemmed from the heritage of Canaan."

- Qehat (Kohath), son of Levi = variant of Aqhat
- Ezekiel 14:14 mentions Danel with Noah and Job as virtuous men of old

This chapter surveys the administrative and historical documents from Ugarit, establishing the dynastic history from Niqmad I (ca. 19th century BC) through Ammurapi (ending ca. 1195 BC with the Sea People invasion)—a span of over 600 years. Gordon examines royal correspondence, land grants, guild organization, and merchant regulations. Most significantly for the Minoan-Semitic thesis, he identifies personal names in PRU V that link Ugarit to both the Aegean (Mn "Minos," Ddl "Daedalus") and early Israel (Yšril "Israel," Abrm "Abram," Mt "Moses"). **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter provides the documentary evidence for cultural connections—personal names demonstrating that the same onomastic traditions existed at Ugarit, in the Aegean, and in Israel. It also illuminates Bronze Age guild society, the social context in which craftsmen like Kothar-wa-Hasis operated. ---

**Thesis**: Ugarit's royal line endured from the 19th century BC until ca. 1195 BC—longer than the Judean House of David (ca. 1000–586 BC). **Dynastic sequence (documented period):**

| King | Approximate Dates | Key Events |
|------|-------------------|------------|
| Ammistamru I | Amarna Age | Loyal to Egypt (Amarna Letter 45) |
| Niqmad II | until ca. 1345 BC | Fire and rebuilding; shift to Hittite vassalage |
| Arhalba | ca. 1345–1336 BC | Childless; levirate marriage arrangement |
| Niqmepa | ca. 1336–1265 BC | Long prosperous reign; merchant regulations |
| Ammistamru II | after ca. 1265 BC | Material prosperity; troubled marriages |
| Ibiranu | after Ammistamru II | Reprimanded for neglecting Hittite obligations |
| Niqmad III | short reign | — |

**Thesis**: Hattusilis III's regulations for merchants from Ur(ra) at Ugarit illuminate the status of foreign merchants—and parallel the Patriarchal narratives. **The three regulations for merchants of Ur(ra):**
1. May ply their trade and collect debts
2. May NOT stay permanently (must leave after harvest)
3. May NOT acquire real estate

**Parallel to Genesis**: In Genesis 34:10, 21, the Shechemites offer Jacob's family precisely these three normally forbidden privileges—trading rights, permanent residence, and purchasing real estate. **The Significance for Abraham's Status**: Gordon notes that Abraham's narrative makes sense within this framework—he is precisely the kind of foreign merchant (from Ur) whose status required special regulations. The offer of these privileges represents a formal elevation of status, not merely hospitality. **Key quote**: "It is interesting to note that these merchants came from Ur(a), a city bearing the same name as the city where Abraham was born."

**Additional Note**: The seasonal restriction (leaving after harvest) explains the transhumant patterns in the Patriarchal narratives—the constant movement between regions reflects the legal status of foreign merchants who could not establish permanent residence without special privilege.

content:

This concluding chapter synthesizes Gordon's central thesis: Ugaritic literature bridges the gap between Homer and the Bible, demonstrating that Greek and Hebrew civilizations emerged from a shared East Mediterranean cultural matrix. Gordon argues that the Helen-of-Troy motif links the Epic of Kret, the Iliad, and the Patriarchal narratives of Genesis. He explains the anti-Canaanite polemic in the Ten Commandments (particularly the prohibition against coveting) as a reaction to Ugaritic values where Baal was described as a "coveting god." Finally, he traces the transmission of Hurrian theogonic myths (Kumarbi/Zeus) through Minoan Crete to Hesiod. **Why this matters for Kothar**: This chapter represents the culmination of Gordon's argument—that the earliest Greek and Hebrew literatures share a common Northwest Semitic ("Phoenician") foundation transmitted through Minoan Crete. The craftsman traditions embodied by Kothar-wa-Hasis, Daedalus, and Bezalel are part of this shared heritage. ---

**Thesis**: The same narrative pattern—kings wresting a beautiful wife—appears in Greek epic, Ugaritic epic, and Hebrew patriarchal narrative. **The three manifestations:**
| Text | King | Wife | Foreign Power |
|------|------|------|---------------|
| Iliad | Menelaus | Helen | Priam's Troy |
| Epic of Kret | Kret | Hurrai | Pbl's Udum |
| Genesis 12, 20 | Abraham | Sarah | Pharaoh/Abimelech |

**Key quote**: "The Epic of Kret, with its Helen-of-Troy motif, anticipates the greatest epic of the West—Homer's Iliad. At the same time it shows quite plainly what had not been seen before: that the same motif forms a major strand in the Patriarchal Narratives of Genesis wherein kings wrest the beautiful Sarah from Abraham, the progenitor of kings."

**Significance**: "This Ugaritic parallel is particularly important because it is simultaneously associated with Greek and Hebrew literatures. Ugarit is the best-known link between the two."

**Thesis**: The prohibition against coveting was specifically directed against Canaanite religious values, where coveting was honorable. **Evidence:**
- The Ugaritic texts describe Baal as a "coveting god" using the same word (*hmd*) as in the Ten Commandments
- In Canaan, coveting was not opprobrious—it was a divine attribute

**Contrast with other commandments:**
- "Not to steal or commit adultery" = universal, enforceable by law
- "Not even to covet" = specifically anti-Canaanite, unenforceable

**Key quote**: "In Canaan 'coveting' was not opprobrious. To the contrary, the Ugaritic texts tell us that Baal was a coveting god, using the same word (hmd) as in the Ten Commandments. Accordingly, the emphasis on not coveting in Israel was prompted in opposition to the honored values of pagan Canaan."

**Thesis**: The Hesiodic theogony (Zeus displacing Cronus) derives from the Hurrian Kumarbi myth, transmitted through Minoan Crete. **The correspondences:**
| Hurrian | Greek |
|---------|-------|
| Kumarbi | Cronus |
| Teshub | Zeus |

**The channel of transmission**: "The Minoan texts from Hagia Triada, Crete, contain two unmistakable Hurrian names, so that now we have the channel of transmission."

**The Hurrian Names in Linear A**: Gordon identifies two Hurrian personal names in the Hagia Triada tablets, demonstrating that a Hurrian-speaking minority lived on Minoan Crete. This Hurrian presence explains how the Kumarbi theogonic myth reached Greece—not through post-Bronze-Age contact, but through the Northwest Semitic cultural matrix in which Hurrians participated. **Hesiod's Cretan Localization**: Hesiod (lines 477 and 480 of *Theogony*) specifically places the Zeus-Cronus myth *on Crete*. This is not poetic invention but cultural memory of the actual transmission route. **Key quote**: "Hesiod (lines 477 and 480) locates the story on Crete. The Minoan texts from Hagia Triada, Crete, contain two unmistakable Hurrian names, so that now we have the channel of transmission. It now appears that the Hurrian minority on Minoan Crete introduced the myth to the Aegean."

- Sumero-Akkadian heritage (east)
- Egyptian legacy (west)
- Canaanite cultural matrix (center)

**Key quote**: "Neither Greece nor Israel had to go abroad to borrow the rich contributions of Babylonia, the Nile Valley and other civilized areas of the Near East. The Sumero-Akkadian, Egyptian, Canaanite, and other heritages were built into the international culture entrenched on Greek and Palestinian soil before the Greeks and Hebrews of the Heroic Age in the second millennium appeared as historic entities."

- An Akkadian tablet records a ship trading between Ugarit and Caphtor (Crete)

**Key quote**: "This is the way mythology states that Ugarit looked to Crete as the centre of its material culture. At that time the greatest artistic centre in the East Mediterranean was Crete."

**Thesis**: The Ugaritic ABC preserves the order inherited by Phoenician-Hebrew, Greek, and Latin alphabets. **Evidence:**
- Ugaritic has 30 letters; the 22 that constitute Phoenician-Hebrew are already in the same sequence
- The letter *u* after *t* is preserved in Ugaritic, Greek, and Latin but lost in Phoenician-Hebrew
- Shorter Ugaritic alphabet (right-to-left, like Hebrew) found at Sarepta, Mount Tabor, Taanach, Beth-Shemesh

**Key quote**: "The most basic level of continuity from Ugarit to all subsequent stages of Western Civilization is brought out by the order of the alphabetic letters used at Ugarit."

**Thesis**: Ugaritic clarifies Hebrew passages where *b* and *l* mean "from" (not "in/to"). **Key example** (2 Kings 14:28):
- Text: Jeroboam II restored Damascus and Hamath *lyhwdh* "from Judah" into Israel
- Problem: How could northern Israel restore areas to southern Judah? - Solution: "Judah" here = Sam'al (Zinjirli) in northern Syria, not Jerusalem
- Ugaritic proves *l* = "from" in this context

**Key quote**: "For two and a half millennia the readers of the biblical books of Kings, with their Jerusalemite Judean orientation, did not understand the passage."

- Jezebel followed Canaanite *imitatio deorum*—did what Anath did (murdered Naboth for property)
- "The tragedy... was not that a good man had the misfortune to be wed to a bad woman, but rather that husband and wife adhered to opposing value systems."

**Thesis**: The Patriarchs were royal merchants operating from Ur(ra), illuminated by Hattusilis III's regulations. **Hattusilis III's tablet to Niqmepa' (ca. 1336–1265 BC):**
Three regulations for merchants of Ur(ra) in Ugarit:
1. May ply their trade and collect debts
2. May NOT stay permanently (must leave after harvest)
3. May NOT acquire real estate

**Genesis 34:10, 21**: Shechemites offer Jacob's family precisely these three normally forbidden privileges:
1. Trading rights
2. Permanent residence
3. Purchasing real estate

**Abraham buying land** (Genesis 23): Stressed precisely because foreigners were not ordinarily allowed to acquire it. **Ur(ra) = Urfa**: Syriac *Orrhai* close to Akkadian *Ur-ra*; suitable location in Hattusilis's realm; connected to Aramaism (matching Patriarchal language and homeland).

metadata.title: The Anath Text

content:
[Document: The Anath Text | Tags: anath, baal, yamm, leviathan, tannin, mot, el, battle-boast, chaos-combat, dualism]

The Anath text forms part of the Baal Cycle. Column I describes a divine banquet with wine and minstrelsy. Column II narrates Anath's bloodthirsty rampage that nearly destroys mankind—a massacre symbolizing victory, followed by the blessings of peace. Columns III-IV tell how Baal induces Anath to visit his mountain by promising to reveal "the secret of nature." When messengers arrive, Anath fears danger threatens Baal and boasts of her past victories: defeating Yamm (Sea), Tannin (Leviathan), Mot (Death), and other cosmic enemies. **Significance**: This text contains Anath's famous "battle boast" listing her defeated enemies—the same monsters (Leviathan, the seven-headed serpent, Tannin) that appear in Isaiah 27:1 and Psalm 74:14. Gordon notes: "We are dealing with a specific borrowing, not with the reappearance of a universal theme."

Gordon emphasizes that this text demonstrates the specific Canaanite origin of biblical dualism:

> "The slaying of the seven-headed Leviathan by the god(s) of goodness shows that the dualistic conflict between good and evil entered the biblical tradition with the absorption of the pre-Hebraic heritage of Canaan."

> "The terminology (not only 'Leviathan,' but also his epithets, such as 'the evil serpent,' 'the crooked serpent,' and 'Tannin,' as in Isaiah 27:1) leaves no doubt, for it is verbally identical in Ugaritic and Hebrew. **We are dealing with a specific borrowing, not with the reappearance of a universal theme.**"

[Document: Baal's Palace (Text 51) | Tags: baal, kothar-wa-hasis, el, asherah, mot, yahweh, window-controversy, palace-building, minoan-architecture, yw-el]

Text 51 narrates the construction of Baal's palace by Kothar-wa-Hasis. All gods except Baal have houses; Baal enlists Anath and Asherah to petition El for permission. El approves, and Kothar builds a magnificent palace of cedar, transformed by divine fire into gold and silver. The centerpiece is the "window controversy"—Kothar insists on installing a window while Baal refuses, though Baal eventually relents. Gordon notes this reflects the introduction of windowed palaces from Crete to Ugarit, since Minoan architecture featured windows while Ugaritic did not. **Critical Footnote**: This text also preserves the name "Yw-El" (Yahweh-El), suggesting Yahweh was originally El's son in pre-Israelite Canaan. ---

> "'Yw-El' is the son of the head of the pantheon. This suggests that 'Yahweh' ('Yw') was originally El's son in pre-Israelite Canaan. It is usual for a younger god to eclipse the older gods in the development of religion. In other words, just as Zeus eclipsed his father Cronus, Yahweh eclipsed his father El. Subsequently, Hebrew monotheism necessitated the identification of Yahweh with El."

**Significance**: This passage provides textual evidence that the divine name Yahweh predates Israelite religion and originally designated a son of El within the Canaanite pantheon. The theological development from polytheistic son-god to monotheistic identification with El parallels the Greek pattern of Zeus superseding Cronus. ---

metadata.title: The Epic of Aqhat

content:
[Document: The Epic of Aqhat | Tags: el, baal, anath, kothar-wa-hasis, epic, model-son, curse, transvestism, kosharot, gilboa-lament]

The Epic of Aqhat is the tale of the righteous King Danel, his model son Aqhat, and his avenger daughter Pughat. After seven days of offerings and incubation, Baal grants Danel a son. Kothar-wa-Hasis brings the boy a wondrous bow. The huntress goddess Anath covets it, offering first wealth, then immortality. Aqhat refuses both, adding that archery is not for women. Anath plots his murder through Yatpan, who strikes him while eagles hover overhead. One eagle devours Aqhat's remains. Drought and famine follow. Danel curses the land, retrieves Aqhat's remains from the mother of eagles, mourns for seven years, then sends his daughter Pughat to exact vengeance. She dons warrior's garb beneath women's clothes and infiltrates Yatpan's camp—where the text breaks off. **Biblical Significance**: Danel's curse parallels David's lament over Gilboa (II Samuel 1:21). Pughat's transvestism explains Deuteronomy's prohibition on cross-dressing. Ezekiel 14:14 and 28:3 mention Danel by name. ---

metadata.title: The Epic of Kret (Krt Texts 125-128)

content:
[Document: The Epic of Kret (Krt Texts 125-128) | Tags: el, baal, asherah, anath, astarte, helen-of-troy-motif, royal-epic, incubation, vow, kret-legend]

The Epic of Kret tells of King Kret whose destined wife has departed before giving him an heir. Through incubation, El appears in a dream and instructs Kret how to retrieve the lady Hurrai from King Pbl of Udum. Kret marshals his army, makes a vow to Asherah, and retrieves Hurrai. El blesses the union with seven sons and a daughter (Octavia). However, Kret fails to fulfill his vow, falls ill, and nearly dies. After divine intervention cures him, his son Yaṣib claims the throne, and Kret curses him. **The Helen-of-Troy Motif**: This epic contains the same wife-retrieval pattern found in Homer's Iliad (Menelaus/Helen/Troy) and Genesis 12, 20 (Abraham/Sarah/Egypt and Gerar). ---

metadata.title: Epilegomena to the Study of Greek Religion

content:
[Document: Epilegomena to the Study of Greek Religion | Tags: zeus, dionysus, agathos-daimon, kouretes, expulsion-impulsion, gorgoneion, liknon, rite-de-passage, totemism, tabu]

This concluding work summarizes Harrison's career findings on Greek religion, distilling *Prolegomena* (1903) and *Themis* (1912) into their essential arguments. Harrison demonstrates that religion is fundamentally social and arises from two primal impulses: **expulsion** (riddance of evil) and **impulsion** (enhancement of life), captured in the Chaeronea formula "Out with Famine, in with Health and Wealth." She traces religious development through four stages—totemism, initiation, king-god, and fertility drama—showing how the god emerges as "desire exteriorized, personified" from collective ritual. The work also acknowledges new debts to Jung, Freud, and the Russian philosopher Solovíóv. ---

metadata.title: Epilegomena to the Study of Greek Religion

content:

Harrison's foundational thesis—all religion serves to conserve and promote life:

> "The religious impulse is directed, if I am right, primarily to one end and one only, the conservation and promotion of life. This end is served in two ways, one negative, one positive, by the riddance of whatever is conceived to be hostile and by the enhancement of whatever is conceived of as favourable to life. Religious rites are primarily of two kinds and two only, of expulsion and impulsion."

**The Chaeronea formula:**
> "A household slave was driven out of doors with rods of *agnus castus*... and over him were pronounced the words 'Out with Famine, in with Health and Wealth.'"

metadata.section: 1. The Dual Impulse: Expulsion and Impulsion
metadata.title: Epilegomena to the Study of Greek Religion

content:
[Document: Epilegomena to the Study of Greek Religion | Tags: zeus, dionysus, agathos-daimon, kouretes, expulsion-impulsion, gorgoneion, liknon, rite-de-passage, totemism, tabu]

Two ritual implements embody the dual impulse:

> "The Gorgoneion... is in fact nothing but a ritual mask, a grinning face with glaring eyes, protruding beast-like tusks and pendent tongue. The Greek used the Gorgoneion for what he called 'prophylactic' purposes, that is to scare away all evil things."

> "Very different in its functions was the *liknon* or winnowing-fan.... The *liknon* became to the Greeks the great symbol and vehicle of purification physical and spiritual. But unlike the Gorgoneion it was wholly alien to the emotions of aversion and fear. It purified in order to promote growth and fertility."

**Marriage formulary preserved the dual purpose:**
> "At Athenian weddings a boy, both of whose parents were alive, carried a *liknon* full of loaves and pronounced the words: 'Bad have I fled, better have I found.'"

The shift from fear to hope defines religious progress:

> "The word 'bonfire' is not, as used to be held, *bon-feu*, good fire, *feu de joie*; it is bane or bone fire, a fire for burning up old bones and rubbish of every kind. Purification and the rubbish-heap first, and only later, because of the splendid blaze, a glow like the life-giving sun, jollification, fertility, impulsion."

> "The history of man's religious development from superstitious fear to faith and hope and charity is largely the history of the shift from *bone fire* to *bon-feu*."

Harrison argues religion precedes and does not require divinity:

> "We must face at the outset the fact that religion does not presuppose a god.... Buddhism claims perhaps more worshippers than any other religion.... No one denies to Buddhism the name of religion, yet Buddhism is godless, pure atheism."

> "Is there then no distinction between religion and magic? There is, and it is a distinction very simple but all important; religion is social, magic is or may be individual, religion is of the group however small, magic of the single unit."

The totem is primarily social, not zoological:

> "The word *totem* means not plant or animal but simply family, group or tribe. It is important to grasp this clearly as the supposed kinship of man with various plants and animals is a fact so odd that it has arrested undue attention and tended to obscure the real significance of the totem."

Harrison adopts Freud's term for the double-edged nature of tabu:

> "This *Ambivalenz* is characteristic of the feeling of the son to the father, and of all savages towards tabued objects. It is the attitude of obedience to a non-natural prohibition, the desire remaining while the prohibition holds."

> "Holiness has just this character of *Ambivalenz*; the thing that is *sacer* as Robertson Smith long ago recognized is impure as well as pure, a danger as well as a safeguard, it attracts and repels."

All life crises share the same structure:

> "All ceremonies concerned directly with the welfare of man have this transition character, ceremonies of birth, of puberty, of marriage and of death are all alike in mechanism, they all facilitate the passage from one state to another."

> "The great Eleusinian mysteries were primarily the rite of man's maturity side by side with rites to promote the maturity of earth's fruits."

**Death as initiation:**
> "That to die is to be initiated into the 'Higher Mysteries' was to the Greek a literal fact. This initiation was consummated by a Sacred Marriage with the Earth Mother."

Harrison describes a Thracian fertility drama still performed:

> "At Viza, the ancient Bizue in Thrace... may still be seen a folk-play which by its very simplicity and even baldness makes singularly clear its original magical intent."

**Structure:**
1. Masqueraders demand food with phallus-shaped knocker
2. Ploughing and sowing pantomime
3. Child grows to maturity, demands bride
4. Antagonist fights, is killed, lamented, and **resurrects**
5. Ploughing repeated with prayer: "May wheat be ten piastres the bushel!"

> "The intent of the whole ritual could not be clearer, it is a fertility drama 'that the poor may eat.'"

This article is Harrison's first major analysis of the Hymn to Diktaean Zeus discovered at Palaikastro, Crete. She argues that the mysteries of Zagreus-Dionysos—involving the dismemberment and resurrection of a divine child by "Titans" (white-clay-men)—are not inhuman cannibalistic rites but **tribal initiation ceremonies** analogous to those practiced by the Wiradthuri of Australia and countless other peoples worldwide. The Kouretes are not mythological beings but **initiated young men** who serve as παιδοτρόφοι (child-rearers) conducting initiates through death-and-rebirth rituals. ---

This chapter analyzes the Hymn to Diktaean Zeus discovered at Palaikastro in eastern Crete. Harrison argues that the hymn preserves in fossilized form the primitive ritual of tribal initiation. The "Kouros most Great" (*Megistos Kouros*) invoked by the Kouretes is not Zeus the Father but a year-spirit projected by the collective emotion of initiated young men. The Kouretes are not mythological attendants but real initiators who enact the death and rebirth of the tribal candidate. ---

content:

Harrison emphasizes the radical import of the opening words:

> "From the circumstances of the finding of the Hymn in the temple of Diktaean Zeus and from the title Kronian, it is clear that Zeus the Father of gods and men, is addressed as 'Kouros most Great,' greatest of grown-up youths. To our unaccustomed ears the title sounds strange and barely reverent." (p. 11)

**Critical distinction**: *Kouros* is not υἱός (son), nor is it παῖς (child). Kouros means "young man just come to maturity"—it connotes no relationship to a parent. The Kouros is the *projection* of the initiating group, not a divine infant.

metadata.section: 1. The Kouros is Not Zeus the Father
