> "Nowhere save in this Hymn do we hear of Zeus with attendant daimones. He stands always alone, aloof, approached with awe, utterly delimited from his worshippers. One god only, Dionysos, and he but a half-bred Olympian, is attended by daimones... The Hymn brings us face to face with the fact that Zeus once had a thiasos, once when he was a young man, a Kouros." (p. 14)

The presence of the thiasos reveals the primitive structure: the god emerges from the group, not the group from the god.

The Kouretes who dance over the infant in the hymn connect to the Zagreus mysteries, where Titans (white-clay-men) dismember a child who is then reborn:

**Cardinal elements:**
1. A child is taken from his mother and tended by men called Kouretes (παιδοτροφία)
2. The child is hidden, made away with, killed, dismembered (ἀφανισμός, σπαραγμός)
3. The child reappears, is brought to life again (ἀναβίωσις, παλιγγενεσία)

> "Every single element, however seemingly preposterous, in both the ritual and myth of Zagreus can be explained I believe by the analogy of primitive rites of tribal initiation." (p. 18)

Harrison etymologizes the Dithyramb—the choral hymn from which tragedy arose—as a "leap-song" connected to the Kouretes' ritual:

> "The word Dithyramb, Διθύραμβος, is, I believe, simply Δί-θύρ-αμβος, 'Zeus-leap-song.' The u in θύρ- for the more usual o of θόρ-, θρῴσκω, is due to northern Greek dialects which regularly show u for o." (p. 204)

**Etymology breakdown:**
| Component | Greek | Meaning |
|-----------|-------|---------|
| Δί- | Δι- | Zeus (genitive stem) |
| -θύρ- | θόρ-/θρῴσκω | leap, spring |
| -αμβος | ἀμβός | song, hymn |

The Kouretes "leap" (*θρῴσκουσι*) in their armed dance, just as the hymn commands the Kouros to "leap for full jars... leap for fleecy flocks." The Dithyramb was thus originally the magical song accompanying the spring-leap ritual that brought fertility.

Harrison connects the Kouretes to the Korybantes through their distinctive headgear:

> "The Korybantes are not really distinguishable from the Kouretes save in one particular—they wear the korybasia, the conical cap... This cap is at once the sign of the initiated and the means of initiation. The neophyte puts on the cap and becomes a Korybas." (p. 27)

**The korybasia (κορυβασία):**
- Conical felt cap worn by initiates
- Etymologically related to κορυβάντες (Korybantes)
- Symbol of transformation from boy to initiated man
- Depicted on Phrygian coins and Samothracian reliefs

The putting-on of the cap is a ritual death—the boy "disappears" under the cap and emerges as a new being, a Korybas.

content:
[Document: Chapter I: The Hymn of the Kouretes | Tags: zeus, megistos-kouros, dionysus, zagreus, kouretes, korybantes, titans, initiation, tribal-initiation, dromenon]

Harrison provides a crucial parallel from mainland Greece—a hymn sung by the women of Elis invoking Dionysus in spring:

> "In Springtime, O Dionysos,
> To thy holy temple come,
> To Elis with thy Graces,
> Rushing with thy bull-foot, come,
> Noble Bull, Noble Bull."

**Structural parallels to the Palaikastro Hymn:**
| Element | Kouretes Hymn | Women of Elis Hymn |
|---------|---------------|---------------------|
| **Invocation** | "Io, Kouros most Great, come!" | "To thy holy temple come" |
| **Season** | "For the Year" (ἐνιαυτῷ) | "In Springtime" |
| **Animal form** | (Bull implicit in leaping) | "Bull-foot... Noble Bull" |
| **Attendants** | "At the head of thy Daimones" | "With thy Graces" |
| **Magical intent** | Fertility, increase | (Spring renewal) |

> "The Elis hymn shows that the invocation of an incoming god is not peculiar to Crete; it belongs to the Spring ritual of the Eniautos-Daimon wherever found. The god is bidden to come because he is not yet there—he is born anew each year." (p. 32)

---

> "The word Kouretes is simply a specialized derivative of Kouros... It is, like Kouros, a word impossible to translate, because we have lost the social condition expressed. Young Men (Kouroi) we know, but Initiated Young Men (Kouretes) are gone for ever." (p. 24)

— Context: Harrison explains why these Greek terms resist translation—we lack the social institution they name. > "At and through his initiation the boy is brought into close communion with his tribal ancestors: he becomes socialized, part of the body politic. Henceforth he belongs to something bigger, more potent, more lasting, than his own individual existence: he is part of the stream of the totemic life, one with the generations before and yet to come." (p. 23)

— Context: The meaning of initiation—social rebirth, not merely ceremonial marking. > "So vital, so crucial is the change that the savage exhausts his imagination and his ingenuity in his emphasis of death and new birth. It is not enough to be killed, you must be torn to pieces or burnt to ashes. Above all you must utterly forget your past life." (p. 23)

— Context: Why the death symbolism in initiation is so emphatic. ---

**Discovery**: The hymn was found at Palaikastro, eastern Crete, in excavations by the British School at Athens (1902–1905). Three main fragments were recovered from near a temple of Diktaean Zeus. **Dating**: The stele was engraved in the 2nd–3rd century AD (cursive letters), but the poem itself dates to approximately 300 BC. Two copies exist on front and back of the same stone—suggesting the stone-mason found the material unfamiliar. **Significance**: Palaikastro preserved archaic customs that had died out at Knossos. As Strabo noted, "when the warlike cities, and especially Knossos, were ravaged, certain customs were kept up among the inhabitants of Lyttos and Gortyna and other lesser towns rather than by the Knossians."

content:
[Document: Chapter X: From Daimon to Olympian — Apollo and the Olympians | Tags: apollo, dionysus, gaia, themis, phoibe, phoibos, python, titans, olympian, aguieus]

This chapter completes Harrison's analysis of the transition from daimon to Olympian by examining Apollo—the one who "successfully" made the passage. Harrison demonstrates that Apollo as Aguieus was originally a fertility-cone like the omphalos, that the Python-slaying myth arose from the ritual death of the snake-king at the enneateric Stepterion, and that Apollo as Phoibos inherited the attributes of moon and sun. Most significantly, the chapter establishes what it means to be an "Olympian": the systematic negation of the Eniautos-daimon's characteristics—shedding animal form, repudiating earth-connection, refusing to die and be reborn. ---

metadata.title: Chapter X: From Daimon to Olympian — Apollo and the Olympians

content:
[Document: Chapter X: From Daimon to Olympian — Apollo and the Olympians | Tags: apollo, dionysus, gaia, themis, phoibe, phoibos, python, titans, olympian, aguieus]

The street-god was originally an omphalos-like pillar:

> "Aguieus is a pillar tapering to the end, which they set up before the doors. And some say they are proper to Apollo, others to Dionysos, others to both." (Harpocration)

Harrison explains: "The pillar was neither Apollo nor Dionysos, it preceded and entered into the nature of both." (p. 418)

**At Ambrakia** the cone appears on coins:
> "The filleted obelisk on the coins of Ambrakia is the symbol and vehicle of a god thrice familiar, Apollo Aguieus, 'He of the Ways.'" (p. 419)

[Document: Chapter X: From Daimon to Olympian — Apollo and the Olympians | Tags: apollo, dionysus, gaia, themis, phoibe, phoibos, python, titans, olympian, aguieus]

Harrison establishes the omphalos's true nature:

> "Varro provides a crucial tradition: the omphalos at Delphi is the tumulus of Python, a sacred snake. The omphalos is thus a grave-mound marked by a holy stone, combining elements of tomb and tombstone." (p. 421)

**Evidence from beehive tombs:**
> "The 'Tomb of Tantalos' on Mt. Sipylos features a terminal cone like the Delphic omphalos, symbolizing life and reincarnation." (p. 422)

Harrison analyzes three nine-year festivals at Delphi:

> "There are three Nine-Year Festivals that the Delphians keep in the following order. One they call Stepterion, the next Herois, the third Charila." (Plutarch, *Greek Questions*)

| Festival | Meaning | Ritual |
|----------|---------|--------|
| **Stepterion** | "Festival of Wreathers" | Attack on king's hut, flight to Tempe, return with laurel |
| **Herois** | "Bringing up of Semele" | Thyiades' mystery, resurrection of earth |
| **Charila** | Famine-expulsion | Puppet beaten and buried, then exhumed |

content:
[Document: Chapter X: From Daimon to Olympian — Apollo and the Olympians | Tags: apollo, dionysus, gaia, themis, phoibe, phoibos, python, titans, olympian, aguieus]

There was no snake in the ritual—only a king's palace:

> "Clearly Plutarch has here no belief in the aetiological myth.... The Stepterion consisted of a secret attack with lighted torches on a hut, which though apparently it is made of wood or reeds had somehow—a piece of purple drapery and a wreath would do it—the semblance of a king's palace." (p. 426)

**The snake-king origin:**
> "There was a snake at Delphi probably painted on the omphalos, and, it may be, a real snake used for divination.... The king as hero-daimon is envisaged as a snake. Cecrops was a snake, Kychreus was a snake. The old snake dies, the young snake lives." (p. 432)

metadata.title: Chapter X: From Daimon to Olympian — Apollo and the Olympians

content:
[Document: Chapter X: From Daimon to Olympian — Apollo and the Olympians | Tags: apollo, dionysus, gaia, themis, phoibe, phoibos, python, titans, olympian, aguieus]

The ritual pole encodes the sequence from Earth to Heaven:

> "They wreathe a pole of olive wood with laurel and various flowers. On the top is fitted a bronze globe, from which they suspend smaller ones. Midway round the pole they place a lesser globe binding it with purple fillets.... By the topmost globe they mean the sun to which they actually compare Apollo. The globe beneath this is the moon." (Proklos)

Harrison concludes: "We have an Eiresione of the Earth, the flowers of the Earth.... We have the Moon with her purple fillets half-way up the pole, and at the top the saffron-decked globe of the golden Sun Phoibos himself. The ladder from Earth to Heaven is complete." (p. 436)

The name Apollon derives from the ephebic assembly:

> "The word ἀπελλαζέως is, Hesychius tells us, Laconian for ἐκκλησιάζειν.... Most significant of all Hesychius has the gloss ἀπελλακᾶς· ἐστιν ἐφήβων κοινωνία." (p. 437)

> "The ἀπελλαία I believe to be the offerings made at puberty initiation. Apellaios is the month of these rites and these offerings, Apellon is the projection of these rites; he, like Dionysos, like Herakles, is the arch-ephebos, the Megistos Kouros." (p. 438)

Harrison identifies three "negative" characteristics:

**1. Sheds plant and animal form:**
> "In art this exclusion of animal and plant life from the cycle of the divine is sometimes claimed as a gain. Rather it leaves a sense of chill and loneliness." (p. 446)

**2. Refuses to be an Earth-daimon:**
> "When the human-shaped Olympians triumph they [the snake-daimones] become evil monsters to be overthrown. Their kingdom is of this earth." (p. 448)

**3. Refuses to be a daimon of air and sky:**
> "The Titans cannot be very precisely delimited from the Giants. They too are in some sense Earth-born.... But, and this is the interesting point, the Titans, unlike the Giants, seem early to have left their earth-nature behind them and climbed one step up the ladder to heaven." (p. 452)

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

This culminating chapter defines Themis as the projection of the collective conscience—not merely abstract justice but the social imperative itself, the "stuff of which religious representations are made." Harrison demonstrates that Themis hovers "on the very verge of godhead" as the force that binds men together, preceding the particular shapes of gods. Using Durkheim's sociology, she argues that religion consists of obligatory beliefs connected to definite practices—and that this obligation derives solely from the social conscience. The chapter traces the shift from matrilinear to patrilinear structure, showing how Zeus, Apollo, and Athena form a patriarchal trinity (Phratrioi) while the older figures (Kronos, Gaia, the Kouretes) preserve matrilinear patterns. ---

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

Harrison's central thesis—Themis is the collective conscience personified:

> "Themis is the force that brings and binds men together, she is 'herd instinct,' the collective conscience, the social sanction. She is *fas*, the social imperative. This social imperative is among a primitive group diffuse, vague, inchoate, yet absolutely binding." (p. 485)

**Etymology reveals function:**
> "The Greek word Themis and the English word Doom are, philology tells us, one and the same.... Doom is the thing set, fixed, settled; it begins in convention, the stress of public opinion; it ends in statutory judgment.... **Themis like Doom begins on earth and ends in heaven.**" (p. 482)

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

Themis precedes and underlies all gods but never becomes fully divine:

> "In a word Themis is not religion, she is the stuff of which religious representations are made. That is why in the ordered sequence of the gods at Delphi we gave Themis no place. She is the substratum of each and every god, she is in a sense above as well as below each and every god, but herself never quite a full-fledged divinity." (p. 489)

**Homer shows her hovering on divinity:**
> "Patroklos comes to the place where was their assembly and their *themis*, whereby also were the altars of their gods established.... The social fact is trembling on the very verge of godhead." (p. 485)

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

Harrison adopts Durkheim's sociological definition:

> "Les phénomènes dits religieux consistent en croyances obligatoires connexes de pratiques définies qui se rapportent à des objets donnés dans les croyances." (p. 490)

**The key insight:**
> "It is the emphasis and representation of herd instinct, of the collective conscience, that constitutes religion." (p. 485)

Religion vs. morality vs. art:
> "Morality is the social conscience made imperative upon our actions, but morality unlike religion, save on questions involving conduct, leaves our thoughts free. Art, which is also, like religion, a representation of the social conscience, has no incumbencies. She imposes no obligation on either action or thought. Her goddess is Peitho not Themis." (p. 491)

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

The barbarian condition is lack of Themis:

> "That is what is wrong with the Cyclopes: they reverence the gods, they are earth-worshippers, and earth for them brings forth her increase, but they are *ἀθέμιστες*, they have no customs, no conventions, binding by common consent, they have no *agora*. That for the Greek was the last desolation." (p. 483)

**Homer's portrait:**
> "Κυκλώπων δ' ἐς γαῖαν ὑπερφιάλων, ἀθεμίστων, ἱκόμεθ'.....τοῖσι δ' οὕτ' ἀγοραὶ βουληφόρου οὔτε θέμιστες." (p. 483)

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

Themis's function in Homer is to convene and dissolve assemblies:

> "Why, we ask, with Hermes and Iris at hand, ready to speed over earth and sea with messages and mandates, should Themis have to execute just this one office of convening the assembly?... She is no herald like Hermes, no messenger like Iris, she is the very spirit of the assembly incarnate. Themis and the actual concrete *agora* are barely distinguishable." (p. 484)

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

The older religion reflected matrilinear society:

> "Mother, Child, Initiated youths, these are the factors of the old social group. The father, Kronos, is...nowhere.... The myth is a presentation, a projection of the days when, at first, the facts of fatherhood were unknown, and later, but little emphasized." (p. 504)

**Woman as social centre:**
> "It is important to note that this primitive form of society is matrilinear not matriarchal. Woman is the social centre not the dominant force.... In primitive matrilinear societies woman is the great social force or rather central focus, not as woman, or at least not as sex, but as mother, the mother of tribesmen to be. This social fact finds its projection in the first of divine figures, in *Kourotrophos*—'Rearer of Sons.'" (p. 505)

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

The Olympian family reflects patrilinear conquest:

> "This alliance of the three Olympians of the Eumenides, Zeus, Apollo, Athena, brings us to a curious point. The bond, we feel, is non-natural; the three gods stand together not because there is any primitive link, any common cultus, but as projections, representations of patriarchy, pushed to the utmost. They are a trinity of *Phratrioï*, *Putrōoï*." (p. 513)

**Apollo's argument in the *Eumenides*:**
> "The mother is no parent of her 'child,' / Only the nurse of the young seed within her. / The male is parent, she as outside friend / Cherishes the plant, if fate allows its bloom." (p. 513)

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

Dike differs from Themis in extending to all nature:

> "We speak of the δίκη of a wolf, a foal, a torrent, not of its θέμις; but man, as well as nature, has his ways, his habits, so we speak of the δίκη of men.... *Dike* then is the way of the world, the way things happen, and *Themis* is that specialized way for human beings which is sanctioned by the collective conscience, by herd instinct." (p. 523)

**Dike as universal course:**
> "In one passage at least, in the *Medea* of Euripides Dike stands for the course, even the circular course of the whole cosmos. In the general reversal of all things: 'Upward go the streams of the living rivers, Dike and all things are turned about.'" (p. 525)

---

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

Harrison analyzes the festival of gender-reversal:

> "The name τὰ ὑβρίστικα means things outrageous, insolent in the etymological sense, things against use and wont. Now why, in a primitive society, should *Themis* who rules over all things be wantonly and yet systematically outraged?" (p. 508)

**The solution:**
> "The rites of puberty, the rites of marriage, are, like all other primitive rites, *rites de passage*: their object is to afford a safe passage in the perilous transit from one age or condition to another.... When he passes to manhood, he ceases to be a woman-thing and begins to exercise functions other and alien." (p. 509)

metadata.section: The Hybristika and Rites de Passage
metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

Harrison explicitly adopts Arnold van Gennep's terminology from *Les Rites de Passage* (1909):

> "Van Gennep has shown that the rites de passage fall into three stages: rites of separation (préliminaires), rites of transition (liminaires), and rites of incorporation (postliminaires). The initiate must die to his old status, pass through a liminal state of suspension, and be reborn to his new condition." (p. 510)

**The three phases in Greek rites:**
| Phase | Name | Example |
|-------|------|---------|
| **Préliminaire** (Separation) | Death of old status | Seclusion from women; departure from mother |
| **Liminaire** (Transition) | Liminal suspension | Gender reversal; silence; darkness |
| **Postliminaire** (Incorporation) | Rebirth to new status | Crowning; new name; return to society |

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

The liminal or transitional phase is characterized by reversal of ordinary rules:

> "In the liminal state, the ordinary rules of Themis are suspended. The initiate is neither boy nor man, neither alive nor dead. He may wear women's clothes, or go naked, or be smeared with clay. He is a-social, extra-social, until the rite of incorporation restores him to the social order—but in a new place." (p. 511)

**Liminal characteristics in Greek rites:**
| Rite | Liminal Feature | Meaning |
|------|-----------------|---------|
| Krypteia (Sparta) | Youth lives wild, like a wolf | Beyond social law |
| Arkteia (Brauron) | Girls "become bears" | Temporary wildness |
| Oschophoria | Youths dress as women | Gender boundary dissolved |
| Argive Hybristika | Women wear men's clothes | Social reversal |

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

The initiatory death is not metaphor but social reality:

> "The death is real in this sense—the boy, the child of his mother, really dies. He is killed, torn to pieces, burnt to ashes, forgotten; and he who rises again is a man and a tribesman. He has been made into something other than he was." (p. 512)

**The death-rebirth pattern:**
1. **Seclusion** - Removal from mother and women
2. **Ordeal** - Pain, terror, mutilation (circumcision, scarification)
3. **Instruction** - Sacred knowledge revealed
4. **New name** - Old identity abandoned
5. **Return** - Re-entry as adult male

> "The severity of initiation rites is not mere cruelty or superstition. It is a religious necessity. The old self must be utterly destroyed that the new self may be born. The greater the transformation required, the more drastic the ritual death." (p. 513)

---

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

Harrison connects oracular rites to initiation:

> "The same *daimones* preside over oracles and over rites of initiation; *Trophoniads*, *Idaean Daktyls* and those of the age of *Kronos* are all substantially the same." (Plutarch, cited p. 517)

**Lethe and Mnemosyne:**
> "*Lethe* is but an attenuated Death; *Mnemosyne*, renewed consciousness, is a new Life." (p. 518)

> "Plato's whole scheme alike of education and philosophy is but an attempted rationalization of the primitive mysticism of initiation, and most of all of that profound and perennial mysticism of the central *rite de passage*, the death and the new birth, social, moral, intellectual." (p. 520)

---

metadata.title: Chapter XI: Themis

content:
[Document: Chapter XI: Themis | Tags: themis, zeus, apollo, athena, dike, horai, kronos, kourotrophos, collective-conscience, social-imperative]

> "Religion has in it then two elements, social custom, the collective conscience, and the emphasis and representation of that collective conscience. It has in a word within it two factors indissolubly linked: ritual, that is custom, collective action, and myth or theology, the representation of the collective emotion, the collective conscience. And—a point of supreme importance—both are incumbent, binding, and interdependent." (p. 491)

— Context: The dual nature of religion as practice and representation. > "The notion of the divinity, far from being what is fundamental in religious life, is in reality but a secondary episode. It is the product of a special process by which one or two of the religious characteristics concentrate and take concrete shape in the form of a more or less defined individuality." (Durkheim, cited p. 494)

— Context: Gods emerge from sanctity, not the reverse. > "And first did the *Moirai* lead Heavenly *Themis* of the Good Counsels with golden horses along the springs of *Okeanos*, up the holy ladder of *Olympos*, along the shining way. She who was of earth, she who was Earth herself, leaves her home and goes the way of all things divine, up to *Olympos*. But, in the very pomp and pageant of her going, we feel she is entering on an alien kingdom." (Pindar, cited p. 527)

— Context: Themis's "translation" to heaven is artificial—she belongs to earth. > "For all men rose again from the earth remembering nothing of their past. And such things as private property and families did not exist, but Earth herself gave them abundance of fruits from trees and other green things, spontaneously, and not through husbandry." (Plato, *Politicus*, cited p. 507)

— Context: The Age of Kronos preserved matrilinear, communal structure. ---

- **Type**: Book Chapter
- **From**: *Themis: A Study of the Social Origins of Greek Religion*
- **Author**: Jane Ellen Harrison (1850–1928)
- **Date**: 1912
- **Pages**: 30–49
- **Citation**: Harrison, J.E. (1912). *Themis*. Cambridge University Press, Chapter II.

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
[Document: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama | Tags: dionysus, dromenon, legomenon, dithyramb, drama, tragedy, mimesis, exarchos, palingenesia, magical-intent]

This chapter develops Harrison's theory that ritual action (*dromenon*) precedes and generates both myth (*legomenon*) and drama. The Greek dithyramb—the choral song to Dionysos from which tragedy arose—was originally a spring *dromenon*, a magical rite of renewal. Harrison traces the psychological and linguistic origins of the *dromenon* concept and argues that drama inherits its essential forms from seasonal fertility ritual. ---

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
[Document: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama | Tags: dionysus, dromenon, legomenon, dithyramb, drama, tragedy, mimesis, exarchos, palingenesia, magical-intent]

Harrison's foundational definition:

> "A *dromenon* is, literally, 'a thing done,' but the word has a shade of meaning that our word 'deed' has lost. By *dromenon* the Greeks meant not only a thing done but a thing re-done, or pre-done; a thing enacted or represented. It is sometimes translated 'ritual,' but *dromenon* goes to the very heart of ritual while 'ritual' is apt to emphasize the outer shell." (p. 35)

**Key distinction**: A *dromenon* is not mere action—it is action with **magical intent**, either commemorative (re-enacting the past) or anticipatory (pre-enacting the desired future).

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
[Document: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama | Tags: dionysus, dromenon, legomenon, dithyramb, drama, tragedy, mimesis, exarchos, palingenesia, magical-intent]

Harrison argues against the view that myths generate rituals:

> "This does not, however, imply, as is sometimes supposed, that ritual is prior to myth; they probably arose together. Ritual is the utterance of an emotion, a thing felt, in action, myth in words or thoughts. They arise *pari passu*. The myth is not at first aetiological, it does not arise to give a reason; it is representative, another form of utterance, of expression." (p. 16)

**The relationship**:
- τὰ δρώμενα = things done (ritual action)
- τὰ ἐπὶ τοῖς δρωμένοις λεγόμενα = things said upon the things done (accompanying words)

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
[Document: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama | Tags: dionysus, dromenon, legomenon, dithyramb, drama, tragedy, mimesis, exarchos, palingenesia, magical-intent]

The dithyramb marks the transition:

> "The Dithyramb was then a *dromenon*, 'a thing done' in relation to a *daimon*, a fertility spirit, and that fertility spirit was in the first instance the group itself. When the group—or if the group be already individualized, the representative of the group—did the Dithyramb, it did its own life-history, it enacted the *palingenesia* or New Birth." (p. 45)

**Three stages:**
1. Collective dance with undifferentiated participants
2. Emergence of a leader (*exarchos*) who stands apart
3. Dialogue between leader and chorus → birth of drama

metadata.title: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama

content:
[Document: Chapter II: The Dithyramb, the Dromenon and the Drama | Tags: dionysus, dromenon, legomenon, dithyramb, drama, tragedy, mimesis, exarchos, palingenesia, magical-intent]

Harrison draws on contemporary psychology:

> "Pantomimic dancing is of the essence of each and every primitive mystery. To disclose the mysteries is, as Lucian puts it, 'to dance out the mysteries.' Instruction among savage peoples is always imparted more or less in mimetic dances." (p. 42)

Mimesis is not mere imitation but **participatory identification**—the dancer *becomes* what he enacts. ---

> "Drama, like the Dithyramb out of which it came, was in its origin and essence the enactment, the *dromenon*, of a god; its representation was in ritual movement what the myth told in words. Drama lived its life in and through the cult of Dionysos because Dionysos, unlike the other Olympians, was himself in origin a *dromenon*, a thing annually enacted, the New Birth, the year-spirit incarnate." (p. 48)

— Context: Why drama belonged to Dionysos specifically, not to any other god. > "The primitive mind is not occupied in asking 'why?' It is too busy dancing and singing to ask questions. The *dromenon* is not an attempt to explain anything, it is simply a rite, a thing done, done for the good of the tribe, done because it always has been done, done with immediate magical intent." (p. 38)

— Context: Against intellectualist theories that see ritual as "primitive science."

The Eniautos-Daimon or Year-Spirit is the central concept of *Themis*. Harrison argues that Greek religion originates not in individual gods but in a collective representation of the life-cycle - a daimon who embodies the death and rebirth of the year, the tribe, and all fertility. This figure manifests as the Kouros, the holy Bull, Dionysus, and ultimately crystallizes into the Olympian gods. The Eniautos-Daimon is at once the projected life of the group and the life of nature; his ritual generates both agonistic festivals and drama. ---

metadata.title: The Eniautos-Daimon (Year-Spirit) Concept

content:
[Document: The Eniautos-Daimon (Year-Spirit) Concept | Tags: zeus, dionysus, agathos-daimon, plouton, horai, charites, eniautos-daimon, year-spirit, year-cycle, seasonal-festivals]

Harrison emphasizes that the "Year" (capitalized) is not a mere calendar unit:

> "The expression 'for the Year' is somewhat enigmatic. It should be carefully noted that the 'Year' for which the Kouros is 'summoned' and 'reared' is not an etos but an eniautos. The two words are in Homer frequently juxtaposed, and the mere fact of the juxtaposition shows that they are distinguished." (p. 221)

| Term | Greek | Meaning |
|------|-------|---------|
| **etos** | year proper | the complete circle of revolution |
| **eniautos** | year-turning | end of old year, beginning of new |
| **telesphoros** | end-bringing | epithet frequently applied to eniautos |

**Etymology (following Prellwitz):**
> "Dr. Prellwitz makes eniautos a nominative formed from a prepositional clause en auto, originally en-an-to 'at-again-the-point.' This admirably suits the new meaning. Eniautos on this showing is 'Here we are again' incarnate." (p. 222)

metadata.title: The Eniautos-Daimon (Year-Spirit) Concept

content:
[Document: The Eniautos-Daimon (Year-Spirit) Concept | Tags: zeus, dionysus, agathos-daimon, plouton, horai, charites, eniautos-daimon, year-spirit, year-cycle, seasonal-festivals]

The eniautos was marked by perilous transition rituals:

> "The eniautos then was the cardinal turning-point of the year, it was ene kai nea in one. Such a day to ancient thinking must be marked out by rites de passage, for the issues were perilous. Such rites de passage are those of Closing and Opening, of Going to sleep and Waking up again, of Death and Resurrection, of killing or carrying out the Old Year and bringing in the New. To such rites it was natural, nay, it was necessary, to summon the Kouros." (p. 223)

metadata.section: 2. The Rites de Passage at the Year-Turning
metadata.title: The Eniautos-Daimon (Year-Spirit) Concept

content:
[Document: The Eniautos-Daimon (Year-Spirit) Concept | Tags: zeus, dionysus, agathos-daimon, plouton, horai, charites, eniautos-daimon, year-spirit, year-cycle, seasonal-festivals]

The year is not an abstraction but its own content - the fruits it brings:

> "The year and the seasons derive then their value, as was natural, from the food they bring. They are not abstractions, divisions of time; they are the substance, the content of time. To make of eniautos a god, or even a daimon, seems to us, even when he is seen to be not a year but a Year-Feast, a chilly abstraction, and even the Horae as goddesses seem a little remote. But to the Greeks, as we see abundantly on vase-paintings, their virtue, their very being, was in the flowers and fruits they always carry in their hands." (p. 226)

**The procession of Eniautos (from Kallixenos, via Athenaeus):**
> "After the Satyrs came two Sileni, the one with petasos and caduceus as herald, the other with trumpet to make proclamation. And between them walked a man great of stature, four cubits tall, in the dress and mask of a tragic actor and carrying the gold horn of Amaltheia. His name was Eniautos. A woman followed him, of great beauty and stature, decked out with much and goodly gold; in one of her hands she held a wreath of peach-blossom, in the other a palm-staff, and she was called Penteteris. She was followed by four Horai dressed in character and each carrying her own fruits." (p. 227)

The Year-Spirit is not an individual but a projection of the group:

> "Man's first need was food and, closely connected therewith, an adequate supply of children. His earliest divinities - vague, hardly personal daimones - were of food and fertility. At first he was contented with magic; he did certain things and believed that they magically reacted on his food supply. Then, when his tribal feeling grew keener and his magic became a ritual, he projected his emotion - it became a daimon - Eniautos-daimon." (p. 158)

> "The Eniautos-Daimon... was at once the representation of the life of the group and the life of nature." (Introduction, p. xxii)

Harrison connects the Eniautos to lunar reckoning:

> "The three Horae are the three phases of the Moon, the Moon waxing, full and waning. After the simple seasonal year with its two divisions came the Moon-Year with three, and last the Sun-Year with four Horae." (p. 233)

**Evidence from Crete:**
- Moon-worship established by Minoan lentoid gems
- Pasiphae = "She who shines for all" (moon-goddess)
- Triple pillars at shrines = waxing, full, waning moon
- Charites = phases of moon giving increase

> "The ritual of the Eniautos-Daimon, who was at once the representation of the life of the group and the life of nature, issued in agonistic festivals and in the drama. **What an Olympian negates:**
> "The complete human-nature god is, roughly speaking, what we call an Olympian. What then are his characteristics? It will be seen in the sequel that they are strangely, significantly negative, that an Olympian is in fact in the main the negation of an Eniautos-daimon." (p. 444)

This chapter examines the thunder-rites practiced by the Kouretes and Idaean Daktyls, using the Euripides *Cretans* fragment as primary evidence. Harrison argues that the mystic "accomplished the Thunders" (βροντὰς τελέσας) through three ritual acts: purification by thunder-stone, hearing mimic thunder from the bull-roarer, and beholding the thunderbolt on a throne. The chapter establishes that sanctity (*mana*) precedes divinity—the thunderbolt was worshipped before Zeus existed to wield it. ---

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:

Harrison analyzes a crucial passage preserved by Porphyry describing the initiation of a Bacchos:

> "There in one pure stream / My days have run, the servant I / Initiate of Idaean Jove; / Where midnight Zagreus roves, I rove. / I have endured his thunder-cry, / Fulfilled his red and bleeding feasts; / Held the Great Mother's mountain flame; / Enhallowed I and named by name / A Bacchos of the Mailed Priests." (p. 97)

**Key ritual elements:**
1. Thunder-cry (βροντάς) of night-wandering Zagreus
2. Feasts of Raw Flesh (ὠμοφαγία)
3. Mountain torches of the Great Mother
4. New name: "Bacchos"

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:

Harrison explains how Pythagoras was initiated by the Idaean Daktyls:

> "Pythagoras, Porphyry tells us, in the course of his journey from Asia Minor to Italy came to Crete. There he met on landing some of the Mystae of Morgos, one of the Idaean Daktyls, by whom he was initiated into their rites. The first rite he underwent at their hands was purification, and this purification was effected by—the thunderbolt or thunder-stone." (p. 102)

The thunder-stone is a prehistoric celt (stone axe) mistaken for a thunderbolt:

> "Such stones are called to-day by the modern Greek peasant 'lightning-axes' (ἀστροπελέκια). Great is their value as charms against thunder, *similia similibus*, to keep milk sweet, to cure rheumatism and the like." (p. 102)

metadata.title: Chapter III: The Kouretes, the Thunder-Rites and Mana

content:

Harrison identifies the instrument of mimic thunder:

> "We know the very instrument with which in ancient days mimic thunder was manufactured, the famous Bull-roarer or ῥόμβος, the sound of whose whirring is mystical, awe-inspiring, and truly religious. It is like nothing in the world but itself, perhaps the nearest approach is the ominous sound of a rising storm-wind or angry imminent thunder." (p. 107)

The scholiast on Clement describes it: "a bit of wood to which a string is tied, and it is whirled round and round at initiation-rites to make a whirring sound."

Harrison argues that the initiate beheld not Zeus but the thunderbolt itself:

> "The thunderbolt was to the primitive Greek not the symbol or attribute of the god, but itself the divine thing, the embodiment and vehicle of the god. As such, long after Zeus had taken on full human form in literature, it held its place in cultus, not as a weapon in the hand of the human god, but actually occupying his throne." (p. 105)

Evidence from coins of Seleukeia Pieria shows "a large thunderbolt with fillet attached, lying on a cushion on a throne."

Harrison traces the mythological identity of Zeus and the thunder-stone:

> "Hesiod knew it, at least subconsciously. When Kronos was about to swallow Zeus, what is it that Rhea gives him and that he really swallowed? A stone in swaddling clothes.... Long before Zeus was Zeus, thunder and lightning were, in a sense to be considered presently, divine potencies, their vehicle was a thunder-stone." (p. 106)

On the Hagia Triada terracotta relief: "We have seen three dancing Kouretes or Korybantes who clash their shields over the infant Zeus. Near him, lying on the ground, is a thunderbolt, his vehicle, his equivalent rather than his attribute."

> "The rites we are about to examine are then not rites of simple tribal initiation, but rather rites of initiation practised by the Kouretes in perhaps a later stage of their development as a magical fraternity. The Kouretes are now well on their way to become daimones; they will presently become actual gods (θεοί), as in Hesiod." (p. 98)

— Context: The Kouretes have specialized from general initiators to a magical fraternity. > "The word Titanes (white-clay-men) comes of course from τῑτάνος, white earth or clay, gypsum. The Titanes, the white-clay-men, were later, regardless of quantity, mythologized into Titanes, Titans, giants." (p. 95)

— Context: Etymology of Titans as initiators, not mythological beings. > "The Greeks, says a Christian Father, worship (θεραπεύουσι) the thunderbolt. The statement causes us something of a shock.... All he states is that they 'worshipped' the thunderbolt, that is, had a cult of it, tended it, attended to it, made it the object of 'religious' care." (p. 109)

— Context: Worship of the thunderbolt precedes worship of Zeus. ---

Harrison draws on Diodorus of Sicily to establish that Cretan mysteries were uniquely accessible:

> "The rite of initiation, which is perhaps the most celebrated of all, is that which is performed by the Athenian at Eleusis."

Yet at Knossos, the pattern was inverted:

> "At Knossos the custom was the rites should be open to all. Things that among others were communicated in secrecy, the Cretans concealed from no one who wished to know."

This openness distinguishes the Cretan mysteries from the exclusive Eleusinian model that later dominated Greek religion. ---

Harrison redefines the term "mystery"—not secrecy but ceremony of purification:

> "The usual derivation of the word is from μύω, I close the apertures whether of eyes or mouth."

But this misses the ritual meaning:

> "A Mystery is a rite, a drama, enacted with magical intent. Mystery is the doing of what relates to a μύσος—a pollution. Primarily, it is a ceremony of purification."

The Greek word for initiation (*τελετή*) likewise reveals the true nature of the rite:

> "The Greek word for initiation (τελετη) tells its own tale—it means not entering in, but completion, accomplishment, fulfilment."

- **Pages**: 111–157
- **Citation**: Harrison, J.E. (1912). *Themis*. Cambridge University Press, Chapter IV.

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

This chapter establishes the theoretical framework for understanding magic as the manipulation of *mana*, with *tabu* as its negative counterpart. Harrison argues that magic was originally public, social, and royal—not the hole-and-corner practice of later times. Using the Dipylon rain-making fragment and the legends of Salmoneus and Picus, she demonstrates that the medicine-king made the weather before any god existed to control it. The bird-magician Picus reveals the undifferentiated unity of bird, seer, magician, and king that preceded anthropomorphic theology. ---

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

Harrison begins with Plato's surprising definition:

> "In the first dialogue that bears the name of Alcibiades Socrates is urging on Alcibiades to an exceptionally high standard of conduct.... 'the one who is wisest teaches the magic (μαγείαν) of Zoroaster the son of Horomazos'; and then to our surprise Socrates adds by way of explanation, 'the art of the magician is the service (θεραπεία) of the gods. The same man gives instruction in kingly duties' (τὰ βασιλικά)." (p. 111)

**Key insight**: Magic was the service of the gods, and knowledge of magic was part of royal education.

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

Harrison analyzes an eighth-century vase showing ceremonial rain-making:

> "A man is seated before an altar on which is a great 'Mycenaean' shield. In either hand he holds an implement... The soft plash is unmistakable. *He is making rain*; making it in the simplest yet most magical fashion." (p. 113)

The implements are gourd-rattles, used worldwide for rain-magic. The medicine-man is not worshipping the shield—he is actively making weather.

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

Harrison rehabilitates Salmoneus from blasphemer to medicine-king:

> "'Salmoneus,' Apollodorus tells us, 'said that he himself was Zeus, and he took away from Zeus his sacrifices and ordered men to sacrifice to him.' Of course he did nothing of the sort: there was no Zeus, there were no sacrifices. What he really did, Apollodorus tells us in the next sentence, he made the weather: 'he fastened bronze cauldrons by straps of hide to his chariot and dragged them after him and said that he was thundering, and threw up blazing torches into the sky and said that he was lightening.'" (p. 114)

At Krannon in Thessaly: "there was kept a bronze waggon, and 'when the land suffered from drought they shook it by way of praying the god for rain, and it was said rain came.'"

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

Harrison's central thesis on the priority of sanctity:

> "We now know, from a study of the customs and representations of primitive peoples, that, broadly speaking, the reverse is true, a thing is regarded as sacred, and out of that sanctity, given certain conditions, emerges a daimon and ultimately a god. *Le sacré, c'est le père du dieu*." (p. 110)

The thunderbolt is sacred before Zeus exists to wield it.

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

Harrison defines the relationship between mana and tabu:

> "In Greece a place that was struck by lightning became an ἄβατον, a spot not to be trodden on, unapproachable.... The other name for these tabu-ed places speaks clearly—they were ἐνηλοσίαι, places of coming. This Pollux tells us, is the name given to places on which a bolt from heaven has descended." (p. 129)

**The ἄβατον** (forbidden place) is fenced because it is charged with dangerous *mana*, not because a god cursed it.

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

Harrison analyzes the Latin woodpecker-king:

> "In the figure of Picus are united, or rather as yet undifferentiated, notions, to us incompatible, of bird, seer-magician, king and daimon, if not god. The daimon as we have already seen with respect to the Kouros Kings were not deified because there were as yet no *dei*. The medicine-king is predeistic, but possessed of those powers which later and more cultured ages have relegated to the 'gods.'" (p. 148)

Picus and Faunus taught Numa the thunder-charm: "a purification (καθαρμόν) against thunderbolts... compounded of onions, hairs, and pilchards."

Harrison argues birds were first weather-makers, then weather-portents:

> "This early way of thinking comes out most clearly in the case of a bird who never became the 'attribute' of any Olympian, the homely woodpecker.... The mantic weather-bird precedes the prophetic god." (p. 137)

**Aristophanes' *Birds*** preserves the memory:
> "We are Delphi, Ammon, Dodona, in fine / We are every oracular temple and shrine... / If birds are your omens, it clearly will follow / That birds are the proper prophetic Apollo." (p. 138)

> "Three hundred stadia further (in the country of the Apennines) is Tiora, called Matiene. Here there is said to have been an oracle of Mars of great antiquity. It is reported to have been similar in character to the fabled oracle at Dodona, except that, whereas at Dodona it was said that a dove perched on a sacred oak gave oracles, among the Aborigines the oracles were given in like fashion by a god-sent bird called by them Picus (the Greeks name it Dryokolaptes) which appears on a wooden pillar." metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

> "Magic was no hole and corner practice but an affair of public ritual, performed with full social sanction. We have in fact a state of things like that which Socrates attributed to the Persians, a social phase in which magic was the service (θεραπεία) of the gods; instruction about it might well be given as part of the duties of a king (τὰ βασιλικά); in a word magic was of the state, not of the individual." (p. 115)

— Context: Against the view that magic was always marginal and disreputable. > "A tool is but an extension, an amplification, of a man's personality. If the savage feels that he can get *Wa-kon'-da*, surely that *Wa-kon'-da* can pass into that outer personality which is his tool, his weapon.... The shield on the altar is sacred because it is a shield, a tool, a defensive weapon, part of a man's personality, charged with magical force." (p. 120)

— Context: Why the Mycenaean shield is sacred without any god. > "The very vividness, the oneness of the perception, seen with the single intention of the poet, makes it to us hard of apprehension.... In the *Bacchae* we catch the god in the three stages of his making." (p. 131)

— Context: Dionysos in Euripides as simultaneously human leader, daimon, and god. ---

metadata.title: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu

content:
[Document: Chapter IV: Magic and Tabu | Tags: zeus-kataibates, picus, magic, tabu, mana, orenda, medicine-king, rain-making, hoplolatry, bird-magic]

Harrison analyzes the *Works and Days* conclusion:

> "Lucky and bless'd is he, who, knowing all these things, / Toils in the fields, blameless before the Immortals, / Knowing in birds and not overstepping tabus." (p. 134)

The pious man's duties are not prayer or sacrifice but **observance of sanctities**—knowing birds and avoiding tabu. The Olympians are "an artificial background."

- **Type**: Book Chapter
- **From**: *Themis: A Study of the Social Origins of Greek Religion*
- **Author**: Jane Ellen Harrison (1850–1928)
- **Date**: 1912
- **Pages**: 158–211
- **Citation**: Harrison, J.E. (1912). *Themis*. Cambridge University Press, Chapter V.

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

This chapter argues that the *omophagia* (eating of raw flesh) central to Bacchic initiation can only be understood through totemism—the felt unity between a human group and its animal or plant kin. Harrison contends that totemism is not a particular social structure but a stage in epistemology, a way of thinking prior to differentiation between subject and object, human and animal. Sacrifice and sacrament are both forms of *mana*-manipulation: building a bridge between human desire and the power of the sacred animal. The communal meal (δαίς) is the prototype of all religious communion. ---

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

The chapter opens with the rite the Bacchos must accomplish:

> "Before he can become a Bacchos, the candidate must have / Fulfilled his red and bleeding feasts. / The omophagia or Eating of Raw Flesh was a rite not confined to the Kouretic initiation of a Bacchos. We meet it again in the Thracian worship of Dionysos." (p. 158)

**The gist of the rite:**
> "Physically repugnant the rite must always be to our modern taste... But our moral repugnance disappears, or at least suffers profound modification, when the gist of the rite is understood. The omophagia was part of a religion, that is a system of sanctities, that knew no gods; it belongs to a social organization that preceded theology." (p. 159)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

Harrison adopts Frazer's revised definition:

> "'Totemism,' Dr Frazer says—and we cannot do better than adopt his definition—'is an intimate relation which is supposed to exist between a group of kindred people on the one side and a species of natural or artificial objects on the other side, which objects are called the totems of the human group.'" (p. 160)

**Two notes of totemism:**
1. It has to do with a **group**, not an individual
2. That group is in peculiar relation to a **non-human group**

The word *totem* itself means "tribe": "The Abbé Thavenal says the word is properly *ote* in the sense of 'family or tribe,' the possessive of which is *otem*."

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

Harrison's key insight—totemism is a stage of thinking:

> "Totemism, then, is not so much a special social structure as a stage in epistemology. It is the reflexion of a very primitive fashion in thinking, or rather feeling, the universe, a feeling the realization of which is essential to any understanding of primitive religion." (p. 164)

The primitive mind does not yet distinguish self from world:

> "Man in the totemistic stage rarely sets himself as individual over against his tribe; he rarely sets himself as man over against the world around him. He has not yet fully captured his individual or his human soul, not yet drawn a circle round his separate self." (p. 163)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

Harrison distinguishes μέθεξις from μίμησις:

> "The ceremonies are however still intensely sympathetic and cooperative; they are, as the Greeks would say, rather *methektic* than *mimetic*, participation to rather than imitation of.... The Emu man still feels he *is* an Emu; the feathers he puts on, the gait he emulates, are his own, not another's." (p. 167)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

Harrison analyzes Australian totem-multiplication rites:

> "When men of the Emu totem desire to multiply emus they set about it as follows. Several of the men open veins in their arms and allow the blood to stream on the ground till a patch about three yards square is saturated with it.... Further, several men of the totem, acting the part of ancestors of the Emu clan, dress themselves up to resemble emus and imitate the movements and aimless gazing about of the bird." (p. 166)

**Two elements:**
1. Shedding of human blood (the human Emu helps the animal Emu)
2. Counterfeit presentment (mystic communion intensified)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

Harrison redefines sacrifice:

> "The word sacrifice, like sacrament, tells the same tale. Etymologically there is nothing in either word that tells of a gift, nor yet of a god, no notion of renouncing, giving up to another and a greater. Sacrifice is simply either 'holy doing' or 'holy making,' ἱερὰ ῥέζειν, just *sanctification*, or, to put it in primitive language, it is handling, manipulating *mana*." (p. 172)

**The bridge metaphor:**
> "When you sacrifice you build as it were a bridge between your *mana*, your will, your desire, which is weak and impotent, and that unseen outside *mana* which you believe to be strong and efficacious." (p. 172)

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

Food as primary religious value:

> "Religion focuses round the needs and circumstances of life.... The primary need, more primary, more pressing than any other, is Food. Man focuses attention on it, feels acutely about it, organizes his social life in relation to it; it is his primary value, it and its pursuit necessarily become the subject-matter of his simplest religion, his δρώμενα, his rites." (p. 174)

Among the Damaras: "They have great reverence for the ox, only slaughter it on great occasions, and every slaughter is regarded as a common festival."

---

metadata.title: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice

content:
[Document: Chapter V: Totemism, Sacrament and Sacrifice | Tags: dionysus, totemism, omophagia, sparagmos, sacrament, sacrifice, communal-meal, methexis, mimesis, intichiuma]

> "One secret of the thrill of the Bacchae is that the god is always shifting his shape. Dionysos is a human youth, lovely, with curled hair, but in a moment he is a Snake, a Lion, a Wild Bull, a Burning Flame." (p. 169)

This is not late mysticism but primitive totemistic thinking:

> "Now all this is usually explained as a 'late' mysticism, a sort of pantheism, the god in all nature. In reality it goes back to things simpler and deeper. It is important to note that this shift to animal shape is not a power of transformation due to the mature omnipotence of the god; it is with the Dithyrambos from his birth." (p. 170)

The first chorus sings: "Then a horned God was found." The Dithyramb is reborn as a bull-god.

metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:

This chapter analyzes the spring *dromenon* as the prototype of Greek religious festival, using the famous Hagia Triada sarcophagos from Crete as primary evidence. Harrison argues that the paintings on the sarcophagos depict not a mere funeral but a seasonal renewal rite—the death and resurrection of the year-spirit. The chapter establishes the connection between Minoan cult practice and later Greek religion, showing how the Dithyramb preserves the structure of this archaic spring ceremony. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:
[Document: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos | Tags: zeus, dionysus, agathos-daimon, pasiphae, europa, charites, spring-festival, dithyramb, hieros-gamos, sacred-marriage]

Harrison analyzes this Late Minoan limestone coffin discovered in 1903:

> "The famous sarcophagos of Hagia Triada presents us, I believe, with a picture of actual Cretan ritual, ritual very closely analogous to, and probably ancestral to, the *dromenon* out of which arose the Dithyramb." (p. 159)

**The scenes depicted:**
1. **Bull sacrifice** - Animal tied to table, blood dripping into vessel
2. **Offerings to the dead** - Figures carrying offerings toward a building
3. **Tree and bird** - Sacred tree with bird perched upon it
4. **Standing figure** - Youth before a building (the *heroon*)
5. **Double axes** - Surmounted by birds throughout
6. **Musicians** - Lyre player and flute player

metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:
[Document: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos | Tags: zeus, dionysus, agathos-daimon, pasiphae, europa, charites, spring-festival, dithyramb, hieros-gamos, sacred-marriage]

The sarcophagos depicts the *hieros gamos*:

> "The wedlock of Earth and Sky is the central mystery of the spring festival. The bull-sacrifice is the means by which the worshippers participate in this cosmic union. The blood poured out is the rain of heaven fertilizing the earth." (p. 178)

**Symbolic elements:**
- Double axe = thunder symbol
- Bird on axe = sky-spirit
- Bull = earth-power
- Blood = rain

metadata.section: 2. The Sacred Marriage of Earth and Sky
metadata.title: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos

content:
[Document: Chapter VI: The Dithyramb, the Spring-Festival and the Hagia Triada Sarcophagos | Tags: zeus, dionysus, agathos-daimon, pasiphae, europa, charites, spring-festival, dithyramb, hieros-gamos, sacred-marriage]

Harrison identifies the bird on the double axe:

> "The cuckoo is, for the Greeks, the bird *par excellence* of the spring, of the sacred marriage. Zeus wooed Hera in the form of a cuckoo. The cuckoo's first song announces the season of ploughing and sowing." (p. 185)

The Hagia Triada bird is likely the cuckoo, marking the scene as a spring festival.

The mysterious standing figure before the building:

> "He is certainly I think a *kouros* like in youth and strength to the *kouroi* who approach him with offerings, only stiff and somewhat xoanon-like as becomes one who is a daimon not a man... Near him is his holy tree, sign and symbol of the life and function of an *Agathos Daimon*." (p. 195)

This figure is **not** a particular dead man but the **collective ancestor**, the year-spirit receiving seasonal offerings. ---

content:

Harrison connects the Cretan spring festival to lunar worship:

> "Pasiphae, 'She who shines for all,' is a Moon-goddess, and Europa her doublet. The bull who weds them is not the sun but the Moon-bull. Crete preserved this lunar reckoning longer than mainland Greece." (p. 186)

**Evidence for Minoan moon-cult:**
- Lentoid gems depicting crescent and horns
- Triple pillars at shrines = waxing, full, waning moon
- Horns of consecration = lunar crescents
- Pasiphae's name (πᾶσι-φάεια, "all-shining")

**The three Charites as moon-phases:**
| Phase | Charis | Function |
|-------|--------|----------|
| Waxing | Auxo ("Increaser") | Growth, increase |
| Full | Thallo ("Bloomer") | Flowering, fruition |
| Waning | Karpo ("Fruit-bearer") | Harvest, completion |

> "The Charites are not mere abstractions of grace and beauty; they are the three phases of the moon who gives increase to flocks and fields." (p. 188)

Harrison cites Cretan coins as evidence that archaic religious forms survived on Crete long after they disappeared elsewhere:

> "The coins of Gortyna show Europa on the tree, the coins of Phaistos the bull and the Europa myth. These are not mere mythological decoration—they are evidence of living cults." (p. 191)

**Key numismatic evidence:**
| Mint | Image | Significance |
|------|-------|--------------|
| Gortyna | Europa in tree | Tree-cult survival |
| Phaistos | Bull carrying Europa | Sacred marriage myth |
| Knossos | Labyrinth pattern | Labrys-cult continuity |
| Praesos | Double axe and bee | Melissa-cult |
| Lyttos | Eagle and serpent | Sky-earth polarity |

> "Crete, remote from the great currents of Hellenic religious development, preserved like a living fossil the rites and symbols of an earlier stratum. What mainland Greece forgot, Crete remembered." (p. 193)

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
[Document: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games | Tags: zeus, hera, pelops, sosipolis, kouretes, eniautos-daimon, year-spirit, new-year-festival, sacred-marriage, penteteris]

This chapter, contributed by Francis Macdonald Cornford, introduces the crucial concept of the **Eniautos-Daimon** (year-spirit) and argues that the Olympic Games originated not as funeral games for a dead chieftain (the Euhemeristic view of Ridgeway), but as a **New Year's festival**—the inauguration of a "Year" (*eniautos*). The Olympic victor does not merely commemorate a dead hero; he *becomes* the Eniautos-Daimon, the fertility-spirit of his year, embodying the community's luck and life-force. ---

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
[Document: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games | Tags: zeus, hera, pelops, sosipolis, kouretes, eniautos-daimon, year-spirit, new-year-festival, sacred-marriage, penteteris]

Cornford rejects the prevailing view that the Games originated as funeral rites for Pelops:

> "It thus appears that the funeral theory, which would have the whole Olympic festival originate in the obsequies of an actual man called Pelops, is contradicted by the more ancient traditions of Elis and unsupported by any monumental evidence. The field is clear for an alternative theory which will take account of the fact that the Games were believed to be older than the time of Pelops." (p. 245)

**Key evidence against funeral origin:**
- No grave of Pelops found at excavations—only a neolithic baby
- Ancient tradition traces Games to before Pelops
- The "dead" at other panhellenic games were not chieftains (Archemoros was an infant, Glaukos a sea-daimon, and at Pytho, a snake)
- Hero-sacrifices at Pelops' precinct were annual, but Games were penteteric

metadata.title: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games

content:
[Document: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games | Tags: zeus, hera, pelops, sosipolis, kouretes, eniautos-daimon, year-spirit, new-year-festival, sacred-marriage, penteteris]

Cornford proposes that the Games reflect a **Saturnalian** or **Kronian** festival—a ritual of the dying year defeated by the vigorous new year:

> "According to the view which we shall put forward, the Games are to be regarded as originally and essentially a New Year's festival—the inauguration of a 'Year.' If it can be shown that the legends can be interpreted as reflecting rites appropriate to such a festival, the hypothesis will have some claim to acceptance." (p. 247)

The central theoretical innovation—the *Eniautos-Daimon* (year-spirit):

> "We may think of the temporary 'king' as actually being the eniautos-daimon or fertility spirit of his 'year.' When the year is fixed by the solar period, we get festivals of the type of the Roman Saturnalia or the Greek Κρόνια... and the single combat appears as the driving out of winter or of the dying year by the vigorous young spirit of the New Year that is to come. It is as eniautos-daimon, not at first as 'incarnate god' or as king in the later political sense, that the representative of the fertility powers of nature dies at the hands of the New Year." (p. 259)

The term *eniautos* denotes:
- A lunar or solar year
- A longer period: 2, 4, or 8 years (trieteris, penteteris, enneateris)

Cornford disentangles two separable elements:

| Factor | Content | Ritual Meaning |
|--------|---------|----------------|
| **(a) Single Combat** | Young king defeats old king | Death of old year, succession of new year-daimon |
| **(b) Marriage Flight** | Bride carried off in chariot | Sacred marriage of Sun and Moon |

> "It is obvious that this story does not describe a primitive form of mere sport. It is made up of at least two distinct factors. (a) There is, first, the contest between the young and the old king, ending in the death of the elder and the succession of the younger to the kingdom. (b) Second, there is the carrying off (ἁπαγή) of the bride." (p. 249)

The victor was treated with divine honors:

> "The Olympic victor... was treated with honours both regal and divine; feasted in the prytaneum; crowned with a spray of olive like the wreath of Zeus himself; pelted, like a tree-spirit or Jack-in-the-Green, with leaves... Finally, on his return to his native city, the victor was dressed in royal purple and drawn by white horses through a breach in the walls. In many cases he was worshipped after death, as a hero; not because he was a successful athlete, but because he had once been an incarnate god." (p. 251)

The Elean tradition traces the Games to a foot-race of Cretan Kouretes:

> "With regard to the Olympic games, the Elean antiquaries say that Kronos first reigned in Heaven, and that a temple was made for him by the men of that age, who were named the Golden Race; that when Zeus was born, Rhea committed the safe-keeping of the child to the Idaean Daktyls or Kouretes, as they are also called; that the Daktyls came from Ida in Crete, and their names were Herakles, Paeonaeus, Epimedes, Jasios, and Idas; and that in sport Herakles, the eldest, set his brethren to run a race, and crowned the victor with a branch of wild olive." (p. 271)

**Conclusion**: "The race, we may suppose, determined who should be the Kouros—the Greatest Kouros—of his year."

The women's games (Heraea) preceded the men's games and belong to the older lunar calendar:

> "The Heraea, then, were probably older than the reconstituted Olympia; and if they gave its name to the month Parthenios, they must have been annual before they were octennial or penteteric. They carry us back to the old lunar year, which preceded the combined sun-and-moon penteteris." (p. 266)

**Key points:**
- Run by the Sixteen Women who wove a robe for Hera
- Virgins raced in order of age (youngest first)
- Victor received olive crown and portion of sacrificed cow
- Associated with Hera Parthenos (virgin Hera renewed after sacred marriage)

Dr. Frazer's interpretation, accepted by Cornford:

> "The union of the full moon and the full-grown Sun is one form—the astronomical—of that sacred marriage which in many parts of the ancient world was celebrated at midsummer. This union, we suggest, is symbolised by the marriage of Pelops and Hippodameia... He gives reason for holding that 'under the names of Zeus and Hera the pair of Olympic victors'... 'would seem to have really personated the sun and moon, who were the true heavenly bridegroom and bride of the ancient octennial festival'." (p. 262)

**Evidence:**
- Twelve rounds of chariot-race = Sun through twelve signs
- Hippodameia = "Horse-tamer" = Moon who rides her horse
- Endymion's fifty daughters = fifty moon months of penteteris
- At stadium starting point: tomb of Endymion (sinking Sun who married Selene)

Oinomaos as weather-magician:

**Sacred tree complex:**
- Phorbas dwelt under oak, challenged pilgrims, hung heads on tree
- At Olympia: wooden pillar (Oinomaos' palace) survived lightning strike
- Altar of Zeus Keraunios (Thunderbolt Zeus) at the spot

Cornford identifies a complex of ancient shrines at the foot of the Hill of Kronos:

| Shrine | Deity | Significance |
|--------|-------|--------------|
| Metroon | Mother Goddess | Very ancient cult |
| Altar of Kouretes | Kouretes | Attendants of infant Zeus |
| Shrine of Eileithyia-Sosipolis | Mother and Infant | The Idaean Cave counterpart |

> "So we find among the most ancient monuments of the Altis a complex of shrines dedicated to the Mother and Child, and the attendant Kouretes—a group whose significance has already been made clear. It represents the three essential factors of a matrilinear society." (p. 275)

**Sosipolis** ("Saviour of the City"):
- Infant god worshipped in cave-shrine
- Manifested as snake
- Fed honey-cakes by aged priestess
- Represents the Eniautos-Daimon in infant form

> "We shall be on safer ground if we restrict ourselves to the simple primitive group, consisting of the weather-magician who wields the fertilising influences of Heaven, and the tree which embodies the powers of the Earth—the vegetation which springs up when the thunder shower has burst, and Heaven and Earth are married in the life-giving rain." (p. 250)

— Context: Cornford cautions against over-theological interpretation; the primitive pattern is weather-magic + sacred tree. > "Magic—the magic which immediately controls the food-supply and the natural phenomena on which it depends—was carried on before there were any gods at all, and can be carried on by direct mimetic methods, without any prayerful appeals to dead ancestors." (p. 247)

— Context: Magic precedes religion; *dromenon* precedes prayer. ---

content:
[Document: Chapter VII: The Origin of the Olympic Games | Tags: zeus, hera, pelops, sosipolis, kouretes, eniautos-daimon, year-spirit, new-year-festival, sacred-marriage, penteteris]

Cornford draws a crucial parallel between Olympic ritual and the Laconian Karneia:

> "At the Karneia, a festival of Apollo Karneios held at Sparta, there was a race of young men called Staphylodromoi, 'runners with grape-clusters.' One of them was decked with fillets of wool and ran in front. The others pursued him, and if they caught him, the event was held to be of good omen for the city; if not, of evil omen." (p. 255)

**The Staphylodromoi ritual:**
| Element | Description | Parallel |
|---------|-------------|----------|
| **The pursued** | Youth decked in wool | Old year-daimon |
| **The pursuers** | Young men with grape-clusters | New year competing |
| **Good omen** | Catching the pursued | Successful succession |
| **Evil omen** | Escape of the pursued | Fertility failure |

> "If we may interpret this race by the analogy of the Olympic legend, the youth who ran in front with the fillets of wool was the outgoing Eniautos-daimon, whom it was necessary to capture and kill. The runners with the grape-clusters are the young men competing for his place." (p. 256)

**The Karneia as parallel:**
- Both festivals involve a chase/contest determining the year-daimon
- Both have archaic elements suggesting pre-Olympian origin
- Both originally annual, later made penteteric
- The grape-clusters (*staphylai*) = vegetation-spirit symbolism

---

The hero-cult is not memorial but functional:

> "The hero is not honoured because he was a great man who deserved commemoration. He is worshipped because his cult serves a function—the function of ensuring the community's fertility and luck. When that function ceases to be understood, the aetiological myth steps in to explain the cult as mere commemoration of the dead." (p. 249)

**The Cornford critique summarized:**
| Ridgeway (Funeral Theory) | Cornford (Ritual Theory) |
|---------------------------|--------------------------|
| Individual hero primary | Collective group primary |
| Funeral games came first | Year-festival came first |
| Hero is dead chieftain | Hero is projected daimon |
| Religion from soul-belief | Religion from *dromenon* |
| Games commemorate death | Games enact succession |

metadata.title: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero

content:
[Document: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero | Tags: agathos-daimon, zeus, cecrops, erechtheus, theseus, hippolytus, hero-cult, functionary, snake-cult, fertility-spirit]

This chapter establishes Harrison's revolutionary thesis that the Greek "hero" is not a dead man but a *functionary*—the projection of a group's collective daimon wearing the mask of an individual. The hero is κρείττων τὴν φύσιν ("stronger in nature") not because of personal achievement but because he embodies the Agathos Daimon, the fertility-spirit of the clan. Using evidence from "Hero Feasts," the cult of Theseus, and the Oschophoria festival, Harrison demonstrates that the hero takes on the life-history of the Eniautos-Daimon and thereby provides the ritual forms (agon, pathos, messenger, threnos, theophany) that underlie Attic tragedy. ---

[Document: Chapter VIII: Daimon and Hero | Tags: agathos-daimon, zeus, cecrops, erechtheus, theseus, hippolytus, hero-cult, functionary, snake-cult, fertility-spirit]

Harrison overturns the assumption that heroes are commemorated dead men:

> "The 'Hero' is not a dead man with a known name and history commemorated by funeral games. His title stands not for a personality, but for an office, defined by its functions and capable of being filled by a series of representatives." (p. 302)

**The word "hero" means "strong" or "powerful":**
> "κρείττονες, Hesychius tells us, is a general term for heroes and for gods, but not all dead men were κρείττονες. This reminds us that the meaning of the word 'hero' is actually not 'dead man,' but, if we may trust Hesychius, it means simply 'powerful,' 'strong,' 'noble,' 'venerable.'" (p. 291)

Harrison analyzes over 300 preserved "Hero Feast" reliefs:

> "A man reclines at a banquet; his wife, according to Athenian custom, is seated by his side. In front is a table loaded with cake and fruits.... But other elements in the design forbid this simple interpretation.... The answer is given, I think, by the snake, who with seeming irrelevance uprears himself beneath the table. The banqueter is a man... And yet he is no real god, no Olympian; rather he is a man masked to his descendants as a daimon, as the Agathos Daimon." (p. 307)

**The rhyton (cornucopia) as daimonic attribute:**
> "They 'assign' the rhyton, the great horn, as appropriate to a hero, because the hero as *daimon* had it from the beginning—the rhyton is the cornucopia." (p. 309)

The snake represents not death but reincarnation and fertility:

> "The snake then stands for life and mana, not for death. In the light of the snake as life-daimon, as 'more than mortal,' we understand many birth-stories current in antiquity." (p. 291)

**The Cleomenes story proves the point:**
> "A few days after, those who were guarding the impaled body saw a huge snake (δράκοντα) wound about the head.... Thereupon a superstitious fear fell on the king and such a dread that it started the women on various purification ceremonies, inasmuch as a man had been put to death who was dear to the gods and of more than mortal nature (κρείττονος τὴν φύσιν)." (p. 290)

Theseus exemplifies the transition from group-daimon to individual hero:

> "Theseus lays no claim to be autochthonous.... He comes from without; he represents the break with the gentile system, with the gens and its Basileus; he stands for democracy. His was the *synoikia*." (p. 331)

The Oschophoria preserves the ritual pattern:

> "In the Oschophoria the winner of the race is, as at Olympia, an *Eniautos-daimon* and a *basileus* in one. He dies as an individual and revives as an eternally recurrent functionary." (p. 355)
